Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Denison, Texas" and may be so cited. 
(Code 1965, § 1-1) 
Charter reference- Authority of council to codify and print ordinances in code form, § 2.15. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to adopt a civil and criminal Code of Ordinances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 53.001 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    The provisions of this Code shall be liberally construed to effect the purposes expressed therein or implied from the expression thereof. In case of doubt or ambiguity in the meaning of such provisions, the general shall yield to the particular. Reference for interpretation and construction shall tend to further the accomplishment of the elimination of the particular mischiefs for which the provisions were enacted. Words shall be construed in their common and usual significance unless the contrary is clearly indicated. In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council, the following rules shall be observed and the following definitions shall apply, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Charter. The word Charter shall mean the Charter of the City of Denison, Texas printed in Part I of this volume. 
    City. The word city shall mean the City of Denison, in the County of Grayson and the State of Texas. 
    City council. The words council or city council shall mean the City Council of the City of Denison, constituting the governing body of the city. 
    City officers, departments, boards, committees, or commissions. Whenever reference is made to officers, departments, boards, committees, or commissions, the same shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Denison, Texas." 
    Code. The word Code shall mean this Code of Ordinances, City of Denison, Texas. 
    Computation of time. In computing any period of time mentioned in the provisions of this Code, the day of the act, event or default after which the designated period of time begins to run is not to be included, and the last day of the period so computed is to be included, unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day which is neither a Saturday, Sunday nor a holiday. 
    County. The term county shall mean the County of Grayson, Texas. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, associations and corporations, as well as to males. 
    Health officer. The director of the Denison-Sherman-Grayson County Health Unit shall have the authority and the duties set forth in this Code for the city health officer, and wherever the term "health officer" is used, either the city health officer or the director of such health unit shall have the right, authority, duty and responsibility to act. 
    Highway. The term highway shall include any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass and causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three (3) or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared. 
    Month. The word month shall mean a calendar month. 
    Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
    oath. The word oath shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words swear and sworn shall be equivalent to the words affirm and affirmed. 
    or, and. Or may be read and, and and may be read or, if the sense requires it. 
    owner. The word owner, applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word person shall extend and be applied to associations, corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Where criminal prosecution may lie, the officers of any corporation shall jointly and severally be subject to prosecution as being included within the term person. 
    Preceding, following. The words preceding and following mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Roadway. The word roadway shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Sidewalk. The word sidewalk shall mean any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription. The word signature or subscription shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
    Standard time. All hours of time mentioned in this Code refer to and shall be determined by Central Standard Time, as commonly known, except that, if at any future time any different standard of time is established by the United States for an area which includes this city, all such hours shall be determined by such officially proclaimed standard, so long as the same remains in effect. 
    State. The word state shall be construed to mean the State of Texas. 
    Street. The term street shall include any highway, alley, street, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, underpass, overpass, tunnel and causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. The abbreviation Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. shall mean the latest edition or supplement of Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes. 
    V.T.C.A. The abbreviation V.T.C.A. shall mean the Vernon's Texas Codes Annotated latest edition or supplement. 
    Written or in writing. The words written or in writing shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word year shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1965, § 1-3) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 312.001 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1965, § 1-2) 
Sec. 1-4. - References and editor's notes. 
    The references and editor's notes appearing throughout the Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to assist the user of the Code. 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
Sec. 1-7. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any ordinance regarding any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of such Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; 
(3)  Any ordinance authorizing any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(4)  Any ordinance regarding any right or franchise granted by the city; 
(5)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(6)  Any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades for streets in the city; 
(7)  Any appropriation ordinance or ordinances providing for the levy of taxes or for adopting an annual budget; 
(8)  Any ordinance relating to local improvements and assessments therefor; 
(9)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the city or discontinuing territory as a part of the city; 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city; 
(11)  Any ordinance or resolution establishing or amending personnel rules or regulations; 
(12)  Any ordinance or resolution prescribing taxicab passenger rates; 
(13)  Ordinances prescribing traffic regulations for specific streets, such as ordinances establishing speed limits or designating one-way streets, no parking areas, truck routes, stop intersections, intersections where traffic to be controlled by signals, etc.; 
(14)  Any ordinance establishing or amending zoning or land use regulations or the zoning map, or rezoning property; 
(15)  Any ordinance calling municipal elections or prescribing the manner of conducting the election in accordance with state law; 
(16)  Any ordinance prescribing any fee or payment of money to the city; 
(17)  Any ordinance prescribing the number, classification, benefits or compensation of any city officers or employees, not inconsistent herewith; 
(18)  Any ordinance which is temporary although general in effect; 
(19)  Any ordinance which is special although permanent in effect; 
(20)  Any ordinance containing any administrative provisions; 
and all such ordinances shall remain in effect and are on file in the city clerk's office. 
Sec. 1-8. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty of forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-9. - Amendments or additions to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are re-adopted as a new Code by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Denison, Texas, is hereby amended to read as follows:..." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Denison, Texas, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _____, which section reads as follows: ..." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, divisions, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1965, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-10. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-11. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable and, if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the council without the incorporation in this Code of any such invalid or unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1965, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-12. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
    Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or wherever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for violations of all ordinances that govern fire safety, zoning or public health and sanitation including dumping of refuse and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for all other violations provided however, that no penalty shall be greater or less than the penalty provided for the same or a similar offense under the laws of the state. Each day any violation of this Code or any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 1-6) 
Cross reference- Miscellaneous offenses, Ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prescribe penalties for violation of ordinances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.001.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City manager general authority. 
    Whenever in this Code the city manager or his staff is required to act affirmatively or to refrain from certain actions as set forth in this Code, and whenever the city manager is of the opinion that strict compliance with the code requirement will result in undue hardship or unequal treatment in the implementation of city services, the city manager may alter the action of city staff in a manner inconsistent with the stated requirement to act or refrain by notifying the staff member concerned in writing of the city manager's decision and instruction, with a copy immediately transmitted to members of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 1(a), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Former § 2-1, pertaining to the designation of the city clerk as records management officer, was deleted as being superseded by the provisions of Ord. No. 3251, adopted Nov. 19, 1990, codified herein as Art. VI. The deleted provision derived from Ord. No. 3224, adopted May 21, 1990. 
 Subsequently, Ord. No. 4701, § 1(a), adopted June 17, 2013, added new provisions as herein set out. 
Secs. 2-2-2-35. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-36. - Youth advisory commission-Created. 
    There shall be established and maintained a commission to be known and maintained as the Denison Youth Advisory Commission (YAC) in the City of Denison, Texas, to serve as a liaison between the city staff and the youth of the community. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-37. - Membership. 
    The YAC shall consist of twenty (20) members and shall be chosen by the city council to serve two-year terms, without compensation. The terms shall run from September 1 to August 31 of each year. Members shall be between the ages of fourteen (14) and nineteen (19). These members shall meet at least one (1) of the following qualifications: 
(1)  Reside within the corporate boundaries of the City of Denison; or 
(2)  Reside within the boundaries of the Denison Independent School District; or 
(3)  Attend a state-recognized school or homeschool within the corporate boundaries of the City of Denison. 
    The following may be ex-officio, non-voting members of the YAC: 
(1)  Two (2) residents affiliated with Denison youth, appointed by the city manager, or his/her designee, to serve as facilitators to the YAC. 
(2)  One (1) city staff member appointed by the city manager to serve as a non-voting, staff liaison to the YAC. 
    No individual who has been convicted of a felony shall be qualified to serve as an ex-officio member of the YAC. By submitting an application for appointment to the YAC, applicants for ex-officio membership must consent to a background check for such purposes, to the extent provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-38. - Application process. 
    All members of the YAC shall be selected through an application process and shall be appointed by the city manager, or his/her designee, and take office upon being sworn in. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-39. - Same-Terms of office; vacancies. 
    The term of office for each member shall be two (2) years, or until his or her successor is duly appointed and qualified. However, when a vacancy occurs prior to the expiration of a term, an appointment may be made by the city manager, or his/her designee, for the remainder of the unexpired terms. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-40. - Officers. 
    The YAC shall elect from its membership officers for two-year terms of office commencing on the first day of September of each year. A member shall be eligible for reelection to any of these offices as long as he or she remains on the YAC. Officers shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Chair: The person, elected by the members of the YAC, who is responsible for running meetings, developing agenda items and helping all officers with their duties. 
(2)  Vice chair: The person, elected by the members of the YAC, who is responsible for running meetings when the chair is not present and helping all officers with their duties. 
(3)  Secretary: The person, elected by the members of the YAC, who is responsible for taking minutes and making sure the YAC city staff liaison has the updated minutes. 
(4)  Historian: The person, elected by the members of the YAC, who is responsible for keeping track of the history of the YAC, including event documentation, photography and website content submittal. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-41. - Functions. 
    The YAC shall study, investigate, plan, implement and advise the city of matters related to youth. Specifically, the YAC is assigned with identifying areas for improvement related to youth, including developing programs and services that empower, support, and inform youth; that create a family-friendly community; and that enable and encourage youth to be productive members of the community. The YAC shall serve as an advisory body to the city on all matters that relate to youth. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-42. - Meetings. 
    The YAC shall hold meetings at least quarterly at locations in the city at times it may designate. At all meetings of the YAC, the presence of a majority of the members then in office shall be necessary and sufficient to constitute a quorum, and an affirmative vote of the majority of those present shall be necessary to pass upon pending questions, except that on tie votes, the vote of the chairperson shall be determinative, the chairperson in addition being entitled to vote on all questions. Minutes of the meeting shall be kept and the record filed with the person performing the duty of YAC city staff liaison. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-43. - Recommendations. 
    In the performance of its function, the YAC is an advisory body authorized to make recommendations to the city manager on: 
(a)  Policy matters affecting the youth of the community; 
(b)  Planning, organizing, coordinating and carrying out drug-free and alcohol free social, cultural, recreational, achieving, educational and other activities for the youth of the community; 
(c)  Establishing guidelines, rules and procedures for participation in such activities; and 
(d)  Entering into agreements with entertainers, concessionaries and other third parties as may be deemed desirable by the YAC within available funds and in accordance with applicable state and city laws and procedures. 
    All revenues derived from fundraising or other means associated with the YAC, which are under the direct control of the city, shall be maintained by the city and deposited to the appropriate fund for utilization in support of YAC related activities to the extent of citywide needs as determined by the city manager, or his/her designee, during the annual budgeting of funds for all city departments. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-44. - Reports. 
    By August 1 of each year, the YAC shall submit to the city council a written report of its activities for the previous year and an annual plan of work for the ensuing year. These documents shall be retained as part of the official city records. 
    Subject to the approval of the city manager, the facilities and personnel of the city shall be made available to assist the YAC in carrying out its functions. 
    The YAC is authorized to amend its rules and procedures for the conduct of its authorized activities, subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
Sec. 2-45. - Attendance. 
    Any member who is unable to attend a meeting shall notify the chair or facilitator in advance of the meeting, stating the reason for his or her absence. YAC members are permitted three (3) unexcused absences from regular meetings. Excessive absences will cause a member's appointment to be reviewed by the YAC officers and ex-officio staff, with potential presentation to the city manager, or his/her designee, for action to remove. 
(Ord. No. 4205, § 1, 2-16-04; Ord. No. 4827, § 1, 8-1-16; Ord. No. 4953, § 2, 7-16-18) 
ARTICLE II. - AUTHORITIES, BOARDS, COMMITTEES, COMMISSIONS[2] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Personnel, Ch. 16; sign review committee, § 19-52; parks and recreation commission, § 18-86 et seq.; board of adjustment, § 28-46 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-46. - Residency requirements for certain appointees. 
(a)  No person is eligible to be appointed to or to serve on the following boards and commissions of the city, nor to be appointed to the following boards or commissions over which the city council or one (1) of its members as the power of appointment, unless that person is a resident of the city at the time of appointment; to-wit: 
(1)  Business and Industrial Corporation of Denison, Inc.; 
(2)  Civil service commission; 
(3)  Community development steering committee; 
(4)  Cemetery advisory board; 
(5)  Greater Texoma Utility Authority; 
(6)  Housing board of adjustment and appeals; 
(7)  Planning and zoning commission; 
(8)  Zoning board of adjustments and appeals; 
(9)  Public library board of directors; 
(10)  Texoma Council of Governments Board of Directors; 
(11)  Buildings appeals board; 
(12)  Denison Community Investment Corporation, subject to the requirements of its corporate by-laws; 
(13)  Parks and recreation advisory board; 
(14)  Convention and visitors bureau advisory board. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 1(b), 6-17-13; Ord. No. 4781, § 1, 4-6-15; Ord. No. 4967, § 2(2.01), 10-1-18) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 2-46 in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as herein set out. Former § 2-46 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3698, § 1, adopted Feb. 17, 1997. 
Cross reference- Qualifications and terms of members, § 2-63; planning and zoning commission, § 2-96 et seq.; parks and recreation commission, § 18-86 et seq.; board of adjustment, § 28-46 et seq. 
Sec. 2-47. - Attendance requirements for persons appointed to boards and commissions. 
    Any person appointed to city boards and commissions shall maintain an annual attendance record of not less than seventy-five (75) percent of all regularly and specially called meetings of such board or commission. Each board or commission shall review annually the attendance of members and report to the city council any noncompliance with this section, along with a recommendation of appropriate city council action. In the event the city council determines that any person subject to the requirements of this section has failed to meet such requirements, the city council may declare such person's seat to be vacant. 
(Code 1965, § 2-14) 
Cross reference- Hospital authority, § 2-61 et seq.; planning and zoning commission, § 2-96 et seq.; parks and recreation commission, § 18-86 et seq.; board of adjustment, § 28-46 et seq. 
Sec. 2-48. - Terms of office, appointees. 
(a)  For each board and commission created by the Charter or ordinances of the city, the term of office for each place on the board or commission shall commence on January 1 and continue for the term of years specified in the Charter or ordinance creating the board or commission. 
(b)  In the implementation of the foregoing subsection (a), each term of office existing on the effective date of this provision shall be extended to the 31st of December next following the existing expiration date of such term. The additional time that the appointee serves by virtue of the extension herein created shall not be counted toward the limitation of service established at Section 10.13 of the Charter of the City of Denison. 
(Ord. No. 3411, § 1, 9-20-93) 
Secs. 2-49-2-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT STEERING COMMITTEE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4361, adopted June 19, 2006, repealed former Div. 2, §§ 2-61-2-80, the provisions of which pertained to the hospital authority. See also the Code Comparative Table for ordinance history.  Subsequently, Ord. No. 4781, §§ 1-7, adopted April 6, 2015, enacted new provisions, but did not specify manner of inclusion. At the discretion of the editor, said provisions have codified to read as herein setout. 

Sec. 2-61. - Name. 
    The community development steering and housing rehabilitation committee shall be renamed the community development steering committee. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 1, 4-6-15) 
Sec. 2-62. - Composition; appointment of members. 
    The community development steering committee shall be composed of five (5) members appointed by majority vote of the city council. Such committee shall be advisory to the city council, and shall possess no authority to bind the city. The committee shall assist the city council in the assessment of the community block grant program for the City of Denison. The committee shall conduct public hearings to receive input from the community on the expenditure of funds. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 2, 4-6-15) 
Sec. 2-63. - Qualifications and terms of members. 
    The members of the community development steering committee shall meet the residency requirement as provided in the City of Denison Municipal Code, section 2-46. Each member of the community development steering committee shall serve for a term of two (2) years. The city council may, by majority vote, appoint a resident citizen of the City of Denison for the remainder of a vacant and unexpired term. Members shall be limited to appointment for not more than three (3) complete successive terms for a total of six (6) years. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 3, 4-6-15) 
Sec. 2-64. - Members to serve without compensation. 
    The members of the community development steering committee shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 4, 4-6-15) 
Sec. 2-65. - Organization; meetings. 
    The members of the community development steering committee shall organize and select a chairman every January. The meetings will be conducted at least quarterly to report the progress of the program. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 5, 4-6-15) 
Sec. 2-66. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the community development steering committee shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of transacting business of the committee. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 6, 4-6-15) 
Sec. 2-67. - Rules of procedure; record of proceedings. 
    The community development steering committee shall adopt its own rules and procedure and keep a record of its proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 4781, § 7, 4-6-15) 
Secs. 2-68-2-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Residency requirements for appointees, § 2-46; attendance requirements for persons appointed, § 2-47; flood prevention and protection, Ch. 8; planning, Ch. 17; subdivisions, Ch. 22; zoning, Ch. 28. 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.001 et seq.; municipal zoning commissions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.007. 

Sec. 2-96. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a planning and zoning commission consisting of five (5) members and four (4) alternate members, all of whom shall be residents of the city. Alternate members shall serve in the absence of one (1) or more of the regular members when requested by the city manager. 
(Code 1965, § 2-20) 
Sec. 2-97. - Appointment and terms. 
    Members and alternate members of the planning and zoning commission shall be appointed by the city council and shall serve for a term of two (2) years or until their successors are appointed. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member or alternate whose term becomes vacant. 
(Code 1965, § 2-21) 
Charter reference- Limitation on number of consecutive terms, § 10.13. 
Sec. 2-98. - Compensation. 
    Members and alternates of the planning and zoning commission shall serve without compensation. However, the city council may authorize the payment of expenses for travel and meetings and similar costs which may be incurred incident to the duties of the planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1965, § 2-22) 
Sec. 2-99. - Removal. 
    Any member or alternate of the planning and zoning commission may be removed by the city council for cause upon written charges and after public hearing. 
(Code 1965, § 2-23) 
Sec. 2-100. - Appointment of officers; adoption of rules. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall appoint its own chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary and shall adopt rules for the conduct of meetings and such other activities as may be appropriate. 
(Code 1965, § 2-24) 
Sec. 2-101. - Meetings. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall meet once each month and at such other times as the chairman or a majority of the regular members of the commission may direct. 
(Code 1965, § 2-25) 
Sec. 2-102. - Quorum. 
    Five (5) members or alternates of the planning and zoning commission shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1965, § 2-26) 
Sec. 2-103. - Duties with respect to zoning ordinance. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall perform all functions necessary to carry out the intent of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 211.001-211.013 relative to the preparation, adoption and amendment of a comprehensive zoning ordinance for the city, including the conduct of public hearings related thereto. The commission shall perform the functions of the zoning board of adjustment as specified by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.008 and by the city's comprehensive zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1965, § 2-27) 
Cross reference- Zoning, Ch. 28; board of adjustment, § 28-46 et seq. 
Sec. 2-104. - Review, approval of subdivision plats. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall perform all functions related to the review and approval of subdivision plats which may be assigned to it by the statutes of the state and ordinances or charter of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-28) 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 2-105. - Duties with respect to flood control ordinance. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall perform all functions necessary to carry out the intent of chapter 8 regarding flood prevention and control and shall perform all duties therein ascribed to it, including specifically the following: 
(1)  To hear and determine appeals from a decision of the director of public works denying a floodplain building permit; and 
(2)  To hear and determine applications for variances and/or exceptions to the provisions of flood prevention and control, chapter 8. 
(Code 1965, § 2-29) 
Cross reference- Flood prevention and protection, § 8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-106. - Recommendations, advice to council. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall recommend to and advise the city council on matters involving the physical improvement of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-30) 
Sec. 2-107. - Records and reports. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall maintain a record of its meetings and shall report to the city council at least once each year concerning its activities for the past year and its intended activity for the ensuing year. 
(Code 1965, § 2-31) 
DIVISION 4. - ANIMAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE (AAC) 

Sec. 2-108. - Creation of animal advisory committee. 
    There is hereby created an Animal Advisory Committee (AAC). 
(Ord. No. 4804, § 1, 1-4-16) 
Sec. 2-109. - Composition of the animal advisory committee. 
    The AAC must be composed of at least one (1) licensed veterinarian, one (1) municipal official, one (1) person whose duties include the daily operation of an animal shelter, one (1) representative from an animal welfare organization and one (1) member of the general public. 
(Ord. No. 4804, § 1, 1-4-16; Ord. No. 4818, § 2(2.01), 7-18-16) 
Sec. 2-110. - Meetings. 
    The AAC shall meet at least three (3) times a year. 
(Ord. No. 4804, § 1, 1-4-16) 
Sec. 2-111. - Terms. 
    AAC members shall serve staggered two-year terms in accordance with section 2-48 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4804, § 1, 1-4-16; Ord. No. 4818, § 2(2.02), 7-18-16) 
Sec. 2-112. - Officers. 
    A chair, vice chair and secretary of the AAC shall be elected by and from the members and shall serve for a term of one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 4804, § 1, 1-4-16; Ord. No. 4818, § 2(2.03), 7-18-16) 
Sec. 2-113. - Powers. 
    The AAC shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt rules and procedures as necessary to provide for the orderly conduct of meetings. 
(2)  Maintain written minutes that record all discussions and recommendations approved by the AAC and the reasons for taking such actions. 
(3)  Conduct surveys and gather information related to animal welfare in the City of Denison. 
(4)  Make advisory recommendations to the city council on policies, programs, or other topics pertaining to the general welfare of animals in the city. Undertake any other research or advisory task at the request of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 4804, § 1, 1-4-16) 
Sec. 2-114. - Meetings. 
    The AAC shall meet at least three (3) times a year. Special meetings may be called at any from time to time as deemed necessary All meetings shall be held in conformance with the Texas Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 4804, § 1, 1-4-16) 
DIVISION 5. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION BOARD 

Sec. 2-115. - Creation of the historic preservation board. 
    There is hereby created a board to be known as the Denison Historic Preservation Board (HPB). 
(Ord. No. 4937, § 5, 3-19-18) 
Sec. 2-116. - Composition of the historic preservation board. 
(a)  The historic preservation board shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the city council. At least two (2) members shall be business owners or property owners within the district. All members shall have a known and demonstrated interest, competence, or knowledge of historic preservation within the City of Denison. The members shall serve at the pleasure of the city council and may be removed at the discretion of the city council. 
(b)  The historic preservation board shall have two (2) ex officio, non-voting members, each of whom shall be entitled to notice of all meetings of the board and to fully participate in the discussion and consideration of all business coming before the board. The ex officio members shall be as follows: 
(1)  The chief building official or designee; and 
(2)  The Main Street director or designee. 
(Ord. No. 4937, § 5, 3-19-18) 
Sec. 2-117. - Meetings. 
    The historic preservation board shall meet at least one (1) time per month if business is at hand. Special meetings may be called at any time as requested by the historic preservation officer. All meetings shall be held in accordance with the Texas Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 4937, § 5, 3-19-18) 
Sec. 2-118. - Terms. 
    Members of the historic preservation board shall serve for staggered terms of two (2) years in accordance with section 2-48. No person shall be appointed to nor eligible to serve for more than three (3) consecutive two (2) year terms of office. 
(Ord. No. 4937, § 5, 3-19-18) 
Sec. 2-119. - Officers. 
    The chairman and vice-chairman of the historic preservation board shall be elected by and from the members of the board and shall serve for a term of one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 4937, § 5, 3-19-18) 
Sec. 2-120. - Quorum. 
    Three (3) members of the historic preservation board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. However, not less than a majority of the full, authorized membership of the board may grant or deny a certificate of appropriateness. 
(Ord. No. 4937, § 5, 3-19-18) 
Sec. 2-121. - Powers. 
    The HPB shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt rules and procedures as necessary to provide for the orderly conduct of HPB meetings. 
(2)  Recommend criteria for the identification of historic, architectural and cultural landmarks. 
(3)  Conduct surveys and maintain an inventory of significant historic, architectural and cultural landmarks and historic districts within the city. 
(4)  Recommend the designation of resources as landmarks and/or historic districts. 
(5)  Maintain written minutes that record all actions taken by the HPB and the reasons for taking such actions. 
(6)  Recommend conferral of recognition upon the owners of landmarks or within districts by means of certificates, plaques or markers. 
(7)  Increase public awareness of the value of historic, cultural and architectural preservation by encouraging and participating in public education programs developed by the historic preservation officer. 
(8)  Make recommendations to the city concerning the utilization of state, federal or private funds to promote the preservation of landmarks and historic districts within the city. 
(9)  Approve or disapprove applications for certificates of appropriateness pursuant to this chapter. 
(10)  Recommend the acquisition of landmark structures by the city where their preservation is essential to the purpose of this chapter and where private preservation is not feasible. 
(11)  Recommend specific design guidelines for the review of landmarks and districts to ensure compatibility within the district. 
(Ord. No. 4937, § 5, 3-19-18) 
Sec. 2-122. - Records and reports. 
    The historic preservation board shall maintain a record of its meetings and shall report to the city council at least once each year concerning its activities for the past year and its intended activity for the ensuing year. 
(Ord. No. 4937, § 5, 3-19-18) 
DIVISION 6. - CONVENTION AND VISITORS BUREAU ADVISORY BOARD[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4967, § 2(2.02), adopted Oct. 1, 2018, enacted provisions designated as div. 5, §§ 2-115-2-117. Inasmuch as division and sections so numbered already exist, said provisions have been redesignated as div. 6, §§ 2-123-2-125, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-123. - Created; membership. 
(a)  There is created the "Convention and Visitors Bureau Advisory Board" of the City of Denison (the "board"). 
    The board shall consist of seven (7) members. Members shall be appointed in accordance with the city Charter and shall serve for no more than two (2) consecutive three (3) year staggered terms. 
    Members of the board shall be appointed from the following groups, organizations or interests as voting members of the board: 
(1)  Owner/general manager/senior management of a food/beverage establishment in the city; 
(2)  Downtown Denison, Inc. representative; 
(3)  Owner/general manager/senior manager of a hotel/motel in the city; 
(4)  Denison Chamber of Commerce Board of Directors Representative; 
(5)  Denison History Representative; 
(6)  Lake Texoma/Tourism Representative; and 
(7)  Sports tourism/outdoor recreation representative. 
    At-large member(s) residing within the corporate city limits or the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city may be appointed to the board if an insufficient number of applications are received from individuals representing these organizations or groups. 
(b)  Notwithstanding section 2-46, individuals who do not reside in the corporate city limits may be appointed and serve on the board if they are an owner, general manager, or senior manager of a business within the city. 
(Ord. No. 4967, § 2(2.02), 10-1-18) 
Sec. 2-124. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purposes of the board are to encourage tourism in the Denison community, to raise the public visibility of local activity which may attract visitors to the city, and to promote and enhance tourism in the convention and hotel industry as authorized by V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 351. 
(b)  The board is directed to: 
(1)  Develop and regularly update a strategic plan to include specific goals and objectives for promoting tourism and the preservation and appreciation of historic and cultural attributes of our community; 
(2)  Develop guidelines and evaluate proposals for the awarding of funds to promote tourism, in compliance with local and state law; 
(3)  Recommend an annual convention and visitors bureau budget for adoption by the city council; and 
(4)  Provide a report to the city council on its programs on a timely basis. 
(Ord. No. 4967, § 2(2.02), 10-1-18) 
Sec. 2-125. - Definitions. 
    To encourage tourism in the Denison community includes but is not limited to: 
(1)  Developing programs to increase community awareness of the value of tourism; 
(2)  Promoting local convention activity; 
(3)  Promoting guided-tour groups and day-visit opportunities for individuals; 
(4)  Promoting existing and developing additional community events, historical attractions, cultural events and athletic activities and facilities designed to bring visitors to Denison; 
(5)  Developing and maintaining signage to inform the public of significant local programs, historical sites, parks and related information; and 
(6)  Any other activity allowed for hotel occupancy taxes by state law. 
(Ord. No. 4967, § 2(2.02), 10-1-18) 
ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENTS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Administrative organization, § 5.01 et seq. 
Cross reference- Fire marshal, § 7-41 et seq.; bureau of fire prevention, § 7-66 et seq.; personnel, Ch. 16. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-126. - Code enforcement authority-Granted. 
    Employees of the city regardless of the department of the city in which employee costs are budgeted, whose function, in whole or in part, includes the inspection of work performed under the authority of the hereinafter itemized chapters of this Code are specifically hereby authorized to enforce the provisions of chapters 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 19, 20, 21, 22, 26 and 28, including but not limited to, the power to cite to appear in answer to complaint as provided in section 2-127. Such employees shall carry on their persons identification issued by the city manager that the employee is duly employed by the city and that the employee is a code enforcement officer of the city. Such employee shall produce such identification on demand while performing duties within the course and scope of the employee's duties. 
(Code 1965, § 5-9) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; flood prevention and protection, Ch. 8; food and food establishments, Ch. 9; housing, Ch. 10; HUD-code manufactured homes and recreational vehicles, Ch. 12; nuisances, Ch. 13; signs, Ch. 19; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21; subdivisions, Ch. 22; utilities, Ch. 26; zoning, Ch. 28. 
Sec. 2-127. - Same-Authority to cite alleged violators. 
    Any employee authorized under section 2-126 as a code enforcement officer of the city is hereby authorized to issue citations citing the allegation of a code violation under the itemized chapters and appendices of section 2-126. In so citing, the code enforcement officer is authorized to request and to receive the alleged violator's promise to appear in answer to the allegation, and to swear and certify as to taking of such promise for the purpose of enforcing the promise to appear by separate complaint. A code enforcement officer is also authorized to take any and all legal steps necessary in the prosecution of the alleged violation in the municipal court of the city; provided, however, nothing herein shall be construed so as to authorize or empower a code enforcement officer to exercise arrest powers conferred and reserved unto law enforcement officers as that term is applied by and through the statutes of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 5-10) 
Secs. 2-128-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Miscellaneous offenses, Ch. 11; personnel, Ch. 16; civil service for firefighters and police officers, § 16-26 et seq. 

Sec. 2-141. - Microfilming of official records. 
    The following procedures are hereby adopted and established, and shall be followed at all times, in carrying out the program of microfilming official records of the police department. 
(1)  The type of records which shall be microfilmed are criminal history record information maintained on all individuals in the custody of the police department, except for criminal history record information pertaining to juveniles. The criminal record history information consists of but is not limited to arrest sheets, officer's arrest report, and investigative records. 
(2)  Indices to all microfilm records maintained in accordance with this section shall be accurately and currently kept. 
(3)  All microfilm used in carrying out the provisions of this section in microfilming official records shall meet the requirements of the United States of America Standards Institute for archival quality, density, resolution and definition. 
(4)  The police chief or his authorized representative shall check, verify and certify that each microfilm record as produced from official records of the police department is a true and correct duplication of the original public record. 
(5)  Public free access to information contained in the microfilm records of the city is hereby guaranteed to the extent to which members of the public are entitled to same under law. 
(Code 1965, § 20-5) 
State Law reference- Microfilming, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 181.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-142. - Racial profiling policy of the city 
(I)  Policy and purpose. This racial profiling policy is adopted in compliance with the requirements of articles 2.131 through 2.136, Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, which prohibits Texas peace officers from engaging in racial profiling. 
(II)  Definitions. 
(a)  Racial profiling means a law enforcement-initiated action based on an individual's race, ethnicity, or national origin rather than on the individual's behavior or on information identifying the individual as having engaged in criminal activity. Racial profiling pertains to persons who are viewed as suspects or potential suspects of criminal behavior. The term is not relevant as it pertains to witnesses, complainants, persons needing assistance, or other citizen contacts. 
(b)  Race or ethnicity means a particular descent, including but not limited to Caucasian, African, Hispanic, Asian, or Native American descent. 
(c)  Acts constituting racial profiling is an act initiating law enforcement action, such as a traffic stop, a detention, a search, an issuance of a citation, or an arrest based solely upon an individual's race, ethnicity, or national origin or on the basis of racial or ethnic stereotypes, rather than upon the individual's behavior, information identifying the individual as having possibly engaged in criminal activity, or other lawful reasons for the law enforcement action. 
(d)  Pedestrian stop means an interaction between a peace officer and an individual who is being detained for the purposes of a criminal investigation in which the individual is not under arrest. 
(e)  Traffic stop means the stopping of a motor vehicle by a peace officer for an alleged violation of law or ordinance regulating traffic. 
(III)  Prohibition. Peace officers of the City of Denison are strictly prohibited from engaging in racial profiling. The prohibition against racial profiling does not preclude the use of race, ethnicity, or national origin as factors in a detention decision by a peace officer. Race, ethnicity, or national origin may be legitimate factors in such a decision when used as part of a description of a suspect or witness for whom a peace officer is searching. 
(IV)  Complaint process and public education. Any person who believes that a peace officer employed by the city has engaged in racial profiling with respect to that person may file a complaint with the city, and no person shall be discouraged, intimidated, or coerced from filing such a complaint, or be discriminated against because they have filed such a complaint. 
    The city shall accept and investigate citizen complaints alleging racial profiling by its peace officers. Such complaints shall be in writing, or the city employee, officer, or official receiving the complaint should reduce the same to writing, and should include the time, place, and details of the incident of alleged racial profiling, the identity or description of the peace officer or officers involved, and the identity and manner of contacting the complainant. 
    Any peace officer, city employee, or city official who receives a citizen complaint alleging racial profiling shall forward the complaint to the chief of police within twelve (12) hours of receipt of the complaint. Receipt of each complaint shall be acknowledged to the complainant in writing, all such complaints shall be reviewed and investigated by the by the chief of police or his designee within a reasonable period of time, and the results of the review and investigation shall be filed with the city manager and with the complainant. 
    In investigating a complaint alleging racial profiling, the investigator shall seek to determine if the officer who is subject of the complaint has engaged in a pattern of racial profiling that includes multiple acts constituting racial profiling for which there is no reasonable, credible explanation based on established police and law enforcement procedures. A single act constituting racial profiling may not be considered a pattern of racial profiling, and shall not be grounds for corrective action. 
    In the event that a complaint of racial profiling filed by an individual involves an occurrence that was recorded on audio or video, the investigator shall, upon commencement of the investigation of the complaint and upon written request of the officer, promptly provide a copy of the recording to the peace officer that is a subject of the complaint 
    The police department of the city shall provide education to the public concerning the racial profiling complaint process. A summary of the public education efforts made during the preceding year shall be included with the annual report filed with the governing body of the City of Denison under subsection VI below. 
(V)  Corrective action. Any peace officer who is found, after investigation, to have engaged in racial profiling in violation of this policy shall be subject to corrective action, which may include oral or written reprimand; diversity, sensitivity or other appropriate training or counseling; paid or unpaid suspension; termination of employment, or other appropriate action as determined by the chief of police in a manner consistent with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143. 
(VI)  Collection of information and annual report when citation issued or arrest made. For each traffic stop in which a citation is issued and for each arrest resulting from such traffic stops, a peace officer involved in the stop shall collect information identifying the race or ethnicity of the person detained, stating whether a search was conducted, and if a search was conducted, whether the person detained consented to the search. 
    The information collected shall be compiled in an annual report covering the period January 1 through December 31 of each year, and shall be submitted to the governing body of the City of Denison no later than March 1 of the following year. The annual report shall not include identifying information about any individual stopped or arrested, and shall not include identifying information about any peace officer involved in a stop or arrest. 
(VII)  Audio and video equipment. 
(a)  The chief of police of the city shall, immediately upon enactment of this policy, commence examination of the feasibility of installing video camera equipment and transmitter-activated equipment in each city motor vehicle regularly used to make traffic stops, and transmitter-activated equipment in each city motorcycle regularly used to make traffic stops, and shall report to the governing body of the city on the findings of such examination no later than six (6) months following enactment of this policy. The report shall include funding options available to the city, including any funding available through the department of public safety. 
(b)  In the event that the findings of such examination support the installation of such equipment, the governing body shall consider and take action on installing the equipment, applying for funding to secure and install such equipment, or such other action as the governing body considers appropriate. In the event the examination does not support installing such equipment, the chief of police of the city shall periodically update the governing body on such feasibility. 
(c)  In the event that the governing body determines that funds are needed in order to install the equipment, it shall pass a resolution certifying that fact to the department of public safety. On receipt of either sufficient funds or video and audio equipment, the governing body shall install video and transmitter-activated equipment in each motor vehicle regularly used to make traffic stops, and shall install transmitter-activated equipment on each motorcycle regularly used to make traffic stops, and the governing body shall pass a resolution certifying to the department of public safety that such equipment has been installed and is being used to record each traffic and pedestrian stop made by a peace officer employed by the city that is capable of being recorded by video and audio or audio equipment, as appropriate. 
(VIII)  Review of video and audio-documentation standards. In the event that audio and video equipment is installed, each audio and video recording shall be retained for a minimum period of ninety (90) days unless a complaint is filed alleging that a peace officer of the city has engaged in racial profiling with respect to a traffic or pedestrian stop, in which case the recording shall be retained until final disposition of the complaint. In conjunction with preparation of the annual report required under subsection VI above, the chief of police shall periodically conduct reviews of a randomly-selected sampling of video and audio recordings made recently by peace officers employed by the city in order to determine if patterns of racial profiling exist. 
    In reviewing audio and video recordings, the investigator shall seek to determine if the officer who is involved therein has engaged in a pattern of racial profiling that includes multiple acts constituting racial profiling for which there is no reasonable, credible explanation based on established police and law enforcement procedures. A single act constituting racial profiling may not be considered a pattern of racial profiling, and shall not be grounds for corrective action. 
(IX)  Collection, compilation, analysis, and reporting requirements in absence of either audio and video equipment or nonfunding certification by the governing body. 
(a)  In addition to the annual report required when citations are issued and arrests made, and so long as the city has not equipped all motor vehicles and motorcycles regularly used to make traffic and pedestrian stops with audio and video equipment, as applicable, and so long as the city has not or is not able to certify to the department of public safety that it needs funds for such audio and video equipment but has not received such funds, then each peace officer of the city shall make the following report for each traffic and pedestrian stop: 
(1)  A physical description of each person detained as a result of the stop, including: 
a.  The person's gender; and 
b.  The person's race or ethnicity, as stated by the person, or if the person does not state the person's race or ethnicity, as determined by the officer to the best of his or her ability; 
(2)  The traffic law or ordinances alleged to have been violated or the suspected offense; 
(3)  Whether the officer conducted a search as a result of the stop, and, if so, whether the person detained consented to the search; 
(4)  Whether any contraband was discovered in the course of the search and the type of contraband discovered; 
(5)  Whether probable cause to search existed and the facts supporting the existence of that probable cause; 
(6)  Whether the officer made an arrest as a result of the stop or the search, including a statement of the offense charged; 
(7)  The street address or approximate location of the stop; and 
(8)  Whether the officer issued a warning or a citation as a result of the stop, including a description of the warning or a statement of the violation charged. 
(b)  The information in each report shall be analyzed and compiled in a report that covers the period January 1 through December 31 of each year, and shall be submitted to the governing body of the city no later than March 1 of the following year. Each such report shall include: 
(1)  A comparative analysis of the information compiled by each officer under subsection IX(a)(1)-(8) to: 
a.  Determine the prevalence of racial profiling by peace officers employed by the city; and 
b.  Examine the disposition of traffic and pedestrian stops made by officers employed by the city, including searches resulting from such stops; and 
(2)  Information relating to each complaint filed with the city alleging that a peace officer employed by the city had engaged in racial profiling. 
(c)  The report required by this subsection IX may not include identifying information about a peace officer who makes a traffic or pedestrian stop or about an individual who is stopped or arrested by an officer. 
(d)  The compilation of information, analysis, and report required by this subsection IX shall not be required for any calendar year during which (1) the city has equipped all motor vehicles and motorcycles regularly used to make traffic and pedestrian stops with audio and video equipment, and each traffic and pedestrian stop made by a peace officer employed by the city that is capable of being recorded by video and audio or audio equipment, as appropriate, has been so recorded; or (2) the city has certified to the department of public safety that it needs funds for such audio and video equipment, as described in subsection VII(c) above, but has not received such funds. 
(X)  Peace officer and police chief training. 
(a)  Each peace officer employed by the city shall complete the comprehensive education and training program on racial profiling established by the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement Officer Standards and Education (TCLEOSE) not later than the second anniversary of the date the officer was licensed, the date the officer applies for an intermediate proficiency certificate, whichever date is earlier. A person who on September 1, 2001, held a TCLEOSE intermediate proficiency certificate, or who had held a peace officer license issued by TCLEOSE for at least two (2) years, shall complete a TCLEOSE training and education program on racial profiling not later than September 1, 2003. 
    The chief of police shall, in completing the training required by V.T.C.A., Education Code § 96.641, complete the program on racial profiling established by the Bill Blackwood Law Enforcement Management Institute of Texas. 
(XI)  The chief of police is hereby instructed to incorporate the foregoing policy on racial profiling into the department's policy manual immediately and to take each and every step necessary to implement the policy in a manner consistent with this section. 
(Ord. No. 4080, §§ 1, 2, 12-17-01) 
Secs. 2-142-2-160. - Reserved.

DIVISION 5. - CITY MARSHAL 

Sec. 2-176. - Office of city marshal created. 
    Pursuant to the authority of section 5.03, Denison City Charter, there is hereby created the office of city marshal that shall consist of a city marshal and such deputies as may be authorized from time to time through the funding of such positions in the city's annual budget. The city marshal shall be appointed by the city manager without competitive examination, shall report to the city manager (or his designee), [and] shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. The city marshal shall not be a member of the police department, but shall be independent. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 1, 9-15-03) 
Sec. 2-177. - Powers and duties. 
    The city marshal shall be empowered to promptly and faithfully execute writs and process issued by the municipal court judge and clerk; issue citations upon information from the code enforcement and building inspections departments of the city; be available to the municipal court when it is in session; take suitable and sufficient bail for appearance before the municipal court of a person charged with a violation of a class C misdemeanor or of an ordinance of the municipality; possess the same power and jurisdiction as a peace officer under the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure to execute warrants, writs, capiases and other process, both criminal and civil, issued by the municipal court, and shall perform such other duties as assigned. 
(Ord. No. 4187, § 2, 9-15-03) 
ARTICLE IV. - MUNICIPAL OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES INDEMNITY[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Tort claims, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code § 102.001 et seq. 

Sec. 2-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Employees and officials shall mean all persons who were, now are, or shall be paid employees of the city or elected or appointed officials of the city, including, but not limited to, the city council, city manager, city staff, members of boards and commissions established by charter or ordinance of the city and under the jurisdiction and direction of the city council. 
    Losses shall mean amounts such as court costs, reasonable attorneys' fees and judgments, or settlements actually incurred. Losses shall not be construed to include fines or penalties imposed in a criminal matter or punitive damages imposed in a civil suit. 
    Wrongful act shall mean any actual or alleged error, act, statement or omission or neglect or breach of duty by a city employee or official. Provided, however, such wrongful act must be within the course and scope of the employee's or official's authority and/or employment with the city and must not be one of the types of actions excluded in section 2-183. 
(Code 1965, § 2-72) 
Sec. 2-182. - Purpose. 
(a)  This article is enacted for the purpose of providing indemnity to all city employees and elected and appointed officials in order to protect them from the expense of defending any civil lawsuit filed against them in their individual capacity as a result of actions taken while acting within the course and scope of their employment or official duty for the city. 
(b)  It is in the best interest of the city and all of its residents to attract and keep qualified personnel as employees and officials of the city. As an aid in attracting and keeping such qualified personnel, the city should provide either insurance coverage or indemnification for such employees and officials in order to minimize the financial risk of being a city employee or official. 
(c)  The city may also be a defendant or entity against which a claim is made; and where any claim is made simultaneously against the city, and no conflict of interest results, the city, through its own insurance coverage or through its own attorneys or funds authorized for such purposes, will provide a simultaneous defense. In such cases the city will pay any losses and the indemnity fund hereinafter provided and established will not be utilized. 
(Code 1965, § 2-70) 
Sec. 2-183. - Exclusions. 
    Any losses arising in connection with any of the following acts or alleged acts shall not be covered by the indemnity reserve fund: 
(1)  Any criminal act, whether felony or misdemeanor. 
(2)  Acts through which the employee or official gained personal remunerative profit to which he was not entitled. 
(3)  Any act of fraud or dishonesty. 
(4)  Any intentional tort such as assault or battery. 
(5)  Any act which is alleged to create a personal contractual debt on behalf of the city employee or official. 
(6)  Any act which the fund administrator finds to be outside the course and scope of the employee's or official's authority and is inconsistent with, contrary to, or in conflict with the interest of the city. 
(7)  Any act for which a local government is prohibited from paying damages pursuant to V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code § 102.002(c). 
(Code 1965, § 2-73) 
Sec. 2-184. - Indemnity reserve fund-Created. 
    There is hereby created an indemnity reserve fund for the payment of losses as provided in section 2-181. Appropriations to said fund may be made by the city council from time to time as it, in its discretion, may find to be in the best interest of the city; provided however, the indemnity reserve fund balance shall not exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) at any given time, and in that event no appropriation may be made to or from such fund, except as provided herein for the payment of losses incurred. No funds of the city, other than those of the indemnity reserve fund, shall be expended for the losses herein defined for which coverage is extended. Nothing herein shall impose a mandatory obligation upon the city to appropriate the maximum amounts as herein established into the indemnity reserve fund. 
(Code 1965, § 2-74) 
Sec. 2-185. - Same-Administration of fund. 
    The indemnity reserve fund shall be administered by the city manager with the advice and counsel of the city attorney; provided, however, when coverage is sought for an act of the city manager or city attorney, the city council shall administer the fund. 
(Code 1965, § 2-75) 
Sec. 2-186. - Coverage. 
    The city shall pay, up to the maximum amount of the indemnity reserve fund, any and all losses incurred by an employee or official of the city which said employee or official shall become obligated to pay as a result of any claim or claims made against them arising out of any alleged wrongful act while such employee or official is acting within the course and scope of his authority and/or employment, but the city shall have the right to defend any suits filed and investigate any claims made with its own attorney or attorneys chosen by it and may settle claims it deems advisable. 
(Code 1965, § 2-71) 
Secs. 2-187-2-205. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCES 

Sec. 2-206. - Signing checks. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized to use automated check signing equipment to affix signatures of the city manager, director of finance and any other person designated by the city manager in writing and placed on file with the city secretary. It shall be the duty of the city manager to put into place such policies and procedures as may be reasonably necessary to safeguard the equipment and accounts of the city so as to prevent the misuse of such equipment and the financial accounts of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 1(d), 6-17-13)
