ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 5(a) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former art. I, §§ 7-1-7-3, and enacted a new art. I as set out herein. Former art. I pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 10-3-10-5. 

Sec. 7-1. - Arson reward. 
(a)  The city will pay a reward of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to any person giving evidence or information which leads to the arrest and conviction for the crime of arson committed within the corporate limits of the city, as such crime is described and defined in the state penal code. 
(b)  The offer of reward provided for herein shall not apply to regular members of the police and fire departments of the city, nor to the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(a), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 7-2. - Unlawful taking or use of fire department equipment. 
    No person shall, under any pretext whatsoever, take or use any of the implements, tools, or apparatus belonging to the fire department, without first obtaining permission and consent of the chief of such department. It shall be the duty of every fireman knowing of a violation of this section to report the same to the fire chief, and the chief shall make complaint to the chief of police, who shall take action in the matter. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(a), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 7-3. - Fees for fire service. 
    Fees for fire service may be set from time to time for fair, usual and customary fees set by the City Council of Denison. Fee schedule will be provided upon request. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(a), 6-17-13) 
Secs. 7-4-7-42. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - FIRE MARSHAL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-126 et seq.; personnel, Ch. 16. 

Sec. 7-41. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4235, § 1, adopted Sept. 7, 2004, repealed § 7-41, which pertained to office created; independent of other departments and derived from Code 1965, § 10-16. 
Sec. 7-42. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4235, § 1, adopted Sept. 7, 2004, repealed § 7-42, which pertained to appointment, qualifications and removal and derived from Code 1965, § 10-17. 
Sec. 7-43. - Duty to investigate fires. 
    The fire marshal or his or her designee shall have the authority to investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of any fire, explosion or other hazardous condition. Information that could be related to trade secrets or processes shall not be made part of the public record, except as directed by a court of law. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(b), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(b) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-43, and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-43 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-18. 
Sec. 7-44. - Taking of testimony generally. 
    The fire marshal, when in his opinion further investigation is necessary, shall take or cause to be taken the testimony, on oath, of all persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge in relation to the matter under investigation, and shall cause the same to be reduced to writing. 
(Code 1965, § 10-19) 
Sec. 7-45. - Authority to summon witnesses, require production of evidence and administer oaths. 
    The fire marshal shall have the power to summon witnesses before him to testify in relation to any matter which is, by the provisions of this division, a subject of inquiry and investigation, and may require the production of any book, paper or document deemed pertinent thereto. The fire marshal is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and affirmations to any persons appearing as witnesses before him. 
(Code 1965, § 10-20) 
Sec. 7-46. - Investigations may be private; separation of witnesses. 
    All investigations held by or under the direction of the fire marshal may, in his discretion, be private, and persons other than those required to be present may be excluded from the place where such investigation is held and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each other and not allowed to communicate with each other until they have been examined. 
(Code 1965, § 10-21) 
Sec. 7-47. - Duty when evidence indicates crime in connection with fire. 
    If the fire marshal shall be of the opinion that there is evidence sufficient to charge any person with the crime of arson or with the attempt to commit the crime of arson, or of conspiracy to defraud, or criminal conduct in connection with any fire, he shall cause such person to be lawfully arrested and charged with such offense, or either of them, and shall furnish the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence, together with names of witnesses and all of the information obtained by him, including a copy of all pertinent and material testimony taken in the case. 
(Code 1965, § 10-22) 
Sec. 7-48. - Misconduct of witnesses summoned by fire marshal. 
    Any witness who refuses to be sworn, or who refuses to appear and testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the fire marshal, or who fails or refuses to produce any book, paper or document touching any matter under examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the proceedings of the fire marshal in the matter of such investigation or inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter under investigation as aforesaid, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. It shall be the duty of the fire marshal to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted. 
(Code 1965, § 10-23) 
Sec. 7-49. - Inspection of premises; ordering removal or repair of dangerous conditions. 
(a)  The fire marshal, upon complaint of any person having an interest in any building or property adjacent, or without complaint, shall have the right, at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of examination, to enter into and upon all buildings and premises within the city. It shall be his duty as often as necessary to enter upon and make or cause to be entered upon and made, a thorough examination of all mercantile, manufacturing and public buildings, together with the premises belonging thereto. 
(b)  Whenever the fire marshal shall find any building or other structure which, for want of repair, or by reason of age or dilapidated condition, or for any cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger other buildings or property, or so occupied that fire would endanger persons or property therein, and whenever he shall find an improper or dangerous arrangement of stoves, ranges, furnaces or other heating appliances of any kind whatsoever, including chimneys, flues and pipes with which the same may be connected, or a dangerous arrangement of lighting device or system, or a dangerous or unlawful storage of explosives, compounds, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, dangerous chemicals, vegetable products, ashes, combustible, inflammable and refuse materials, or other conditions which may be dangerous in character or liable to cause or promote fire or create conditions dangerous to firefighters, public or occupants, he shall order the same to be removed or remedied, and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant of the building or premises. 
(c)  If the owner or occupant deems himself aggrieved by such order, he may, within five (5) days, appeal to the appeals board as prescribed in the code, which shall hear the cause of the complaint and, unless by its authority that order is revoked, such order shall remain in force and be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant. 
(d)  Any owner or occupant who fails to comply with such order shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(c), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(c) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-49, and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-49 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-24; and Ord. No. 4474, §§ 1, 2, adopted Aug. 4, 2008. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to provide for condemnation and removal of structures constituting fire hazards, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, § 342.012.

(Code 1965, § 10-25) 
Sec. 7-51. - Record of fires to be kept. 
    The fire marshal shall keep in his office a record of all fires investigated, together with all facts statistics and circumstances, including the origin of the fires and the amount of the loss, which may be determined by the investigation required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(d), 6-17-13)

(10)  Section 503.3 of the 2012 International Fire Code is hereby amended as follows: 
503.3 Marking. Striping, signs, or other markings when approved by the fire code official, shall be provided for the fire apparatus access roads to identify such roads or prohibit the obstruction thereof. Striping, signs, and other markings shall be maintained in a clean and legible condition at all times and be replaced or repaired when necessary to provide adequate visibility. 
1.  Striping - Fire apparatus access roads shall be continuously marked by painted lines of red traffic paint six inches (6") in width to show the boundaries of the lane. The words "NO PARKING FIRE LANE or FIRE LANE NO PARKING" shall appear in four inch (4") white letters at 25 feet intervals on the red border markings along both sides of the fire lanes. Where a curb is available, the striping shall be on the vertical face of the curb. 
2.  Signs - Signs shall read "NO PARKING FIRE LANE" or "FIRE LANE NO PARKING" and shall be 12" wide and 18" high. Signs shall be painted on a white background with letters and borders in red, using not less than 2" lettering. Signs shall be permanently affixed to a stationary post and the bottom of the sign shall be six feet, six inches (6'6") above the finished grade. Signs shall be spaced not more than fifty feet (50') apart along both sides of the fire lane. Signs may be installed on permanent buildings or walls or as approved by the Fire Chief.

ARTICLE IV. - FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Flammable liquids, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 9201. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-116. - Containers for quantities of five gallons or less. 
(a)  Construction of section and definitions. This section shall be construed so as to effectuate its general purpose to prohibit and prevent the sale of gasoline or other flammable liquids in quantities of five (5) gallons or less, except in an approved container meeting the standards set forth in this section, and to prohibit the keeping of flammable liquids in or upon any premises in quantities of five (5) gallons or less unless it is kept in an approved container meeting the standards as herein described, thereby protecting the public safety and welfare. As used in this section, the words approved container mean either a metal automatic self-closing type container so sealed by means of a lid or other device that neither liquid or vapor will escape from it at ordinary temperatures, or a metal container properly equipped and fitted with a metal lid or the equivalent thereof in such a manner and to the extent that the contents thereof will not spill if dropped or turned over, and the contents will not ignite when exposed to open flame or ignition and the liquid and vapor will escape from it at ordinary temperatures and so designed for safety purposes against the danger of fire. 
(b)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, dispense or cause to be sold or dispensed any quantity of gasoline or other flammable liquid in quantities of five (5) gallons or less, except in an approved container meeting the standards set forth in subsection (a). It shall likewise be unlawful for any property owner or occupant or tenant of property to purchase or keep any flammable liquid in or upon the premises in quantities of five (5) gallons or less, unless such flammable liquid is kept in an approved container meeting the standards described in subsection (a). 
(c)  Violations. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, on conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined as prescribed in section 1-12 of this Code. Any violation of this section by an agent, servant, employee or representative of the owner or person selling or dispensing gasoline or other flammable liquid shall be deemed a violation by such owner or person. 
(Code 1965, § 10-2) 
Secs. 7-117-7-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Liquefied petroleum gas, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 113.001 et seq. 

Sec. 7-131. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them: 
    Building official shall mean and include the chief building official or his or her authorized representative. 
    Distribution shall mean to deliver, apportion or dispense liquefied petroleum gas from a tank (whether stationary or mobile) larger than eight thousand (8,000) gallons by volume. 
    Fire marshal shall mean and include the city fire marshal and any authorized deputy or assistant of the fire marshal of the city. 
    Liquefied petroleum gas shall mean and include any material which is composed predominantly of any of the following hydrocarbons or mixtures thereof: propane, propylene, butanes (normal butane or iso-butane) and butylenes. 
    Premises shall mean and refer to the grounds, as well as all buildings and appurtenances pertaining thereto, and any adjacent premises, if directly or indirectly under the control of the same person. 
    Railroad commission shall mean the state railroad commission or any regularly authorized deputy or agent thereof. 
    Vehicle shall mean any automobile, truck or trailer and all appurtenances pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(i), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(i) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-131, and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-131 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-58. 
Sec. 7-132. - Compliance with article and commission regulations. 
    No person shall keep, store, retain, handle, haul, transport, dispense, distribute, use or consume, within the corporate limits of the city, any liquefied petroleum gas except upon full compliance with the requirements of this article, the adopted fire code and with the requirements and regulations of the interstate commerce commission and of the railroad commission. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(i), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(i) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-132, and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-132 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-59. 
Sec. 7-133. - Distribution from vehicles filled outside the city. 
    The distribution of liquefied petroleum gas may be allowed from trucks or vehicles filled outside of the corporate limits of the city to any user whose use thereof is permitted within the city by the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(i), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(i) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-133, entitled "Sale or distribution installations prohibited," and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-133 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-60. 
Sec. 7-134. - Permit for installation or repair of facilities. 
    No person shall install or repair any tank, container or equipment for the storage and/or consumption of liquefied petroleum gas, or install any piping for the distribution or use of liquefied petroleum gas on any premises within the city, until he secures a permit from the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(i), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(i) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-134, entitled "Distribution from vehicles filled outside city," and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-134 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-61. 
Sec. 7-135. - Approval of plans and specifications for equipment for industrial and similar uses. 
    Piping, pipe fittings, appliances and other equipment designed or intended for the distribution and utilization of liquefied petroleum gas for industrial and similar uses, other than for domestic and small commercial uses, shall not be installed, repaired, extended or altered until a detailed set of plans and specifications for such use and equipment has been filed in the office of the building official and approved by him. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(i), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(i) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-135, entitled "Permit for installation or repair of facilities," and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-135 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-63. 
Sec. 7-136. - Requirements for equipment for domestic and small commercial uses. 
    Piping, pipe fittings, appliances, and other equipment designed and intended for the distribution and utilization of liquefied petroleum gas for domestic and small commercial uses shall not be installed, repaired, extended or altered, unless it is made to comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All piping, appliances, and equipments shall be installed in full compliance with the ordinances of the city regulating installations for natural gas, except where otherwise specifically required by this division and by the regulations of the railroad commission. 
(2)  Liquefied petroleum gas at pressure in excess of one (1) pound per square inch shall not be permitted inside buildings without specific approval of the building official and fire marshal. 
(3)  All piping shall comply with the cities adopted fuel gas code and/or the Texas Railroad Commission. If piping is to be placed underground, it shall be buried not less than eighteen (18) inches underground in a trench used for no other purposes. 
(4)  When an existing natural gas piping system is to be used for liquefied petroleum gas, all piping of the existing system is to be used for liquefied petroleum gas, all piping of the existing system shall be removed and installed in the manner prescribed for new liquefied petroleum gas installations. 
(5)  All appliances used with liquefied petroleum gas shall be designed and adapted for use with the particular mixture of liquefied petroleum gas normally supplied to the piping system. Automatic appliances having a pilot light shall have an approved automatic safety cutoff. 
(6)  Floor furnaces shall not be permitted on liquefied petroleum gas systems. 
(7)  Liquefied petroleum gas piping, appliances and equipment shall not be permitted in basements or pits or any other low places where such gas can collect to form a dangerous inflammable mixture. 
(8)  Houses having continuous foundations shall have suitable vents from under such houses if liquefied petroleum gas piping is installed under such houses. 
(9)  Rubber or leather, including rubber hose, shall not be used where in any manner exposed to the solvent action of liquefied petroleum gas. 
(10)  Liquefied petroleum gas piping shall not be installed underneath a concrete foundation or slab. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(i), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(i) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-136, entitled "Approval of plans and specifications for equipment for industrial and similar uses," and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-136 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-64. 
Sec. 7-137. - Inspection and approval of piping, appliances and other equipment. 
    Piping, pipe fittings, appliances and other equipment for the distribution and utilization of liquefied petroleum gas shall not be placed in service or used until after the same has been tested, inspected and approved by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(i), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(i) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-137, entitled "Requirements for equipment for domestic and small commercial uses," and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-137 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-65. 
Sec. 7-138. - Inspection and approval of consumer tanks and containers. 
    Liquefied petroleum gas tanks and containers shall not be placed in service or filled upon the premises of the ultimate user, or, when placed underground, tanks shall not be covered over, until the work of installation has been inspected and approved by the building official and/or fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(i), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 5(i) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-138, entitled "Inspection and approval of piping, appliances and other equipment," and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former § 7-138 derived from the 1965 Code, § 10-66. 
Sec. 7-139. - Inspection and approval of consumer tanks and containers. 
    Liquefied petroleum gas tanks and containers shall not be placed in service or filled upon the premises of the ultimate user, or, when placed underground, tanks shall not be covered over, until the work of installation has been inspected and approved by the plumbing inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 10-67) 
Sec. 7-140. - Odorization required. 
    In order that the danger of escaping combustible gas may be minimized and to facilitate the quick detection of gas leaks, all liquefied petroleum gas shall be effectively odorized so as to indicate positively, by a distinctive odor, the presence of gas down to concentration in air of as much as one-half of one (1) percent by volume. 
(Code 1965, § 10-68) 
Sec. 7-141. - Adjustments or changes in accessories, regulators, etc. 
    Adjustments, changes or alterations in the accessories, devices, regulators and safety devices of liquefied petroleum gas containers shall not be made except by persons licensed by the state railroad commission to do such work. 
(Code 1965, § 10-69) 
Sec. 7-142. - Storage inside buildings. 
    No liquefied petroleum gas shall be stored or retained inside of any structure within the city, except in interstate commerce commission containers in sizes of sixteen (16) pounds of gas or less, which containers may be used inside of buildings by obtaining written permission from the fire marshal. 
(Code 1965, § 10-70) 
Sec. 7-143. - Remedying defective equipment. 
    Whenever within the city, or outside the city for a distance of five thousand (5,000) feet from the city limits, liquefied petroleum gas equipment is found to be defective or improperly installed, or is being handled or operated in such a manner as to become a menace to public safety or welfare, the same may be deemed a nuisance by the building official or fire marshal by serving of a written notice upon the owner thereof, or upon the person having control thereof on the premises, whereupon the matter covered in such notice shall be immediately remedied or abated. 
(Code 1965, § 10-71) 
Sec. 7-144. - Construction of article. 
    This article is hereby declared to be remedial and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public health, safety and welfare through provisions for safety to life and property from fire and other hazards incident to the handling, retaining and use of liquefied petroleum gas within or on buildings and premises within the corporate limits of the city. This article shall be construed to be supplemental to the laws of the state and of the regulations of the railroad commission applying to liquefied petroleum gas as now or hereafter existent or promulgated in conformity with the laws of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 10-72) 
Sec. 7-145. - Containers to conform to state law and regulations of railroad commission. 
    All containers used for hauling or transporting liquefied petroleum gas upon or over any premises or upon any street, alley or public thoroughfare within the city shall be designed, constructed and operated in a manner as required by the laws of the state and all special regulations of the railroad commission, as now or hereafter promulgated in conformity with the laws of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 10-78) 
Sec. 7-146. - Inspection and approval of carriers, containers, etc. 
    The city shall have the right, at any reasonable time, to have a competent inspector examine all carriers, containers and other property and equipment used in the transportation of liquefied petroleum gas and in the filling of containers, and if any of such property, upon inspection, is found defective or does not comply with all safety standards, such property shall immediately be taken out of service, and shall remain out of service until repaired and approved by the fire marshal. All new carriers and containers to be used in the future shall, before being placed in service, be examined and approved by the fire marshal as to its safe condition. 
(Code 1965, § 10-79) 
Sec. 7-147. - Vehicle design, construction and operation standards. 
    All vehicles used for the transportation or removal of liquefied petroleum gas over the streets, alleys or public thoroughfares of the city shall be designed, constructed and operated in accordance with the published regulations for the design, construction and operation of automobile tank trucks and tank trailers for the transportation of liquefied petroleum gas, adopted by the National Board of Fire Underwriters and the National Fire Protection Association, which regulations shall be kept on file in the office of the building official and may be examined and inspected by the public at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1965, § 10-80) 
Sec. 7-148. - Maintenance of vehicles, tanks and containers. 
    All vehicles, tanks or containers used for transporting liquefied petroleum gas shall be kept in good condition at all times, and if found in use when in a hazardous condition or in need of repair, such use and condition shall constitute prima facie evidence of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 10-81) 
Sec. 7-149. - Unloading of railroad cars, trucks and trailers. 
    Railroad cars and trucks and trailers transporting liquefied petroleum gas shall not be loaded or unloaded within the corporate limits of the city, except as otherwise specifically provided in this division. 
(Code 1965, § 10-82) 
Sec. 7-150. - Routes to be used. 
    Vehicles hauling or transporting liquefied petroleum gas shall not be driven in the city except on designated highways or truck routes and routes designated by the fire marshal. In the event of any breakdown or other mechanical difficulty where such vehicle is unable to proceed, the driver thereof shall immediately notify the fire department. 
(Code 1965, § 10-83) 
Sec. 7-151. - Parking of vehicles. 
    No vehicle containing liquefied petroleum gas shall be parked or stored on streets, alleys, public thoroughfares, or at any other point in the city, except as follows: 
(1)  Such vehicle may be parked at the point where the commodity is to be delivered and such delivery shall be made without undue delay. 
(2)  Such vehicle may be parked for a period not exceeding ten (10) minutes at gasoline filling stations for the purpose of taking on fuel, water, oil, and other emergency servicing. 
(Code 1965, § 10-84) 
Sec. 7-152. - Repair of vehicles. 
    No vehicle used for hauling or transporting liquefied petroleum gas or vehicle using the same for fuel shall be repaired or placed in any garage for repair until the truck tank or fuel tank is empty of gas, including the pump and hose, and all master valves have been closed. The owner of such garage or repair place shall check these facts before making any repairs thereto. In instances where emergency repairs are necessary, the fire marshal shall be notified immediately and the repairs made under his supervision. 
(Code 1965, § 10-85) 
Sec. 7-153. - Transfer of load from one vehicle to another. 
    No liquefied petroleum gas shall be transferred from one (1) vehicle to another on any street, alley, public thoroughfare or any point except that, in case of emergency, such transfer may be made under the supervision of the fire marshal. 
(Code 1965, § 10-86) 
Secs. 7-154-7-170. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - DENISON EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- See the editor's note to Article V hereof. 

Sec. 7-181 - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Emergency medical services or emergency services shall mean services used to respond to an individual's perceived need for immediate medical care and to prevent death or aggravation of physiological or psychological illness or injury. 
    Non-emergency medical services shall mean any circumstance in which a patient is transported by a licensed emergency medical services provider using an emergency medical services vehicle under circumstances which are or have been represented to be of a non-emergency nature. 
    Non-emergency medical services provider or provider shall mean a person, corporation, or other entity performing non-emergency medical services or emergency medical services within the City of Denison, other than the Denison Fire Rescue or Denison Fire Department. 
(Ord. No. 4861, § 2(2.01), 4-3-17) 
Sec. 7-181.1. - Service created, name; to be operated within and as part of the fire department; emergency medical calls exclusive. 
    There is hereby created a service to the people of Denison to be called the Denison Emergency Medical Service ("Denison EMS"), which service shall be operated within and as a part of Denison Fire Rescue, except as expressly authorized by this article. The primary purpose of such service shall be to provide emergency medical service and transportation of injured or ill persons and persons suffering life threatening conditions to an appropriate certified emergency medical facility. 
    All calls for emergency medical services ("EMS") that originate within the city limits of the City of Denison, or in the primary response area of the City of Denison, shall be directed to Denison Fire Rescue via City of Denison Communications Center (9-1-1) and responded to solely by the Denison EMS. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, registered provider under this article, provider that is not registered under this article, or any company, service or corporation, affiliated or in partnership with the foregoing to knowingly, intentionally, or recklessly furnish, operate, advertise or otherwise engage, or profess to be engaged in the service or operation of emergency medical services from a point originating within the corporate limits of the City of Denison or in the primary response areas of the Denison EMS unless provided by: 
(a)  Denison EMS through the City of Denison Fire Department; 
(b)  A person or entity providing service to an address located outside of the city limits or primary response area of the Denison EMS and going to a hospital located inside of the city limits; or 
(c)  A person or entity meeting requirements of the State of Texas Department of State Health Services for emergency medical services personnel, vehicles and equipment, and where required meeting the department of state health services regulations for mobile intensive care unit level, who responds to a request of the City of Denison Communications Center (9-1-1), Denison Fire Rescue, Denison EMS or City of Denison's Director of Emergency Management to lend assistance when a major disaster or other occurrence results in emergency calls exceeding the capacity of Denison EMS. 
(Ord. No. 4861, § 2(2.01), 4-3-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4861, § 2(2.01), adopted April 3, 2017, repealed former § 7-181, and enacted new provisions designated as §§ 7-181 and 7-181.1 to read as herein set out. The service may also be available to persons in other portions of Grayson County under contracts for said services in existence or as may be entered into between the City of Denison and other affected governing bodies. 
(Ord. No. 3520, § 2(31/2-3), 3-6-95)

Fee schedule will be provided upon request. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 5(l), 6-17-13)

Editor's note- Section 5(l) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed former § 7-185, which pertained to when service fees due and payable, collection, billing of charges, delinquent accounts, and derived from Ord. No. 3520, § 2(31/2-5), adopted March 6, 1995. 
Sec. 7-186. - Registration required for business providing emergency medical services and non-emergency medical services; prohibited acts. 
(a)  Registration required. The business of providing medical transportation service, both emergency medical services and non-emergency medical services, is a business affected with the public interest, health, safety and welfare, and no person shall operate such business within the city limits of the City of Denison or the primary response areas of the City of Denison (except on a mission with a patient through the area, or from a pick up point outside the primary response area of the City of Denison to a destination with the City of Denison) without first obtaining the registration granted by the City of Denison under the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Misrepresentation prohibited; notification of 9-1-1. It shall be unlawful for a person, a registered provider under this article, a provider that is not registered under this article, or any company, service or corporation, affiliated or in partnership with the foregoing, to provide, offer to provide, or represent itself as the Denison EMS or an employee, affiliate, agent, or representative of Denison EMS. Furthermore, if a private or public non-emergency medical services provider receives an emergency call from any source to respond in the city limits of the City of Denison, or the primary response area of the Denison EMS, such provider shall immediately notify the City of Denison EMS Communications Center (9-1-1) by utilizing the City of Denison Fire Department's primary dispatch channel and shall not respond to such call unless requested to do so by the City of Denison EMS dispatcher. 
(c)  Duplication of emergency medical services prohibited. Duplication of emergency medical services shall be unlawful. Duplication of emergency medical services occurs when a provider intentionally or knowingly responds to a call for emergency medical services within the corporate limits of the City of Denison or within the primary response areas of the Denison EMS and such response is without the request or express authorization of the City of Denison EMS dispatcher or other authorization under section 7-181 of this article. 
(d)  Registration requirements-Applicant. Any person or entity seeking to provide non-emergency medical services within the corporate limits or the City of Denison or the primary response area of the Denison EMS shall first register and obtain a certificate of inspection from the City of Denison. An application for registration shall be obtained from, and filed with the City of Denison's Office of the City Manager. In order to be registered within the city, a non-emergency medical services provider shall meet the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Vehicles. Each vehicle owned, leased or used by the applicant must be authorized by the Texas Department of State Health Services, or its successor, as a basic life support vehicle or higher, and may be operated only when such vehicle meets all conditions required by Chapter 773 of the Texas Health and Safety Code, as amended. 
(2)  Equipment. Each vehicle owned, leased or used by the applicant shall be furnished with all of the equipment (and qualified personnel) required by the Texas Department of State Health Services, or its successor, for an advanced life support vehicle and shall be properly permitted by appropriate licensing agencies to operate as such. All equipment must be clean, in working order and available in sufficient quantity to provide safe transport and care of sick and injured persons, and no vehicle may be operated as an advanced life support vehicle or higher unless it meets the foregoing requirements. 
(3)  Insurance. Each vehicle owned, leased or used by the applicant shall be covered by a public liability insurance policy on that ambulance vehicle, such insurance policy to be issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Texas. At minimum, such insurance policy: 
a.  Shall provide automobile liability coverage for claims for damages resulting from an automobile accident resulting in damage and/or personal injury or death in an amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence; professional liability coverage for damages resulting from professional malpractice in an amount of not less than three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) per occurrence; general liability umbrella coverage in an amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00); and workers' compensation coverage at the state minimum based upon payroll; and 
b.  Shall not contain a passenger liability exclusion. 
(e)  Requirements for a registered non-emergency services provider. Registered non-emergency services providers shall comply with each of the following requirements: 
(1)  Inspection sticker. Each vehicle owned, controlled or used by a registered non-emergency medical service provider within the City of Denison or primary response area of Denison EMS shall display a current and valid City of Denison registration sticker in a place on the vehicle that is clearly visible from the outside of the vehicle. The City of Denison Fire Chief, or his designee, or the Denison Police Department shall have the right to inspect the provider's vehicles, equipment and personnel, at any time without prior notice, to ensure compliance with local, state and federal regulations and to ensure compatibility with City of Denison radio systems. 
(2)  Records. A registered non-emergency services provider shall maintain an accurate record of all calls answered and patients transported, including all pertinent facts regarding the services rendered and shall make such records available at any reasonable time for inspection by the City of Denison. The provider shall notify the City of Denison in writing of all complaints received by and any corrective or disciplinary actions taken by the Texas Department of State Health services concerning the provider. 
(3)  Licensed physician. The provider shall retain the services of a State of Texas licensed physician to function as its medical control physician to supervise the quality of service delivered by the provider as required by state law and regulation. 
(f)  Registration period. The registration provided under this article shall be valid for one (1) year from the date of issuance by city and shall remain in effect for such one-year period, unless revoked as provided herein. The registration granted by city under this article shall not be assigned, sublet or otherwise transferred by the provider. 
(g)  Revocation. The City of Denison reserves the right to immediately revoke the registration of any service provider who violates this article or any other local, state or national laws, and the city shall send written notice of such revocation to the person designated for notice on the provider's application for registration. Any provider whose registration is revoked may appeal that determination by filing a written appeal to the city manager within ten (10) days of the date of city's written notice of revocation. Such appeal shall set forth the basis for the appeal in detail and request for re-instatement or renewal of registration. The decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(h)  Registration fee. To compensate the City of Denison for administrative costs of registration and compliance with the requirements of this article, a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be submitted with each application for registration under this article. An application for which required payment has not been submitted shall be considered incomplete and will not be processed until the appropriate fee is paid by the applicant.

(Ord. No. 4861, § 2(2.02), 4-3-17)
