(3)  Setback: Twenty (20) feet from any public right-of-way or property line. 
(4)  Maximum height dimension of display: Fourteen (14) feet. 
(5)  Display area ratio: The width to height ration must not be less than two to one (2:1) nor more than four to one (4:1). 
(6)  V-type signs: The angle between the display area of V-type signs shall not be greater than forty-five (45) degrees measured back to back, and, if the size of each area is three hundred (300) square feet or less, the maximum distance at the nearest point between the two (2) backs, as measured at the apex, shall not exceed one and one-half (11/2) feet. If the size of either area exceeds three hundred (300) square feet, then the maximum distance between the two (2) backs, as measured at the apex, shall not exceed three and one-half (31/2) feet. Back-to-back signs must be on common supports, and the nearest point between the two (2) backs shall not exceed five (5) feet plus the diameter of the intervening upright or support. 
(7)  The display area shall not have any extensions beyond the basic dimensions of the display area, any inserted, flashing, or neon lighting, three-dimensional features, or moving components. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-141. - Annual operating fee. 
    Each permittee shall pay an annual operating fee per display area per off-premise sign. The amount of the fee shall be established by the city's comprehensive fee schedule. The annual operating period shall run from January 1 through December 31of each year. The amount of the fee shall not be pro-rated unless specifically allowed in the city's comprehensive fee schedule. The first annual operating fee shall be due on January 1 immediately following the date of the permit. Failure to pay the annual operating fee shall be cause for the chief building official to order the sign to be removed or to remove the sign and charge the cost of removal to the sign owner. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Secs. 19-142-19-144. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - HISTORIC OVERLAY AREA 
    No signs, other than those listed below, shall be installed or erected in the Historic Overlay Area indicated by the City of Denson Zoning Map. No permit shall be issued and no sign erected unless the sign is approved by the Historic Preservation Board of the City of Denison. Any variance to the terms of this article shall be determined by the historic preservation board and not the building appeals board. 
    Note: Colors utilized in signage must comply with the historic color palette adopted by the historic preservation board. 

Sec. 19-145. - Projecting signs. 
    Projecting signs shall only be allowed within the Historic Overlay Area and must meet the following regulations: 
(1)  Signs shall be constructed of noncombustible material. 
(2)  Signs shall not project more than four (4) feet, measured from the building face, and shall not be closer than eight (8) feet from the back of the curb line. 
(3)  Signs shall be at least eight (8) feet above the sidewalk. 
(4)  Signs may be externally illuminated. Internal illumination shall not be permitted. 
(5)  Signs shall not exceed twenty (20) square feet per sign face. 
(6)  For any projecting sign that extends over or into a right-of-way, prior to the issuance of a sign permit, the proprietor shall file with the city clerk a certificate of insurance for general liability in the minimum coverage amount of $500,000.00/$1,000,000.00, combined single limit, evidencing the City of Denison as an additional insured. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-146. - Awning signs. 
    Awning signs must meet the following regulations: 
(1)  An awning may extend the full length of the wall of the building to which it is attached and shall be no more than six (6) feet in height and shall provide a clearance of at least eight (8) feet above the sidewalk. 
(2)  Artwork or copy on awning signs shall be limited to a business name, business logo and/or property address. 
(3)  The artwork or copy for an awning sign shall not exceed twenty (20) percent of the area of the awning and shall extend for no more than sixty (60) percent of the length of the awning. 
(4)  Awnings shall not be illuminated. 
(5)  Awnings shall be composed of canvas or other fabric material approved by the historic preservation commission. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-147. - Canopy sign. 
    Canopy signs must meet the following regulations: 
(1)  A canopy sign may be attached to, or be an integral part of the face of a canopy. 
(2)  Artwork or copy on canopy signs shall be limited to a business name, business logo and/or property address. 
(3)  The artwork or copy on a canopy sign shall not exceed ten (10) percent of the face of the canopy, or a maximum of twenty-five (25) square feet, whichever is greater. 
(4)  An illuminated stripe may be incorporated into a canopy. The stripe may extend along the entire length of the face of the canopy. The width or thickness of the stripe shall be limited to one-third ( 1/3 ) of the vertical dimension of the face of the canopy. The internal illumination of a canopy is limited to the portions of the canopy face on which a sign or stripe is permitted. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-148. - Wall signs. 
(a)  Where allowed. Wall signs shall be limited to buildings located in a non-residential zoning district or to churches, apartments, schools and other non-residential uses, with the exception of model homes, located within a residentially zoned district. 
(b)  Installation requirements. All signs and their words shall be mounted parallel to the building surface to which they are attached, and shall project no more than twelve (12) inches from that surface, except for projecting signs as allowed in article XIV. Wall signs shall not extend above the wall or building surface to which the sign is attached. Banner signs shall not be utilized as permanent wall signs, but only as promotional signs as allowed in section 19-117. 
(c)  Maximum sign area. Wall signs shall not exceed the following area schedules: 
(1)  Attached signs located at a height of thirty-six (36) feet or less shall be limited to two (2) square feet of sign area for each lineal foot of building frontage for a single tenant building, or lease space frontage in a multiple tenant building, not to exceed four hundred fifty (450) square feet. 
(2)  Attached signs located above a height of thirty-six (36) feet shall be permitted an increase in maximum effective area. Such increases shall not exceed five (5) additional square feet in effective area, as restricted in paragraph (1) above, for each additional one (1) foot of height above thirty-six (36) feet measured from the base of the sign. Signs may be increased hereunder to a maximum size of six hundred (600) square feet. 
(3)  Attached signs may be located on any facade except for signs located on the side or rear wall of a building where the sign would face an adjacent residential zoning district. The sum of the effective area of all attached signs shall not exceed the allowable effective area specified in paragraphs (1) or (2) above, whichever paragraph is applicable. Signs on a single façade shall not exceed the sign area allowed in paragraph (1) above. 
(d)  Wall signs in the Historic Overlay Area must be externally illuminated. Internal illumination shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-149. - Roof signs. 
    One roof sign shall be allowed for each building. The size of the roof sign shall be limited by the maximum size allowed in paragraph 19-148(c)(1) above. The size of all wall signs shall be added to the size of the roof sign to determine the total amount of sign area and shall not exceed the requirements of subsection 19-148(c)(3) above. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-150. - Illumination of attached signs. 
    Attached signs may only be illuminated utilizing external lighting. Exterior letters with exposed neon lighting are not allowed. All sign lighting must be specifically approved by the historic preservation board. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-151. - Window signs. 
    Window signs do not require a permit or a permit fee. Window signs must meet the following regulations: 
(1)  Window signs must not obscure more than twenty-five (25) percent of the window area per facade. 
(2)  The sign area shall be measured by drawing a rectangular or square box around the sign elements, then multiplying the height by the width. For signs whose shape is irregular, the box must enclose all elements of the sign. 
(3)  No illuminated window signs shall be allowed within two (2) feet of the window surface, except for open/closed signs. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-152. - Sandwich board signs. 
    Businesses may display sandwich board signs that comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  Signs may only be placed on the sidewalk during the hours that the business is open to the public. 
(2)  Signs must be placed within three (3) feet of the front wall of the business and must allow for a minimum open space of four (4) feet between the sign and the edge of the sidewalk adjacent to the street to allow for unobstructed pedestrian passage along the sidewalk. 
(3)  Prior to initiating the use of the adjacent sidewalk, the proprietor shall file with the city clerk a certificate of insurance for general liability in the minimum coverage amount of $500,000.00/$1,000,000.00, combined single limit, evidencing the City of Denison as an additional insured. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-153. - Digital (electronic) signs. 
    Digital or electronic signs are specifically prohibited within the Historic Overlay Area. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-154. - Real estate signs. 
    Real estate signs may be erected that comply with section 19-116 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-155. - Kiosk signs. 
    Kiosk signs may be erected as long as the provisions of article XII of this Code are met and the signs are approved by the historic preservation board. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-156. - Exempt signs. 
    Signs exempted by article V of this Code are also specifically allowed in the Historic Overlay Area. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-157. - Promotional signage. 
    Promotional signage complying with section 19-117 of this Code are specifically allowed in the Historic Overlay Area. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-158. - Searchlights. 
    Searchlights complying with section 19-118 of this Code are specifically allowed in the Historic Overlay Area. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Sec. 19-159. - Menu board signs. 
    Two (2) menu board signs may be attached to any surface on the building as long as they do not conflict with any other right-of-way regulations required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4678, § 1, 2-18-13) 
Chapter 20 - SOLID WASTE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Public works department, § 2-161 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7; food and food establishments, Ch. 9; housing, Ch. 10; posting advertising matter on property without consent of owner prohibited, § 11-1; nuisances, Ch. 13; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21; utilities, Ch. 26; zoning, Ch. 28. 
State Law reference- Solid waste management, resource recovery and conservation act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4477-7c. 

Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Brush means the cuttings or trimmings from trees, shrubs or lawns and similar material. 
    Garbage means municipal solid waste consisting of putrescible animal and vegetable waste materials resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, and consumption of food, including waste materials from markets, storage facilities, handling and sale of produce and other food products; and nonputrescible household solid waste consisting of combustible waste including paper, rags, cartons, and similar materials and noncombustible waste including glass, crockery, tin and aluminum cans. 
    Hazardous waste means any commercial or residential garbage, trash, rubbish or other solid waste identified or listed as a hazardous waste by the administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency pursuant to the federal Solid Waste Disposal Act, as amended by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. 6901 et seq., as amended. 
    Industrial solid waste means solid waste resulting from or incidental to any process of industry or manufacturing, or mining or agricultural operations. 
    Infectious waste means commercial or residential garbage, trash, rubbish or other waste containing pathogens or biologically active materials, which because of its type, concentration and quantity is capable of transmitting disease to persons exposed to the waste, including human and animal tissue, bandages, syringes and other materials used in health care which become contaminated by pathogenic materials. 
    Municipal solid waste means solid waste resulting from or incidental to municipal, community, commercial, institutional and recreational activities, and includes garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, and other solid waste other than industrial waste and special waste. 
    Recyclable waste means any commercial or residential garbage, trash, rubbish or other solid waste which is not special waste that has been collected or sorted for legitimate reuse or reclamation. 
    Special waste means any commercial or residential garbage, trash, rubbish, hazardous waste, infectious waste, or other solid waste that because of its quantity, concentration, physical or chemical characteristics or biological properties is not collectable by the city's sanitation department. 
(Code 1965, § 12-2; Ord. No. 3339, § 2, 7-6-92; Ord. No. 3495, § 1, 11-7-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-2. - Scope and effect of chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all territory within the corporate limits of the city. It is the intent of the city council through this chapter to fully regulate the collection of municipal solid waste within the city. Ownership of municipal solid waste set out for collection shall be vested in the City of Denison. 
(Code 1965, § 12-1; Ord. No. 3339, § 3, 7-6-92) 
Sec. 20-3. - Residential garbage containers. 
(a)  Residential customers of the city shall be required to dispose of all garbage in plastic garbage bags. Bags used for these purposes are to meet minimum standards as may be established by the city. In no instance shall the bags be packed so as to contain more than fifty (50) pounds of garbage. 
(b)  Garbage bags shall be fastened at all times so that flies or other insects shall not have access to the contents thereof. Garbage bags which are not properly fastened or which are torn shall not be removed by employees, agents or permittees of the city for purposes of disposal. 
(c)  No garbage shall be picked up by the city in any type of container other than a plastic garbage bag. 
(d)  Rolls of garbage bags shall be sold by the city at such locations as may be established by the city manager, shall be sold at an amount at least equal to one hundred seventy-five (175) percent of the price per roll paid by the city to its wholesale supplier. Nothing herein shall be construed to be made applicable to any number of rolls of garbage bags which may be included in the basic residential garbage collection charge. 
(Code 1965, § 12-3; Ord. No. 3134, § 5, 3-20-89; Ord. No. 3495, § 2, 11-7-94) 
Sec. 20-4. - Collection of garbage, brush, trash from dwelling places. 
(a)  Residential garbage bags shall be picked up at the curb or near the street right-of-way adjacent to the front lot line or from such other location as may be designated in writing by the director of public works. Garbage bags shall not be left at the curb except on the days for regularly scheduled garbage pickup service. It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant or lessee placing bags for collection to keep the area around same maintained free and clear of loose trash, garbage, paper or waste materials. A maximum of twenty (20) bags per week per residence will be picked up by the city. All garbage from private residences placed in plastic bags shall be removed from the premises by the city or its permittees once weekly. 
(b)  All brush and appliances to be collected shall be stacked or placed at the edge of paved and improved alleyways, where they exist, or at the curb of the street adjacent to the property or at such other locations as may be approved for sanitation service by the city manager or his or her designee. In no instance shall tree limbs or trees exceeding the length of twelve (12) feet or exceeding a weight of fifty (50) pounds be collected as part of the city's brush collection service. 
(c)  Garbage or recycling bins shall not be left at the curb except on the days for regularly scheduled pick-up garbage and/or recycling service as the schedule may dictate. Bins of all kind and nature left on the curb for more than twenty-four hours shall be a violation of this section. 
(d)  Cardboard boxes which are broken down shall be picked up by the city as part of its regular garbage collection service. 
(e)  Rock, scrap building materials or waste resulting from construction, remodeling or general cleanup of vacant or improved property; sizeable amounts of trees, brush and debris resulting from property being cleared in preparation for construction, will not be removed by the city as part of its regular service. Property owners shall be responsible for having such debris removed at their expense. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person who is not a residential refuse customer of the city to dispose of any garbage, brush, refuse or solid waste of any nature within the city by any means. It shall be unlawful for any person who is a residential refuse customer of the city to allow, suffer or permit any person to place any garbage, brush, refuse or solid waste for collection at the customer's collection point when the person making the disposition is not a member of the household or when the garbage, brush, refuse or solid waste was not generated at or by the customer's residence. 
(Code 1965, §§ 12-4, 12-5(a); Ord. No. 3134, §§ 2, 3, 3-20-89; Ord. No. 3139, §§ 2, 3, 5, 4-3-89; Ord. No. 3329, §§ 1, 2, 3-16-92; Ord. No. 3495, §§ 3, 4, 11-7-94; Ord. No. 4701, § 14(a), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 20-5. - Service and charges for collection. 
(a)  The charges fixed under the terms of this section, or any charge under a contract that may be entered into by the city for the removal and disposal of garbage, shall be a charge against the owner, occupant or lessee of the premises, and the amount so fixed shall be collected monthly through the city water department as water charges are collected. Water services shall be discontinued for failure to pay the charges herein established in the same manner as it is discontinued for failure to pay water or sewer charges. The failure to pay the charges herein established shall subject the customer to the same penalty as prescribed for failure to pay water or sewer charges. 
(b)  Any person making application for water service shall be deemed to have applied for garbage service and shall be considered a customer of the city until such time as water service to such person has been discontinued. Garbage service shall be provided to the location of the active water account only. 
(c)  The city may not be required to provide garbage collection or disposal service to any area not within the corporate limits of the city. In the event garbage collection and disposal service is provided to areas or locations outside the city limits, the user charge or fee levied shall be no less than two (2) times that which would be charged to a similar class or type of customer situated within the city limits. 
(d)  The schedule of rates and charges is on file in the public works office. 
(Code 1965, § 12-5) 
Sec. 20-6. - Containers furnished by city for commercial and industrial concerns. 
(a)  The director of public works shall locate and place garbage and refuse containers for use by commercial and industrial concerns in accordance with the needs of the concern. All concerns for which containers are provided by the city shall place their garbage and dry refuse in such containers. It shall be unlawful for any person using such containers to leave the lid open after placing refuse materials therein. 
(b)  No person shall place or permit to be placed any manure, offal, night soil, ashes, dead animals, including fish entrails and heads thereof, rocks or construction waste materials, including lumber or any large pieces of metal, in containers provided by the city under this section. The city shall not empty any containers holding items prohibited by this section. 
(c)  All cardboard boxes and cartons must be broken down and bundled before being placed in any container furnished by the city, and no such bundle should exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight. 
(d)  No person, other than the party paying the charges for such service, shall place any garbage, brush or dry refuse in any container provided by the city under this section. 
(Code 1965, § 12-6) 
Sec. 20-7. - Collection by city from commercial and industrial concerns. 
(a)  All commercial and industrial concerns afforded garbage and refuse service by the container system provided for in this chapter shall pay a charge approved and adopted by the city council and kept on file in the office of the city manager or his or her designee. 
(b)  Commercial and industrial concerns provided pickup service and not provided with containers furnished by the city under this chapter shall be charged on the basis of an amount per month per cubic yard of refuse picked up each week. Any commercial or industrial concern, upon approval of the city manager or his or her designee, may have additional collections in any single week provided by the city for containerized service and shall be charged, on the appropriate monthly bill, at the rate approved and adopted by the city council and kept on file in the office of the city manager or his or her designee. 
(c)  All commercial and industrial concerns not located within the central business district not provided with containers furnished by the city in the chapter and whose daily refuse collection requirements are less than twenty (20) bags per week, shall pay a charge per month which is approved and adopted by the city council and kept on file in the office of the city manager or his or her designee. 
(d)  A fee and late penalties shall be established for customers desiring roll-on/roll-off container service. The fee and late penalties schedule established for customers desiring roll-on/roll-off service shall be as approved and adopted by the city council and kept on file in the office of the city manager or his or her designee. 
(e)  Any commercial or industrial customer whose garbage and refuse collection needs exceed the normal container service provided by the city, pursuant to this chapter, may request special collection services. The city manager or his or her designee is authorized to negotiate contracts for the meeting of such special refuse collection needs, subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(f)  The city may not be required to provide garbage and refuse service to any area not within the city. In the event garbage and refuse collection is provided to areas or locations outside the city limits, the user charge or fee levied shall be no less than two (2) times that which would be charged to a similar class or type of customer situated within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 14(b), 6-17-13; Ord. No. 4974, § 3, 12-10-18) 
Editor's note- Section 14(b) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 20-7 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 20-7 derived from the 1965 Code, § 12-7; and Ord. No. 3139, § 4, adopted April 3, 1989. 
Sec. 20-8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 14(b) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 20-8, which pertained to waste material as fill, and derived from the 1965 Code, § 12-10. 
Sec. 20-9. - City to provide solid waste services. 
    The city's sanitation department shall be the exclusive provider of residential and commercial garbage, rubbish and refuse collection and disposal services for all premises within the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to provide residential or commercial garbage, rubbish or refuse collection or disposal services to any person for compensation within the city, or to make use of the public streets for that purpose, except as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3339, § 5, 7-6-92) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3339, § 4, adopted July 6, 1992, repealed former § 20-9, relative to permits, and § 5 of said ordinance enacted new §§ 20-9-20-13 to read as herein set out. The provisions of former § 20-9 derived from Code 1965, § 12-11. 
Sec. 20-10. - Prohibited materials and regulations. 
(a)  The city shall keep a list of special waste that is not acceptable for collection and disposal by the sanitation department. The city manager or his or her designee may also make reasonable rules regarding the collection and disposal by the city's sanitation department of any garbage, rubbish, trash, or other solid waste that requires special preparation or handling to meet the requirements of any local, state or federal law or regulations. The list of special waste and the rules shall be written and kept on file by the city manager or his or her designee and be available for public inspection during regular business hours. 
(b)  No person shall deposit in any container serviced by the city any special waste. The city may refuse to collect, transport, or dispose of special waste or any other garbage, rubbish, trash, or other solid waste that does not comply with this chapter or the regulations made by the head of the sanitation department. 
(c)  Each property owner shall be responsible for arranging with an authorized private hauler for the collection, removal, and disposal of any special waste, or other solid waste which the city will not collect. 
(Ord. No. 3339, § 5, 7-6-92; Ord. No. 4701, § 14(c), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 20-11. - Owner to arrange for commercial collection. 
    Every owner, occupant, tenant or lessee of any business, commercial, or institutional property, or other property not entitled to receive residential garbage collection services shall arrange, by contract with the city, for commercial garbage collection and disposal services from the city, except as otherwise specified in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3339, § 5, 7-6-92) 
Sec. 20-12. - Annual permit required for special waste haulers. 
(a)  No person shall collect or remove for compensation from any property within the city any special waste without first obtaining a special waste hauler's permit from the sanitation department. 
(b)  The person applying for a special waste hauler's permit shall make application to the city's sanitation department on forms provided for that purpose, and pay the required fee. The application shall require the following information: 
(1)  The name and business address of the applicant. 
(2)  The name of the owner of the property and the address where the special waste will be collected. 
(3)  A description of the special waste to be collected. 
(4)  The location where the special waste will be disposed, including proof, when required by the head of the sanitation department, that the applicant is legally authorized to dump at the specified location. 
(5)  A description and the license number of the motor vehicles to be used in collecting and transporting the special waste within the city. 
(6)  Any other information which is reasonably necessary to administer this section. 
(c)  The city manager or his or her designee shall issue the special waste hauler's permit to the applicant if: 
(1)  Proper application has been made and the fee paid. 
(2)  The applicant will only be collecting special waste as defined in this chapter. 
(d)  The special waste hauler's permit shall be valid for one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(e)  The special waste hauler's permit fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 3339, § 5, 7-6-92; Ord. No. 4701, § 14(d), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 20-13. - Recyclable waste. 
(a)  Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit a person from collecting, gathering, or transporting recyclable refuse collected from property within the city. 
(b)  Any person who transports recyclable refuse collected by others outside the person's household from any property inside the city to a point outside the city more than three (3) times per year shall register with the city's sanitation department, on forms provided for that purpose. There shall be no fee for registration. 
(Ord. No. 3339, § 5, 7-6-92) 
Sec. 20-14. - Discontinuation of services for nonpayment. 
    The city may suspend solid waste services to any person who is delinquent in the payment of all solid waste disposal service fees until the delinquent claim, including late penalties, is fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 4974, § 4, 12-10-18) 
Chapter 21 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS, AND RIGHT-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 4775, adopted March 16, 2015, changed the title of ch. 21 from "Streets and Sidewalks" to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Specific code enforcement authority, § 2-126; public works department, § 2-161 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places prohibited, § 3-8; animals prohibited from running at large, § 4-9; building lines established on certain streets, § 5-2 et seq.; numbers for buildings, § 5-4; flood prevention and protection, Ch. 8; food and food establishments, Ch. 9; housing, Ch. 10; posting advertising matter on property without consent of owner prohibited, § 11-1; posting advertising matter on utility poles prohibited, § 11-2; sleeping on public property prohibited, § 11-9; sale of merchandise in residential districts restricted, § 11-10; nuisances, Ch. 13; location of oil and gas wells in or obstructing streets and alleys prohibited, § 14-2; depth of oil or gas and oil pipe line restricted, § 14-64; peddlers and solicitors and certain other sales, Ch. 15; planning, Ch. 17; public property, Ch. 18; signs, Ch. 19; solid waste, Ch. 20; subdivision regulations, Ch. 22; traffic, Ch. 25; stopping, standing and parking regulations on streets, § 25-131 et seq.; speed limits on specific streets, § 25-106 et seq.; utilities, Ch. 26; zoning, Ch. 28. 
State Law reference- General authority of city relative to street abandonment, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 253.001; building lines and condemnation of easements, etc., for streets, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 213.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Obstructions generally. 
(a)  Except as the city council may otherwise provide, it shall be unlawful for any person to place goods, wares, merchandise, fruits, vegetables, boxes, barrels, containers, dispensers, signs or any other obstruction of any kind in or upon any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk within the city. Likewise, except as the city council may otherwise provide, it shall be unlawful for any person in charge of or occupying any property to permit goods, wares, merchandise, boxes, barrels, containers, signs or other obstructions to remain on the street, alley, avenue or sidewalk adjoining the property or building in his charge or control, whether the same was placed thereon by such person or not. 
(b)  Within the Central Business District the city manager may grant permission to individual merchants or an association of merchants to display goods, wares and merchandise for sale along the publicly-owned sidewalks during such times and under such conditions as may be specified by the city manager in the granting of such permission. 
(Code 1965, § 23-1; Ord. 3443, §§ 1, 2, 2-7-94) 
Sec. 21-2. - Obstructions and planting in parkways-Generally; application for use permit. 
    No obstruction or planting of any kind shall be maintained, constructed, placed, planted or grown in the area of the public parkway lying between the curb or grade line of any public street and the abutting sidewalk or private property line other than grass, plants or shrubs; grass will be cut and maintained in an acceptable manner, plants or shrubs will be kept trimmed or pruned so as not to exceed eighteen (18) inches in height above the top of curb level and in such a manner as to keep such plants and shrubbery from encroaching over or obstructing the adjacent public sidewalk street area, traffic-control signs or devices. Provided, however, the owner of any abutting property may use the public parkway contrary to the above provision by application for a street parkway use permit executed by the building official who is hereby authorized to issue such a permit which shall provide that the permittee by acceptance of such permit agrees and obligates himself or assigns to maintain any tree, shrub or plant placed in such area in such manner as to keep same from becoming a motor vehicle or pedestrian traffic hazard and will not interfere with an unobstructed view of street signs, traffic-control signs or devices. If such parkway shall at any time be needed for any public purpose or for any utility line or poles, street signs, traffic signs and/or other devices placed in such area under lawful authority of the city council, the permittee shall whenever it shall be deemed necessary in the public interest, as may be determined by the city council, remove any tree, plant or shrub situated within such area at no expense to city. 
(Code 1965, § 23-2.1) 
Sec. 21-3. - Same-Notice to remove; failure to comply with notice. 
    Whenever the building inspector receives information and proof of the existence of any obstruction prohibited by the provisions of section 21-2 or whenever he has been directed by the city council to cause any obstruction to be removed from the public parkway area as described herein, he shall issue a written notice to any person responsible for the violation or obstruction ordering the abatement or removal of the same. He shall, at the same time, send a copy of the notice to the director of public works. Such notices shall specify the nature of the violation or obstruction and shall designate a reasonable time within which such abatement or removal shall be accomplished. In the event such notice is not complied with within the specified time, the director of public works who received the copy of the original notice shall be so advised by the building inspector, and he is hereby authorized to immediately institute proceedings for the abatement or removal thereof, as provided in section 13-29 through section 13-31. 
(Code 1965, § 23-2.2) 
Sec. 21-4. - Duty to keep sidewalk, parkway and alleyway clean. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner, tenant or lessee to keep the abutting or adjacent sidewalk, parkway, and alleyway clean and free of all weeds, trash, rubbish, filth, and debris which may incumber such sidewalk, parkway and alleyway and to place such material in trash receptacles as required by this Code and failure to comply with the requirement of this section shall be and is hereby declared to constitute a nuisance subject to abatement as provided for in section 13-29 through section 13-31. 
(Code 1965, § 23-2.3) 
Sec. 21-5. - Obstructing passage of water through or across street or sidewalk. 
    Any person who shall in any manner obstruct the free passage of water through or across any street, road, highway, sidewalk or alley in this city, so as to interfere with the free and easy passage of the same, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 23-4) 
Sec. 21-6. - Minimum height of stairways or fire escapes over street or alley. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, place or permit to remain on any building in his control or possession any stairway or fire escape over any paved street, avenue or alley at a lesser height than fifteen (15) feet from such paving. 
(Code 1965, § 23-5) 
Sec. 21-7. - Trees near streets, sidewalks or drives. 
    Trees shall not be placed nearer than three (3) feet nine (9) inches to sidewalks and curbs, unless an approved means to control root growth, such as special curbing, is provided, and shall be spaced sufficiently to prevent interference of adjacent trees when mature. Roots of any tree or other plant which tend to damage or interfere with sidewalks, curbs or drivers shall be corrected by the owner of the tree or plant and any sidewalk, curb or drive thus damaged shall be repaired by such owner in a manner approved by the city manager or his or her designee. Trees shall be maintained to give a vertical clearance of seven (7) feet over walks and thirteen (13) feet over streets. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 15(b), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 15(b) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 21-7 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 21-7 derived from the 1965 Code, § 23-6. 
Sec. 21-8. - Hedges, retaining walls, steps, fences, etc., near streets or alleys. 
    Hedges, retaining walls, steps, fences or other accessories for property abutting a street or alley shall be located on such property and no portion thereof shall lie in the street or alley, except footings to walls which may be placed under the surface in a manner approved by the director of public works. The design of retaining walls referred to herein shall be approved by the director of public works. 
(Code 1965, § 23-7) 
Sec. 21-9. - Painting, marking, etc., streets, sidewalks and curbs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to paint, stain or mark any sign, figure, character or letter upon any sidewalk, curb or paved street in the city, except that the numbers of a street address may be painted on the sidewalk or curb abutting a street in such manner as to aid in identifying and locating such real property. 
(b)  Persons who go from house to house for the purpose of painting such address numbers shall be required to obtain a license from the city as provided in section 15-26 et seq. 
(Code 1965, § 23-8) 
Sec. 21-10. - Maintenance of sidewalks, driveways, etc., by property owners or occupants. 
(a)  It shall be the duty and the obligation of all owners, occupants and users of real property within the corporate limits of the city, upon which property a sidewalk, driveway or other way is located and used by or which may be used by the public, to keep and maintain such sidewalk, driveway or way in a safe condition for use. Such sidewalks, driveways or ways shall be maintained so as to be free of depressions, excavations, inequalities, obstacles, obstructions or encroachments by the owner or occupant of such real property. 
(b)  The responsibility for and cost of the repair of curbing existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this subsection was derived shall be equally borne by the property owner adjacent to such curbing and the city. Such cost shall include material, labor and engineering, if any. 
(Code 1965, § 23-9; Ord. No. 3868, § 1, 4-5-99; Ord. No. 4701, § 15(c), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 21-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 15(d) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 21-11 which pertained to requirements by contractor installing service lines in city right-of-way, and derived from the 1965 Code, § 23-10. 
Secs. 21-12-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS, DRIVES, CURBS AND GUTTERS 

Sec. 21-26. - Control. 
    The construction of sidewalks, drives, curbs and gutters in the streets of the city shall be subject to control by the director of public works or other designated representative of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 23-20) 
Sec. 21-27. - Contractor's bond. 
    Every person engaging in the business of constructing sidewalks, drives, curbs and gutters in the streets of the city shall execute a surety bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), payable to the city and conditioned that such person will construct all sidewalks, drives, curbs and gutters in strict compliance with the specifications of this article and hereafter required by ordinance of the city, and to the satisfaction of the director of public works and that such person will well and truly indemnify and keep harmless and secure the city from the payment of any and all damages arising out of the laying of any sidewalk, drive, curb or gutter by such person. Such bond shall also be conditioned that all sidewalks, drives, curbs and gutters constructed by the maker of the bond shall remain in good condition for two (2) years after being constructed, and should any sidewalk, drive, curb or gutter constructed by the maker not remain in good condition for two (2) years, the maker will make all necessary repairs, keeping it in good condition for that period. 
(Code 1965, § 23-21) 
Sec. 21-28. - Work to be performed by authorized contractor. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or cause to be constructed any concrete sidewalk, drive, curb or gutter in the streets of the city, unless such work is performed by a contractor who has executed the bond required by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 23-22) 
Sec. 21-29. - Work permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lay, build or construct any sidewalk, drive, curb or gutter, whether consisting of brick, concrete or other materials, upon any of the streets or avenues within the city without first securing a permit so to do. Before any such permit shall be granted, it shall be the duty of the person contemplating such work to make application to the director of public works for such permit, giving the location of the property in front of which the work is to be done, and a description of the work and the material to be used. Such permit shall be issued upon payment of a fee in the amount of one dollar ($1.00), if the applicant has complied with all provisions of this article and if the proposed work will conform to this article. 
(Code 1965, § 23-23) 
Secs. 21-30-21-60. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 15(d) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed §§ 21-30-21-41, which pertained to grading, materials generally, concrete generally, forms; placement of concrete; preservation of grade and line stakes; etc., curing of concrete, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, drives, parkway grading, cleanup, replacement of defective work; deviation from article, street improvements under an assessment paving project, and derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 23-24-23-35.

ARTICLE IV. - STREET AND ALLEY ABANDONMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoning roadways, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 253.001. 

Sec. 21-81. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of interpreting this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section: 
    Alley means a secondary means of access which is platted, dedicated, or deeded in fee simple to the public and not merely existing by easement rights, whether open on the ground or not. 
    Easement means property reserved by plat, dedication, or instrument for public use and access where the abutting property owner or owners own the underlying fee simple title to the land. 
    Right-of-way generally means the entire platted, dedicated, or deeded public street or alley which exists between two (2) property lines, whether improved or not, but also may refer to any other public way or portion thereof. 
    Streets means thoroughfares, public drives, roads, or ways which are platted, dedicated, or deeded to public use, whether open on the ground or not. 
(Code 1965, § 23-51) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-82. - Administrative charges. 
    Upon filing of any request for abandonment of a street, alley, right-of-way, or easement, an administrative fee shall be paid to the planning department in the amount of one hundred eighty-five dollars ($185.00) to cover the expense of administering the procedure outlined in this article, the cost of mailing notices and release forms to all abutting property owners, and the cost of publishing the public notice. Such fee is nonrefundable, regardless of the ultimate action of the city, and shall be in addition to other charges hereinafter described. 
(Code 1965, § 23-52) 
Sec. 21-83. - Procedure, generally. 
    Any person desiring the city to abandon, close, and vacate any street, alley, right-of-way, or easement shall file a petition with the planning department, in writing, directed to the planning and zoning commission. Such petition shall contain a description of the street, alley, right-of-way, easement, or portion thereof, to be abandoned, closed, and vacated. Attached to such request shall be a list of all owners of property abutting such street, alley, right-of-way, or easement, together with the last known address of each such owner. In the event that the petition requests abandonment of a portion of a street, alley, right-of-way, or easement which, whether open on the ground or not, can be accessed by the public from either direction, it shall be necessary for the petition to provide the planning department with the names and last known addresses of all abutting property owners for both the portion to be abandoned and for that portion which is not to be abandoned. In all cases, applicant must provide sufficient information for the city to prepare an ordinance abandoning, closing, and vacating said property. In the event that all abutting property owners do not join in such petition, a statement shall be attached to said request showing the reason for non-participation of those who have not signed. Ownership information appearing on the last approved city tax roll shall be conclusive as to the names of the abutting property owners. Upon the filing of such request, the planning department shall mail notices of such request to all utility companies in the city. Such notice to utility companies must be given not less than ten (10) days before the date set for the planning and zoning commission's consideration of such request. 
(Code 1965, § 23-53) 
Sec. 21-84. - Hearings. 
(a)  Upon filing of the information set out in section 21-83 above, the planning and zoning commission shall review all information and make its recommendation to the city council. It shall be the burden of the applicant to support the petition by showing that the abandonment of such street, alley, right-of-way, or easement is in the public interest due to as many of the following prerequisites as may be established: 
(1)  That such street, alley, right-of-way, or easement has never been used by the public but has, in fact, been abandoned and vacated for any public use. 
(2)  That the street, alley, right-of-way, or easement, as it now exists, is not accessible to the general public. 
(3)  That, if there were any public need for the continuance of such street, alley, right-of-way, or easement in times past, such need no longer exists. 
(4)  That the street, alley, right-of-way, or easement has, in fact, never been used by the public and, in cases of streets and alleys, that they are not paved or graveled and, as a practical matter, are not accessible to the public and/or that the expense of opening or improving for use such street, alley, right-of-way, or easement would be prohibitive due to location or topography. 
(b)  Following consideration by the planning and zoning commission, said application shall be set for a public hearing before the city council. At least ten (10) days prior to the public hearing, the planning department shall notify, by mail, all abutting property owners or, in the partial closure of a street, alley, right-of-way, or easement, all affected property owners. Prior to the public hearing, the city shall obtain, at applicant's sole expense, an appraisal of the fair market value of said property, prepared by a city-approved real estate appraiser, in accordance with Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 5421c-12. Applicant must then pay to the city the appraised value of the property to be abandoned, and such payment shall be retained by the city in the case of city council approval or refunded to applicant in the case of city council denial. The city council shall then hold a public hearing for the purpose of either approving or denying such application. In the event of approval by the city council, the property shall be sold to the abutting property owners in proportion to their abutting ownership, such division to be made in an equitable manner. The applicant, at his or her expense, shall provide individual quitclaim deeds for each affected property owner, said deeds to be executed by the mayor of the city. The applicant shall then receive original executed quitclaim deed, certified copy of ordinance, and other such documents to be filed for record at applicant's expense. 
(Code 1965, § 23-54) 
Sec. 21-85. - City-initiated abandonment. 
    City-initiated abandonments shall not require the payment of application fee; however, appropriate hearings shall be required and notice provisions met as otherwise required. 
(Code 1965, § 23-54.1) 
Secs. 21-86-21-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STREET NAMES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Numbers for buildings, § 5-4. 

Sec. 21-106. - Procedure generally. 
    Any person desiring the city to change the name of any street thereof shall file a petition with the city secretary, in writing, directed to the city council. Such petition shall contain a description of the street. A list of all abutting property owners shall be attached to such petition, together with the last known addresses of all such owners. In the event that all abutting owners do not join in such petition, a statement shall be attached to said request showing the reason for nonparticipation of those who have not signed. Ownership information appearing on the last approved city tax roll shall be conclusive as to the names of the abutting property owners. Upon the filing of such request, the city secretary shall mail notices of such request to all abutting property owners. Such notice must be given not less than ten (10) days before the date set for hearing. Notice shall be considered as being properly given when notices are deposited, addressed and postage paid, in the United States mails. 
(Code 1965, § 23-55; Ord. No. 4701, § 15(a), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 21-107. - City council action. 
    No request for a street name change shall be acted upon until after a public hearing in relation thereto, at which parties in interest and citizens shall have had an opportunity to be heard. At least ten (10) days' notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published in a paper of general circulation in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 23-56) 
Sec. 21-108. - Administrative charges. 
    Upon the filing of any request for a street name change, an administration fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be paid to the city secretary to cover the expense of administering the procedure outlined in this article, the cost of mailing notices to all abutting property owners, and the cost of publishing the public notice. Such fee shall be nonrefundable. 
(Code 1965, § 23-57; Ord. No. 4701, § 15(a), 6-17-13) 
Secs. 21-109-21-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ENTERTAINMENT DISTRICTS 

Sec. 21-121. - Entertainment district established. 
    The Downtown Entertainment District, referred to in this article as "the district" is hereby created within the area of downtown Denison, the boundaries of which are more particularly described as follows: 
    Beginning at the southwest corner of Forest Park which is the common point of the east right-of-way line of the 300 Block of South Fannin Avenue and the north right-of-way line of the 400 Block of West Morgan Street; 
    Then northerly along the east right-of-way line of Fannin Avenue, across Crawford Street to the southwest corner of Block 63, OTP; 
    Then westerly along the north right-of-way line Crawford Street one city block to the southwest corner of Block 17, Steven's Addition; 
    Then northerly along the east right-of-way line of the 100 and 200 block of south Barrett Avenue, crossing Chestnut Street, to the northwest corner of Block 16, Steven's Addition; 
    Then westerly along the south right-of-way line of the 600 and 700 block of West Main Street to the northwest corner of Block 2, Miller's First Addition; 
    Then northerly, crossing Main Street, along the east right-of-way line of Armstrong Avenue to the northwest corner of Block 19, Miller's First Addition; 
    Then easterly along the south right-of-way line of West Woodard Street to the intersection with Austin Avenue, crossing Austin Avenue to the northwest corner of Block 46, OTP; 
    Then northerly across Woodard Street to the northwest corner of Block 39, OTP; 
    Then easterly along the south right-of-way line of Gandy Street to the northeast corner of Block 40, OTP; 
    Then southerly along the west line of the railroad right-of-way to its intersection with the 100 block of East Crawford Street; 
    Then westerly along the north right-of-way line of Crawford Street, crossing Houston, Austin and Rusk Avenues to the southeast corner of Block 62, OTP; 
    Then southerly, crossing Crawford Street, to the south right-of-way line of Crawford Street at a point that is the northeast corner of the Denison ISD Munson Stadium property; 
    Then westerly along the south right-of-way line of Crawford Street to a point that is the northeast corner of Forest Park and the northwest corner of DISD Munson Stadium property; 
    Then southerly along the common line separating Forest Park from Munson Stadium to a point in the north right-of-way line of West Morgan Street; 
    Then westerly along the north right-of-way line of the 300 and 400 block of West Morgan Street to the point of beginning. 
(Ord. No. 4643, § 1, 3-5-12) 
Sec. 21-122. - Use of public sidewalk. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions of this Code and subject to the requirements and limitations herein provided, the public sidewalks within the district adjacent to commercial enterprises within the district may be used by the proprietors of such enterprises during the hours of business operation for such uses as, but not limited to, the display of merchandise, merchandise racks, sandwich board signs, benches, tables, food service, etc. Prior to initiating the use of the adjacent sidewalk, the proprietor shall file with the city secretary a certificate of insurance for general liability in the minimum coverage amount of five hundred thousand dollars/one million dollars ($500,000.00/$1,000,000.00), combined single limit, evidencing the City of Denison as an additional insured. Additionally, during the period when the adjacent sidewalk is occupied by the adjacent proprietor, the following standards shall apply: 
(1)  Between the curb of street and the area of sidewalk used, maintain at least six (6) feet of clear passage for pedestrians, 
(2)  Tables and chairs shall not be placed within ten (10) feet of an entrance or doorway, 
(3)  No fences, walls, partitions, barriers, or other fixtures or objects may be placed in the sidewalk area with the exception that a removable freestanding balustrade may be used to mark the boundaries of a sidewalk café or food serving area, if applicable, 
(4)  Keep clean of spills, debris, litter, etc. the adjacent sidewalk and street areas, 
(5)  The property owner is responsible for condition of the sidewalk and the making of repairs to the sidewalk area and to brick pavers. Repairs shall be made within thirty (30) days after notice from city. 
    Nothing herein shall be construed to limit or prohibit an adjacent property owner from applying for and receiving a sidewalk license agreement for commercial use of the sidewalk beyond that which is contemplated by this section. 
(Ord. No. 4643, § 1, 3-5-12; Ord. No. 4701, § 15(a), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 21-123. - Sound amplification within district. 
    Pursuant to the authority of section 13-102 of this Code, and without the issuance of a permit for amplification, an entertainment venue within the district may use amplification during periods of operation of the venue during days and times of day that coincide with the alcoholic beverage permit in use by the venue, and in no event shall the measurement of the sound exceed ninety (90) dB at the point of sound mixing. If no alcoholic beverage permit is applicable, sound amplification shall cease at 2:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday and at Midnight during the remaining days. 
(Ord. No. 4643, § 1, 3-5-12) 
Sec. 21-124. - Special event street and public park use. 
    Authority is hereby delegated to the city manager, or his designee, to undertake the following: 
(1)  Close the streets, or portions thereof, within the district for events sponsored by the city or held in conjunction with the city, for such times and duration as may be specified in writing to the chief of police; 
(2)  Grant a temporary, exclusive use of public park space in order to facilitate such events, and promulgate performance requirements for grantees; 
(3)  Promulgate standards for closing such streets, for the occupying and use of streets and public parks during the periods of such events, including, but not limited to, the use of streets and parks for the sale and consumption of beer and wine; 
(4)  Suspend temporarily valid mobile vending and itinerant merchant permits so as to prohibit the holders of such permits from participating in special events without first having registered and paid any applicable fee associated with exhibiting or vending during the special event; and 
(5)  Enter into such rental and use agreements on behalf of the city as may be reasonably necessary to support and encourage such special events. 
(Ord. No. 4643, § 1, 3-5-12) 
Sec. 21-125. - Alcohol possession and consumption. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 3-5, 3-8, and 3-10 of this Code and V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 101.75, the possession and consumption of beer and wine on public property within the district during the days and hours of a special event within the district is permitted. This section does not affect the prohibition against possessing an open container in a passenger area of a motor vehicle under V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 49.031. 
(Ord. No. 4643, § 1, 3-5-12) 
Sec. 21-126. - Conflict with other provisions. 
    It is the legislative intent of the city council that conflicting provisions of this article with other sections of this Code be read together and reconciled so as to preserve the meaning, intent and effect of each provision if possible. But should such conflicts be irreconcilable, then it is the city council's intent that the provisions of this article shall control to the extent necessary to resolve the conflict. Nothing herein is intended to repeal any provision of the Code unless such repeal is clearly stated herein. 
(Ord. No. 4643, § 1, 3-5-12) 
Secs. 21-127-21-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RIGHT-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-130. - Administration. 
    The city manager shall appoint a right-of-way (ROW) manager, who is the principal city official responsible for the administration of the ROW, ROW permits, the regulation of same and ordinances and codes related thereto. The ROW manager may delegate any or all of the duties hereunder. The ROW manager shall have the duties, responsibilities and authority as specified for the ROW manager stated herein. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-131. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions apply in this article. The terms, phrases, words, abbreviations and their derivations shall have the same meanings herein. When not inconsistent with the context words used in the present tense include the future; words in plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely permissive. 
    Abandoned facilities means facilities no longer in service or physically disconnected from the operating facilities, or from any other facilities, or from any other facilities that are in use or that still carry service. 
    Administration fee means the fee charged by the city to recover its costs incurred for ROW management; including, but not limited to, costs associated with registering applicants; issuing, processing, and verifying ROW permit applications; inspecting job sites and restoration improvements; determining the adequacy of the ROW restoration; revoking ROW permits and other costs the city may incur in implementing the provisions of this article. 
    Applicant means an owner or authorized agent of an owner, who submits an application for a permit under the provisions of this article. 
    Area of influence means that area around a utility excavation where the pavement and subgrade is impacted by the excavation and is subject to more rapid deterioration due to the trench excavation. 
    Backfill means the following: 
(1)  The placement of new dirt, fill, or other material to refill an excavation; or 
(2)  The return of excavated dirt, fill or other material to an excavation. 
    Certified telecommunications provider or "CTP" means a person who has been issued a certificate of convenience and necessity, certificate of operating authority, or service provider certificate of operating authority by the Texas Public Utility Commission or "PUC" to offer local exchange telephone service as defined by V.T.C.A, Local Government Code ch. 283 or "the Act". 
    City as used herein shall mean the City of Denison, Texas and the city's officers and employees. 
    City project means the construction, location, maintenance, relocation, alteration, improvement, repair, removal or other work performed by the city, or its designee, in the public right-of-way or on any city utilities or city facilities. 
    City utilities means any water, sewer or drainage line owned and operated by the City of Denison. 
    Collector street means any roadway or street classified on the City of Denison's Comprehensive Plan, as it exists or may be amended, as a collector. 
    Compaction refers to consolidating backfill material in a trench to prevent future settlement. 
    Comprehensive plan means the City of Denison's Comprehensive Plan, as it exists or may be amended. 
    Contractor means any public or private person, subcontractor or organization, other than the City of Denison, Texas. 
    Construction means boring, the breaking of pavement, or the installation, modification, upgrade, maintenance, removal, or similar activities, within the right-of-way. The definition includes, but is not limited to, providing primary service, restoration, or maintenance of existing facilities within the ROW. 
    Day means business day unless otherwise specified. 
    Department means the City of Denison Department of Public Works or a successor department that is responsible for management of the ROW and roadway infrastructure. 
    Emergency operations are defined as those operations and repairs necessary to prevent damage or injury to the health or safety of the public or any person and the work necessary to address or prevent an immediate service interruption. Upgrading of facilities, new service installation and neighborhood improvement projects are not emergency operations. 
    Excavation means any activity that removes or otherwise disturbs soil, pavement, driveways, curbs, or sidewalks in the ROW and does not include landscaping activity unless the activity removes or disturbs the paved portion of the ROW. 
    Facilities means the equipment, and property, including but not limited to, lines, poles, mains, pipes, conduits, ducts, cables, valves, man holes, hand holes and wires located under, on, or above the surface of the ground within the ROW, and related facilities and equipment used or useful for the provision of utility services. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission. 
    Governing body means the Mayor and the City Council of the City of Denison, Texas. 
    Governmental entity means any county, township, city, town, village, school district, library district, road district, drainage or levee district, sewer district, water district, fire district or other municipal corporation, quasi-municipal corporation or political subdivision of the State of Texas or of any other state of the United States and any agency or instrumentality of the State of Texas or of any other state of the United States. 
    Holiday shall refer to days in which city offices are closed in observance of a holiday. 
    Local street means any roadway or street not classified on the City of Denison's Comprehensive Plan, as it exists or may be amended, as a highway, major thoroughfare, minor thoroughfare or collector. 
    Main line shall refer to lines other than service connections used to convey the ROW user's product. 
    Major project means any project, which includes three hundred (300) or more linear feet of excavation or any excavation under pavement. 
    Pavement shall refer to streets containing Portland cement, asphalt, brick or other rigid or semi-rigid material that covers the surface of a street and their underlying sub grade and base. 
    Permit means a permit issued under this article authorizing excavation in the ROW. 
    Permittee means any person or ROW user to whom a permit is issued to excavate a ROW. 
    Person means any person, company, partnership, contractor, subcontractor, agency or other public or private entity, excepting the city. 
    Perpendicular excavations means any trench with a centerline that when projected toward the centerline of the street, the two (2) lines intersect at an angle of ninety (90) degrees. 
    Public inconvenience penalty shall refer to a penalty assessed to the ROW user who denies the public the use of public property for a time period greater than allowed by this article. 
    PUCT means the Public Utility Commission of Texas. 
    Registration means the annual application process of the ROW user to use any portion of the ROW. 
    Registration certificate shall refer to the document provided by the city, annually, upon approval of the application for registration. 
    Repair means the temporary or permanent construction work necessary to make the ROW useable. 
    Repair area means that area around excavation where the pavement and sub grade is impacted by an excavation. 
    Restoration means the process by which an excavated ROW and surrounding area, including, but not limited to, pavement and foundation structures, ground cover, landscaping, and monuments are returned to the same condition, or better than that which existed before the commencement of the work. 
    Resurfacing means any repaving, overlay, seal or reconstruction which creates a new pavement surface over the entire width of the street, excluding crack seals and localized base and pavement repairs. 
    Right-of-way or public right-of-way (ROW) means the surface of, and the space above and below, any street, road, highway, freeway, lane, path, drainage way, channel, fee interest, public way or place, sidewalk, alley, boulevard, parkway, drive, fire lane or other easement now or hereafter held by the city or over which the city exercises any rights of management or control and shall include, but not be limited to, all easements now held, or hereafter held, by the city, but shall specifically excludes private property. 
    Right-of-way (ROW) manager as used herein shall mean the ROW Manager of the City of Denison, or his/her designee. 
    Right-of-way (ROW) user means a person, its successors and assigns, that uses the ROW for purposes of work, excavation, provision of services, or installing, constructing, maintaining, or repairing facilities thereon, including, but not limited to, landowners and service providers. 
    Routine service operation means a work activity that makes no material change to the facilities and does not disrupt traffic. 
    Service means a commodity provided to a person by means of a delivery system that is comprised of facilities located or to be located in the ROW, including, but not limited to, gas, telephone, cable television, internet services, open video systems, alarm systems, steam, electric, water, telegraph, data transmission, petroleum pipelines, or sanitary sewage. 
    Service connection shall refer to the line that serves no more than two (2) individual customers or two (2) meter banks. 
    Street means the paved portion of the ROW that has been constructed, reconstructed, or resurfaced with concrete or asphalt or some other surface. 
    Surface mounted markers refers to any sign, post or other marker, which rises above the surface of the ground to show the location of an underground utility. 
    TMUTCD shall mean the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, as it exists or may be amended. 
    Thoroughfare means any roadway or street classified on the City of Denison's Comprehensive Plan, as it exists or may be amended, as a highway, major thoroughfare or minor thoroughfare. 
    Traffic control representative shall refer to the designated representative of the row user who is responsible for work zone safety and compliance with TMUTCD. The ROW user shall ensure such person has adequate training, knowledge and authority to perform the responsibilities listed above. 
    Trench shall refer to excavation deeper than twenty-four (24) inches. This shall include linear trenches, holes, pits and etc. 
    Underground Facility Damage Protection Safety Act shall refer to the V.T.C.A., Utility Code § 251.001 et seq., as it exists or may be amended. 
    Utility means any privately or publicly owned entity which uses ROW to furnish the public any general public service, including, without limitation, sanitary sewer, gas, electricity, water, telephone, petroleum products, telegraph, heat, steam or chilled water, together with the equipment, structures, and appurtenances belonging to such entity and located within and near the ROW. Poles are regulated herein only as specifically set forth in this article. 
    White lining means marking the excavation site with white washable marking paint or flags prior to requesting a utility locate in order to further identify the site. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-132. - Utility coordination. 
    Each utility shall name a utility coordinator who shall participate in utility coordination meetings upon request by the City of Denison. All ROW users with open permits shall send one (1) representative to the utility coordination meeting pertaining to the specific/related project as determined by the City of Denison. Meetings shall be held at the time and location established by the city. City shall notify, by any means, the ROW users of the required attendance meetings. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-133. - Field utility coordination. 
    The ROW user shall notify the department at each of the following times during a project: (a) forty-eight (48) hours before the start of construction; (b) upon completion of the initial backfill; and (c) upon completion of the project. The ROW user shall make a request for a utility locate in compliance with the Underground Facility Damage Prevention and Safety Act. 
    The use of markers, stakes, poles, barricades or other devices shall be used in such a way to avoid damage to adjoining property. The use of "non-washable" markers is prohibited. Compliance with the Texas Utilities Code, as amended, is required at all times. 
    All barricades, plates, cones, traffic directional equipment and all other traffic control devices owned, leased or used by the ROW user and used on or near any excavation shall be maintained in a clean and functional condition as determined by the City of Denison. Modifications to any traffic control plan shall be implemented immediately upon notification from the City of Denison. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-134. - Maps and records of registrants. 
    Upon request, each existing ROW user shall provide the city an accurate map of their service area. The map shall be in electronic format overlaid over the City of Denison ETJ map. In dual coverage areas, the city may request additional information to enable identification of ROW users. 
    Each ROW user must maintain accurate and up-to-date maps and records of its facilities. The city's available plans and maps may be provided upon request. The ROW users provided information should include true bearings and distances to the nearest established street lines and official monuments, which shall be accurately described on the map. The ROW user will provide the city with information within ninety (90) days of a request for maps from the city. 
    If the maps and records submitted in response to any request by or requirement of the city include information expressly designated by the ROW user as a trade secret or other confidential information protected from disclosure by state law, the city and its agents, employees, or other representatives may not disclose that information to the public without the consent of the ROW user, unless otherwise compelled by an opinion of the attorney general pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, as amended, or by a court having jurisdiction of the matter pursuant to applicable law. This subsection may not be construed to authorize a ROW user to designate all matters in its maps and records as confidential or as trade secrets. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-135. - Notice. 
    Notice for purposes of this article shall be made to the city via electronic message (e-mail), overnight courier (generally used carrier with tracing available), hand delivery with signed receipt, facsimile transmission, or deposited with sufficient postage with the United States Postal Service return receipt required. All notices shall be provided to the ROW manager. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-136. - Registration. 
(a)  Nothing in this section relieves a ROW user and/or utility from obtaining a permit under this article to perform work in the ROW. 
(b)  In order to protect the public health, safety, and welfare, a utility maintaining or operating existing facilities in the ROW must register with the ROW manager in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  The registration must be on a form furnished by the ROW manager and made in the name of the ROW user that owns the facilities. 
(2)  Registration expires December 31 of the following year after the first registration occurs. If the utility fails to renew registration by that date, the city will send by certified mail a notice of noncompliance to the address listed on the registration. If the utility fails to renew registration within thirty (30) calendar days after the date of sending the notification, the facilities of the utility will be deemed to have been legally abandoned. 
(3)  If information provided as part of the registration changes, the utility must inform the ROW manager, in writing, not more than thirty (30) days after the date the change occurs. 
(4)  The utility shall also include the following registration: 
a.  The name of the utility using the ROW, including any business name, assumed name, or trade name the utility operates under or has operated under in the city within the past five (5) years. 
b.  If the utility is a CTP, the certificate number issued by the Texas Public Utility Commission. 
c.  The ordinance number of any franchise or license issued by the city that authorizes the utility to use the ROW. 
d.  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least two (2) persons who will be general, day-to-day contacts for the utility. At least one (1) of the addresses must be within fifty (50) miles of the City of Denison. 
e.  The name and mailing address of the officer or agent designated as the person authorized to receive service of process on behalf of the utility. 
f.  The name, address and telephone number of any contractor or subcontractor, who will be working in the ROW on behalf of the utility. This list may be amended as needed by the utility; however no work shall be performed in the ROW by a contractor or subcontractor that is not on the list, regardless of whether a permit is required. 
g.  The names and telephone numbers of at least two (2) persons serving as emergency contacts who can be reached by telephone twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week. 
h.  Proof of existing insurance that complies with section 21-189. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-137. - Traffic handling training. 
    The ROW user is responsible for work zone safety including, but not limited to, traffic control through the designated traffic control representative. The representative is responsible for compliance with the TMUTCD and the traffic control plan (if required) at all work zone sites. The traffic control representative shall ensure employees on the job site have adequate training. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-138. - Reporting obligations. 
    All ROW users shall, upon request, provide proof of any necessary permit, license, certification, grant, registration, franchise agreement or any other authorization required by any governmental entity, including, but not limited to, the city, state, or federal government, or railroad or pipeline company, including a description of the ROW user's intended use of the ROW, information sufficient to determine whether the ROW user is subject to franchising or licensing by the city, and information to determine whether the ROW user has applied for and received any certificate of authority required by the PUCT. The information provided shall be sufficient enough to determine whether the ROW user has applied for and received any permit or other approvals required by the FCC. ROW user shall provide all such other information as may be reasonably required by the city to complete the registration statement. 
(Ord. No. 4775, § 2, 3-16-15) 
Sec. 21-139. - Relocation of facilities for public improvements. 
(a)  In the exercise of governmental functions, the city has first priority over all uses of the ROW. The city reserves the right to, among other things, lay water, sewer, drainage, and other pipelines or cables and conduits, and to do underground and overhead work, and attachments, restructuring, or changes in street facilities in across, along, over, or under a public street, alley or ROW occupied by an agency or ROW user, and to change the curb, sidewalks, or the grade of streets.
