    No driver of any vehicle shall drive over an unprotected hose of the fire department when such hose has been laid down on any street or private driveway to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the fire department official in command. 
(Code 1965, § 26-51) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 101. 
Sec. 25-58. - Funeral processions. 
    Every funeral procession shall be marked with appropriate pennants or other device or method, such as burning headlights in daytime, sufficient to show the nature of such procession and any person who, as the driver of any vehicle, shall cross through or interrupt any funeral procession shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 26-52) 
Sec. 25-59. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    Any driver of any vehicle who shall drive such vehicle upon any sidewalk or sidewalk area of any street within the city, except on a driveway, public or private, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 26-53) 
Sec. 25-60. - Driving through safety zones. 
    No driver of any vehicle shall, at any time, drive through or within a safety zone. 
(Code 1965, § 26-54) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 85. 
Sec. 25-61. - Passing around rotary traffic island. 
    The driver of a vehicle passing around any rotary traffic island within the city shall drive only to the right of such island. 
(Code 1965, § 26-55) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 59(c). 
Sec. 25-62. - Exhibition of acceleration prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver of any motor vehicle to wilfully cause such vehicle to dig out or to cause any such vehicle to make unnecessary noise by reason of operating such vehicle in such manner as to cause the wheels thereof to spin or slide on the roadway of any street when starting such vehicle or while making any turning movement. 
(Code 1965, § 26-57; Ord. No. 4701, § 18(c), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 18(c) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, changed the title of § 25-62 from "Digging out prohibited" to "Exhibition of acceleration prohibited." 
Sec. 25-63. - Alternative motor-driven vehicles. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
    Neighborhood electric vehicle and low-speed vehicle are synonymous and mean: 
(1)  A vehicle subject to Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 500 (49 C.F.R. Section 571.500); and 
(2)  A vehicle registered by the State of Texas; and 
(3)  A vehicle for which the owner or operator has complied with V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 601, Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility. 
    Motor assisted scooter. 
(1)  Means a self-propelled device with: 
a.  At least two (2) wheels in contact with the ground during operation; 
b.  A braking system capable of stopping the device under typical operating conditions; 
c.  A gas or electric motor not exceeding forty (40) cubic centimeters; 
d.  A deck designed to allow a person to stand or sit while operating the device; and 
e.  The ability to be propelled by human power alone; and 
(2)  Does not include a pocket bike or mini-motorbike. 
    Pocket bike or mini-motorbike means a self-propelled vehicle that is equipped with an electric motor or internal combustion engine having a piston displacement of less than fifty (50) cubic centimeters, is designed to propel itself with not more than two (2) wheels in contact with the ground, has a seat or saddle for the use of the operator, is not designed for use on a highway, and is ineligible for a certificate of title under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 501. The term does not include: 
(1)  A moped or motorcycle; 
(2)  An electric bicycle or motor-driven cycle, as defined by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 541.201; 
(3)  A motorized mobility device, as defined by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.009; 
(4)  An electric personal assistive mobility device, as defined by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 551.201; or 
(5)  A neighborhood electric vehicle. 
(b)  (1)  In addition to the streets and highways listed in subsection (b)(2) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a neighborhood electric vehicle or a motor assisted scooter on a street for which the posted speed limit is equal to or greater than thirty-five (35) miles per hour. A neighborhood electric vehicle may cross a road or street at an intersection where the road or street has a posted speed limit equal to or greater than thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a neighborhood electric vehicle or a motor assisted scooter on any of the following streets within the corporate limits; to-wit: 
a.  North and South Avenues: 
Armstrong. 
Crockett. 
Juanita. 
Lillis Lane. 
Maurice. 
Mirick. 
Park. 
b.  East and West Streets: 
Coffin, from Spur 503 to Woodlawn Blvd. 
Crawford. 
Crawford Street Road. 
c.  State Highways: 
F.M. 120. 
Spur 503. 
State Highways 84 and 91. 
U.S. Highway 75. 
U.S. Highway 69. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a neighborhood electric vehicle upon any street within the corporate limits unless such person shall be the holder of a valid Texas Driver's License issued by the state department of public safety. 
(c)  This section may not be construed to authorize the operation of a pocket bike or mini-motorbike on any: 
(1)  Highway, road, or street; 
(2)  Path set aside for the exclusive operation of bicycles; or 
(3)  Sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 4481, § 1, 10-6-08) 
Sec. 25-64. - Use of hand-held mobile telephones prohibited in school zones. 
(a)  For purposes of this section the following definitions apply: 
(1)  Engaging in a call shall mean talking into, dialing, answering or listening on a hand-held mobile telephone, but shall not include holding a mobile telephone to activate or deactivate such telephone. 
(2)  Hands-free mobile telephone shall mean a mobile telephone that has an internal feature or function, or that is equipped with an attachment or addition, whether or not permanently part of such mobile telephone, by which a user engages in a call without the use of either hand (or prosthetic device or aid in the case of a physically disabled person), whether or not the use of either hand (or prosthetic device) is necessary to activate, deactivate or initiate a function of such telephone. 
(3)  Hand-held mobile telephone shall mean a mobile telephone with which a user engages in a call using at least one (1) hand (or prosthetic device or aid in the case of a physically disabled person). 
(4)  Mobile telephone shall mean the device used by subscribers and other users of wireless telephone service to access such service and shall include personal digital assistants. 
(5)  Personal digital assistant shall mean a device operated using a wireless telecommunications service that provides for data communication other than by voice. 
(6)  Wireless telephone service shall mean two-way real-time voice telecommunications service that is interconnected to a public switched telephone network and commonly referred to as cellular service or personal communication service. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided below, it shall be unlawful for a person to drive or operate a motor vehicle in a school zone, as designated by any lawful authority, on official school days, during the hours when school zones are in effect, and when school zone signs and signs prohibiting hand-held mobile telephone use are posted in place, while using a hand-held or hands-free mobile telephone to engage in a call or to create, send or read messages. 
(c)  An operator of a motor vehicle who holds a mobile telephone to, or in the immediate proximity of his or her ear while such vehicle is in motion is presumed to be engaging in a call within the meaning of this section. Immediate proximity shall mean that distance as permits the operator of a mobile telephone to hear telecommunications transmitted over such mobile telephone, but shall not require physical contact with such operator's ear. 
(d)  Subsection (b) shall not apply to: 
(1)  The use of a mobile telephone for the sole purpose of communicating with any of the following regarding an emergency situation, an emergency response operator; a hospital, a physician's office; 
(2)  Any law enforcement, public safety or police officers, emergency services officials, first aid, emergency medical technicians and personnel, or any fire safety officials in the performance of duties arising out of and in the course of their employment as such; or 
(3)  The use of a hands-free mobile telephone when being used in a hands-free manner. 
(Ord. No. 4499, § 1, 2-16-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4499, § 1, adopted Feb. 16, 2009, set out provisions intended for use as § 25-63. Inasmuch as there were already provisions so designated, the provisions have been redesignated as § 25-64, at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 25-65-25-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES 

Sec. 25-81. - Conformity with manual and specifications of state highway department; uniformity. 
    All traffic-control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by the state highway department. All signs and signals required under this chapter for a particular purpose shall, so far as practicable, be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic-control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic-control devices. 
(Code 1965, § 26-70) 
Sec. 25-82. - General powers and duties of director of public works relative to devices. 
    The director of public works shall place and maintain traffic-control signs, signals and devices when and as required under this chapter to make effective the provisions of this chapter, and may place and maintain such additional traffic-control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate traffic under this chapter or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. It shall be the duty of the director of public works to supervise the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control devices. 
(Code 1965, § 26-71) 
Sec. 25-83. - Designation of crosswalks, safety zones; marking traffic lanes. 
    The director of public works is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at any intersection where, in his opinion, there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may deem necessary. 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(3)  To mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1965, § 26-72) 
Sec. 25-84. - Obedience to devices. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 26-73) 
Sec. 25-85. - Necessity of signs. 
    No provision of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if, at the time and place of the alleged violation, an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(Code 1965, § 26-74) 
Sec. 25-86. - Installation of traffic lights. 
    The director of public works, as authorized by the city council from time to time, shall designate intersections at which traffic shall be controlled by electric traffic-control signals or lights and shall cause such signals or lights to be installed and maintained at such intersections. 
(Code 1965, § 26-75) 
Sec. 25-87. - Ratification of existing devices. 
    All traffic-control signs, signals, devices, and markings placed or erected prior to the adoption of this Code and in use for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic are hereby affirmed, ratified and declared to be official traffic-control devices, provided such traffic-control devices are not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter or state law. 
(Code 1965, § 26-79) 
Sec. 25-88. - Unauthorized signs, signals, etc. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any road, street or highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an imitation or resembles an official traffic-control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic-control device or any railroad signal or sign, and no person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any highway or street any traffic signal or sign bearing thereon any commercial advertising. This shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection, upon private property adjacent to streets or highways, of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signals. 
(b)  Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the city is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 36. 
Sec. 25-89. - Altering, injuring, etc., devices. 
    No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic-control device or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon or any other part thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 26-81) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 37. 
Secs. 25-90-25-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SPEED REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Speed of vehicles in cities and authority of cities to alter prima facie speed limits established by state law, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, §§ 166, 169. 

Sec. 25-106. - Maximum limits generally. 
(a)  No person shall operate or drive any vehicle on any street within the city at a greater speed than thirty (30) miles per hour, unless signs are erected designating another speed in accordance with this article. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, no person shall drive a vehicle on a street at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and having regard to the actual and potential hazards then existing. In every event, speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(c)  The driver of every vehicle shall, consistent with the requirements of (b) above, drive at an appropriate reduced speed when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway, and when a special hazard exists with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or street or highway conditions. 
(Code 1965, § 26-92) 
Sec. 25-107. - Maximum limits on specific streets. 
    The city council may alter the maximum speed limit of thirty (30) miles per hour, as established by section 25-106, on any street or portion thereof within the city in accord with the provisions of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, section 169. Whenever signs are posted giving notice of the maximum legal speed limit so established for a particular street or portion thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle at a rate of speed in excess of such limit. 
(Code 1965, § 26-93) 
Sec. 25-107.1. - School zone speed limits.

(b)  It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of the prima facie speed limit as herein established on the days, times and portion of streets herein specified and identified. Upon conviction of violation, punishment shall be by fine in an amount not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 3795, §§ 1, 3, 4-20-98; Ord. No. 4217, § 1, 4-5-04; Ord. No. 4262, § 1, 12-13-04; Ord. No. 4430, § 1, 11-19-07; Ord. No. 4500, § 1, 2, 2-16-09; Ord. No. 4701, § 18(d), 6-17-13; Ord. No. 4838, § 2, 9-19-16) 
Sec. 25-107.2. - Additional school zone speed limits. 
(a)  The prima facie maximum speed limit is established at twenty (20) miles-per-hour and it shall be unlawful to exceed such speed, during the hours of 7:30 a.m. until 8:30 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. until 3:30 p.m. on each and every day in which the Denison public and private schools are in session and holding classes, on the following described portions of city streets; to-wit:

Sec. 25-107.3. - Speed limits on certain highways. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle upon a public road, street or highway in the City of Denison, Texas, at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and circumstances then existing. Except when a special hazard exists that requires lower speeds for compliance with the above requirement, the limits hereinafter set out shall be lawful, but any speed in excess of the limits as hereinafter set out for the streets and highways and portions thereof to which they apply shall be prima facie evidence that the speed is not reasonable or prudent: 
Farm-to-Market (FM) Highway 120 from the west city limit of Denison in a easterly direction for an approximate distance of 2.254 miles a speed limit of sixty (60) miles per hour at all times; thence in a easterly direction for an approximate distance of 0.600 miles a speed limit of fifty (50) miles per hour at all times; thence in a easterly direction for a distance of 2.090 miles a speed limit of forty (40) miles per hour at all times; thence in an easterly direction for an approximate distance of 0.374 miles a speed limit of 35 (thirty-five) miles per hour at all times; thence in an easterly direction for an approximate distance of 0.504 miles a speed limit of 45 (forty-five) miles per hour at all times to the east city limit of Denison as evidenced by the attached plan is hereby approved and made a part thereof. 
FM Highway 131 , from approximate highway mile point 0.623 the northern city limit of Denison to mile point 2.200 the southern city limit of Denison in southerly direction a distance of approximately 1.577 miles, a speed limit of fifty-five (55) miles per hour at all times; as evidenced by the plan attached to Ord. No. 4521 is hereby approved and made a part thereof. 
On U.S. 75 frontage roads from their beginning at approximate mile point 10.672 on the northbound frontage road and mile point 10.680 on the southbound frontage road to approximate mile point 6.444 in southerly direction a distance of approximately 4.321 miles on the northbound frontage road and approximately 4.313 miles on the southbound frontage road, a speed limit of 55 (fifty-five) miles per hour at all times; thence southerly on both the northbound and southbound frontage roads from the approximate mile point 6.634 to the intersection of FM 120, for a distance of approximately 0.526 miles, a speed limit of 55 (fifty-five) miles per hour at all times as evidenced by the attached plan is hereby approved and made a part thereof. 
    The violation of any provision of this section shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor offense punishable by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day a violation of this section continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3841, §§ 1, 2, 4, 12-14-98; Ord. No. 4068, § 1, 9-4-01; Ord. No. 4188, §§ 1, 3, 9-15-03; Ord. No. 4515, § 1, 5-18-09; Ord. No. 4521, § 1, 6-15-09; Ord. No. 4686, § 1, 4-15-13; Ord. No. 4833, § 2, 9-6-16) 
Sec. 25-108. - Maximum limit in certain alleys. 
(a)  The maximum legal speed limit in those alleys situated between Main Street and Chestnut Street from Houston Avenue on the East to Barrett Avenue on the West, and between Main Street and Woodward Street from Barrett Avenue on the West to Houston Avenue on the East, is hereby fixed as fifteen (15) miles per hour. When signs are in place giving notice of such limit, no person shall drive a vehicle in any such alley at a speed in excess of such limit. 
(b)  The maximum legal speed limit in those alleys situated immediately East and West of Frances Avenue and Flowers Drive on the South of Hi Meadow Drive on the North, is hereby fixed as fifteen (15) miles per hour. When signs are in place giving notice of such limit, no person shall drive a vehicle in any such alley at a speed in excess of such limit. 
(Code 1965, § 26-94) 
Sec. 25-109. - Racing prohibited. 
    Any person who shall race or engage in a contest for speed between motor vehicles of any kind upon any public street or alley within the city shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. The fact that the actual speed attained by any vehicle engaged in racing or a contest for speed is less than the prima facie legal speed limit shall be no defense to a complaint of racing or engaging in a contest for speed in violation of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 26-95) 
Sec. 25-110. - Minimum limits. 
    No person shall drive a motor vehicle at such a slow speed as to impede or block the normal and reasonable movement of traffic, except when reduced speed is necessary for safe operation or in compliance with law. 
(Code 1965, § 26-96) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 170(a). 
Sec. 25-111. - Exemptions from article. 
    The provisions of this article and other ordinances of the city regulating the speed of vehicles shall not apply to vehicles of the fire department when responding to a call, nor to police patrols, nor to physicians or ambulances when actually engaged in responding to emergency calls; provided however, that this section shall not authorize any ambulance driver to exceed the maximum legal speed limit by more than ten (10) miles per hour. 
(Code 1965, § 26-97) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 172. 
Secs. 25-112-25-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate standing and parking of vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(1). 

Sec. 25-131. - Unattended vehicles. 
    No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine and effectively setting the brakes thereon and, when standing upon any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the roadway. 
(Code 1965, § 26-108) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 97. 
Sec. 25-132. - Prohibited in certain places. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk or sidewalk area. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant, except within an officially marked parking stall. 
(5)  On a crosswalk. 
(6)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection or within twenty (20) feet of an intersection when marked by a yellow-colored curb. 
(7)  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign, or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway. 
(8)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings. 
(9)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
(10)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and, on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within seventy-five (75) feet of such entrance (when properly signposted). 
(11)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(12)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(13)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel. 
(14)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. 
(15)  Within twenty (20) feet of a refuse container furnished by the city to commercial and industrial concerns pursuant to chapter 20. 
(16)  Within ten (10) feet of either side of the driveway of any business or commercial establishment located within a business district. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any prohibited area specified above or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1965, § 26-109) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 95. 
Sec. 25-133. - Prohibited on certain streets. 
    No person shall park a vehicle or permit a vehicle to stand unattended on the following roadways, streets or highways: 
(1)  State Highway 91, on either side of the street in the following locations: 
a.  Armstrong Avenue from Scullin Avenue to Main Street. 
b.  Main Street from Scullin Avenue to Tone Avenue. 
c.  Tone Avenue from Main Street to Washington Avenue. 
(2)  Morton Street between Tone Avenue and Maurice Avenue. 
(3)  Austin Avenue between U.S. Highway 69 East and Washington Street. 
(4)  Scullin Avenue, in its east side of the street from its intersection with Armstrong to its intersection with Crawford Street. 
(5)  Both sides of Armstrong Avenue from Scullin Avenue to a point seven hundred twenty-five (725) feet south of Bullock Street. 
(6)  On the north side of Main Street between Travis Avenue and Crockett Avenue. 
(7)  On the south side of the 300 block of West Gandy Street, beginning one hundred twenty (120) feet west of the west curbline of the intersection of Gandy Street and Rusk Avenue, and extending westward twenty-five (25) feet. 
(8)  East and west sides of S.H. 91 South from Bullock Street to Flowers Drive. 
(9)  On the north side of the 100 block of East Main Street, from a point two hundred seventy (270) feet east of the east curbline of Houston Avenue, eastward to the east right-of-way line of the railroad. 
(10)  In the 500 block of South Burnett Avenue, on both the east and west sides of the street. 
(11)  Tower Lane, along the east curbline from its intersection with Armstrong Avenue to the beginning of its cul-de-sac. 
(12)  Seymore Street, on the north side of the street from the point of its intersection with Woodlawn Avenue to the point of its intersection with Maurice Avenue. 
(13)  That portion of the east curbline of the 2100 block of Mirick Avenue extending twenty-five (25) feet north of the north edge of the driveway of the Denison Girls Club to twenty-five (25) feet south of the south edge of such driveway. 
(14)  Flora Lane, on its south side of the street. 
(15)  Farm to Market Road 120 on either side of the roadway from its intersection with Bush Avenue to its intersection with Spring Valley Drive. 
(16)  Martin Luther King Boulevard on either side of the street in the 800 block; on the north side of the street in the 900 block; and on the south side of the street in the 1000 block. 
(17)  Armstrong Avenue on the west side from its intersection with Main Street to a point one hundred sixty-one (161) feet south of the intersection with Martin Luther King Boulevard. 
(18)  Pool Road beginning at a point one thousand nine hundred twenty (1,920) feet north of FM 691 and continuing in a northerly direction to the end of the present line of dedication; such parking prohibition to be effective on Monday through Friday, from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(Code 1965, § 26-109; Ord. No. 3104, § 1, 10-3-88; Ord. No. 3122, § 1, 2-6-89; Ord. No. 3129, § 1, 2-20-89; Ord. No. 3140, § 2, 4-17-89; Ord. No. 3190, § 1, 12-18-89; Ord. No. 4106, § 1, 5-6-02; Ord. No. 4122, §§ 1-4, 7-15-02; Ord. No. 4487, § 1, 11-17-08; Ord. No. 4603, § 2, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 4624, § 1, 10-17-11; Ord. No. 4701, § 18(e), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 25-134. - Prohibited for certain purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or permit to be parked any vehicle on any street in the city for the purpose of exhibiting such vehicle for sale, or for the purpose of washing such vehicle, or for the purpose of making repairs to such vehicle, except such repairs as may be necessary as emergency repairs. 
(Code 1965, § 26-110) 
Sec. 25-135. - Ten feet of roadway to be left available for traffic. 
    No person shall stop, stand, or park any vehicle upon a street in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of either lane of a roadway for free movement of the vehicular traffic, except that a driver may stop temporarily during the actual loading or unloading of passengers or when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals of a police officer. 
(Code 1965, § 26-111) 
Sec. 25-136. - Stop intersections. 
    The city council may designate any street intersection as a stop intersection and designate the streets upon which vehicles shall stop before entering such intersection. Whenever any intersection has been so designated, the director of public works shall cause the same to be identified by the erection of stop signs indicating which vehicles approaching the intersection shall stop, and it shall be the duty of the driver of any vehicle approaching such a sign to bring such vehicle to a complete stop at such sign or at a clearly marked stop line before entering the intersection, except when directed to proceed by a police officer or a traffic-control signal. After having so stopped, such driver shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles which have entered the intersection or which are approaching so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard. Such driver, after having so yielded, may proceed and the drivers of all other vehicles approaching on the intersecting street shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle so proceeding into or across the intersection. 
(Code 1965, § 26-112) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to designate stop intersections, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, §§ 27(a)(6), 91(a); duty of drivers with respect to stop signs, art. 6701d, §§ 73, 91(c).

Editor's note- Per the city's request to list all traffic and speed schedules, § 25-136.1 was added at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 25-137. - Stop on emerging from alley, driveway, parking lot or building and authorized procedure for entering traffic. 
    The driver of a vehicle emerging from an alley, driveway, parking lot or building shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving onto a street, roadway or highway, sidewalk or onto a sidewalk area extending across any alleyway or driveway, yielding the right-of-way to any pedestrian or vehicular traffic as may be necessary to avoid collision. All vehicles shall enter the roadway, street or highway in the approved direction of traffic for the nearest lane of traffic for that roadway, street or highway where traffic-control signs, devices or markings so direct. 
(Code 1965, § 26-113) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 92. 
Sec. 25-138. - Stop at railroad crossing upon approach of train. 
(a)  Whenever any person driving a vehicle approaches a railroad grade crossing under any of the circumstances stated in this section, the driver of such vehicle shall stop within fifty (50) feet, but not less than fifteen (15) feet, from the nearest rail of such railroad, and shall not proceed until he can do so safely. The foregoing requirements shall apply when: 
(1)  A clearly visible electric or mechanical signal device gives warning of the immediate approach of a railroad train; 
(2)  A crossing gate is lowered or when a human flagman gives or continues to give a signal of the approach or passage of a railroad train; 
(3)  A railroad train approaching within approximately one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet of the highway crossing emits a signal audible from such distance and such railroad train, by reason of its speed or nearness to such crossing, is an immediate hazard; 
(4)  An approaching railroad train is plainly visible and is in hazardous proximity to such crossing. 
(b)  No person shall drive any vehicle through, around or under any crossing gate or barrier at a railroad grade crossing while such gate or barrier is closed or is being opened or closed. 
(Code 1965, § 26-114) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 86. 
Sec. 25-139. - Designation and marking of parking stalls and areas where parking is prohibited or limited-Generally. 
(a)  The director of public works shall cause parking stalls to be maintained and marked off in and on such streets and parts thereof as may be designated by the city council from time to time and he shall cause spaces in which parking is prohibited to be maintained and marked off in and on such streets and parts thereof as may be designated by the city council from time to time. The director of public works shall also cause time limit parking areas to be maintained and marked off in and on such part or parts of streets as may be designated by the city council from time to time. All such spaces or areas shall be clearly indicated by appropriate signs or by markings on the pavement or curb. 
(b)  In areas designated as time limit parking areas, parking may be limited to any period prescribed by the council, the same to be designated with clearly distinguished markings or signs at both ends of the time limit area and at reasonable intervals between the beginning and ending of such time limit area, indicating the time allowed for parking in such area. 
(c)  Any prohibition of or time limit on parking established under this section shall apply on such days and between such hours as prescribed by the council. 
(Code 1965, § 26-115) 
Sec. 25-140. - Same-Parking lots leased by city restricted to two-hour parking. 
    All parking lots leased by the city are time limit parking areas within the meaning of this article. The use of individual parking stalls within such lots are restricted to two-hour parking at all times. Such lots will be clearly marked and posted as city parking lots. Signs shall be erected designating stalls within such lots as two-hour limit parking. 
(Code 1965, § 26-115.1) 
Sec. 25-141. - Same-Parking spaces for disabled or handicapped persons on public or private property. 
(a)  The owner or operator of any private parking facility is authorized to designate one (1) or more parking stalls or spaces in such private parking facility or lot for the exclusive use of vehicles which display a distinguishing license plate, specially designated symbols, tags or other devices prescribed from time to time by the state highway department including but not limited to license plates with the letters "DV" appearing as either a prefix or a suffix to the numerals on the plates and the words "DISABLED VET" appearing on such license plates, devices prescribed or designed by the state highway department with the word "DISABLED" printed thereof or with a prominently displayed identification card provided by the state department of highways and public transportation for disabled persons or such other devices, symbols or tabs as may be prescribed from time to time by the state highway department under the authority of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6675a.5e.1. 
(b)  All disabled or handicapped parking stalls or spaces authorized and designated under this section shall be of such size and marked according to prevailing state and federal standards for handicapped parking which stalls or spaces shall be a minimum of twelve (12) feet, six (6) inches in width for adequate wheelchair clearance. If the owner or operator of a private parking facility who has previously designated areas for handicapped parking elects not to conform such spaces to the standards herein required, such spaces and the marking thereof shall be eliminated by such owner or operator. The cost and expenses for the striping and marking of disabled or handicapped parking spaces on private property shall be the responsibility of the owner or operator of the private parking facility. Such stalls or spaces shall be designated by posting, at the owner's or operator's expense, immediately adjacent to and visible from each stall or space, a sign consisting of a profile view of a wheelchair with occupant in white on a blue background on a pole at least five (5) feet in height and included on such sign a notice of penalty for parking violations of a fifty dollars ($50.00) to two hundred dollars ($200.00) fine. The city will provide and install the signs required by this section on both public and private property, but the owner or operator of a private parking facility shall pay to the city the actual cost of labor and materials incurred to install the signs on such private property, together with ten (10) percent of the amount as a fee payment for establishing such disabled or handicapped parking on such private parking facility. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this section: 
(1)  For the operator of any vehicle not displaying a distinguishing license plate, symbol, tag or other device issued to disabled or handicapped persons pursuant to Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6675a-5e.1, and as set forth in (a) above to stop, stand, park, or leave standing such vehicle in any parking stall or space properly designated for the exclusive use of physically disabled or handicapped persons pursuant to this section. 
(2)  For the operator of any vehicle to cause, allow, permit or suffer such vehicle to be parked in any parking stall or space reserved for the disabled or handicapped pursuant to this section, even if such vehicle has affixed thereto a valid license plate, symbol, tag or other device issued in accordance with state law, and as set forth in (a) above, if such vehicle is not being used by or for the transportation of a disabled or handicapped person at the time such vehicle is parked in a reserved space. 
(3)  For the operator of any vehicle to cause, allow, permit or suffer such vehicle to be parked so that such vehicle blocks an access or curb ramp or any other architectural improvement designed to aid the disabled or handicapped. 
(d)  Such unlawful action as set forth in (c) above shall constitute a misdemeanor offense, which shall, upon conviction, subject the offender to a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). Furthermore, the operator of any vehicle found to be in violation of the provisions of (c) above may be issued a citation and summons to appear in municipal court regarding such violation. Furthermore, any vehicle found to be in violation of the provisions of (c) above may be towed from such disabled or handicapped parking space designated by this section at the expense of the owner or operator of such vehicle, and may be impounded until all towing and storage charges are paid. 
(Code 1965, § 26-115.2; Ord. No. 3131, § 2, 3-7-89) 
Sec. 25-141.1. - Disabled parking space designated. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to park or stand a motor vehicle in the disabled parking space herein designated unless such motor vehicle is marked as a vehicle eligible to use such restricted parking space, as defined and required by state law. Upon conviction of violation of the terms of this section, punishment shall be by fine in an amount consistent with the ordinances of the City of Denison and the laws of the State of Texas, but in no event in an amount exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
    A disabled parking space is created and established: 
In the 500 block of West Day Street adjacent to Lot 8, Block 1, A.R. Collins 1st Addition, parallel parking at the curb. 
(Ord. No. 3843, §§ 1, 3, 1-19-99) 
Editor's note- Per the city's request to list all traffic and speed schedules, § 25-141.1 was added at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 25-142. - Parking in prohibited areas; overtime parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name or owned or operated by him or in his possession or under his control to be or remain in any space or area in which parking is prohibited as provided in section 25-139 or in a time limit parking area for a longer period of time than that designated by the markings on the street or by signs clearly visible. 
(Code 1965, § 26-116) 
Sec. 25-143. - Parallel and angle parking. 
(a)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except as otherwise provided in this section. On one-way streets, vehicles may be parked on the left side of the street, with the left-hand wheels within eighteen (18) inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, unless signs prohibit parking. 
(b)  The director of public works, with the approval of the city council, shall determine upon which streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking shall not be indicated upon any federal-aid or state highway within this city unless the state highway engineer has determined that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the street or upon any railway tracks. 
(c)  Upon those streets which have been signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or markings. 
(d)  Whenever parking spaces are marked by lines on the pavement, whether for parallel or angle parking, a vehicle must be parked entirely within the lines of the parking space. 
(e)  Angle parking has been approved at the following locations: 
Woodard Street -All spaces on the south side of the 100 block east. 
(Code 1965, § 26-117) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 96. 
Sec. 25-144. - Parking or standing in alleys. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to block the free passage of other vehicles in such alley. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of (a) above, it shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in any alley within the fire limits of the city, except when such vehicle is actually being used for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
(Code 1965, § 26-118) 
Sec. 25-145. - Parking for more than forty-eight hours prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to allow, cause or permit such vehicle to remain standing or parked on any street, alley, avenue or public way within the city for more than forty-eight (48) hours continuously. 
(Code 1965, § 26-119) 
Sec. 25-146. - Parking in time-limited spaces. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle, or to permit a vehicle under his control to stand unattended, in the following parking spaces, on the following roadways, streets, or highways, for a period of more than two (2) consecutive hours. This time limitation shall apply between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, inclusive, except for any and all legal holidays. 
Burnett Avenue -All spaces on both sides of the street in the 100 and 200 blocks south and in the 100 block north. 
Chestnut Street -All spaces on both sides of the street in the 200, 300, and 400 blocks west. 
Chestnut Street -All spaces on the south side of the street in the 500 block west. 
Chestnut Street -Two (2) spaces on the north side of the street in the 100 block west, between Houston Avenue and police department parking lot. 
Chestnut Street- Two (2) spaces on the south side of the street in the 100 block west, beginning one hundred eighteen (118) feet west of the southwest corner of Houston and Chestnut for a distance of eighty (80) feet. 
Fannin Avenue -All spaces on the east side of the street in the 200 block south that are north of the alley. 
Gandy Street -All spaces on the south side of the street in the 300 block west from the west curbline of Rusk Avenue to a point two hundred twenty-six (226) feet west of the west curbline of Rusk Avenue. 
Houston Avenue -All spaces on the east side of the 100 block south. 
Houston Avenue -All spaces on the east side of the 100 block north, except the two (2) northernmost angle parking stalls. 
Houston Avenue -All spaces north of the alley on the west side of the 100 block north. 
Houston Avenue -Three (3) spaces on the west side of the street in the 100 block south, between the alley and the Chestnut Street intersection. 
Main Street -All spaces on the north side of the 100 block east, from the east curbline of Houston Avenue to a point two hundred seventy (270) feet east of the east curbline of Houston Avenue. 
Main Street -All spaces on both sides of the street in the 200, 300, 400, 500, and 600 blocks west. 
Main Street -All spaces on the south side of the street in the 700 block west. 
Main Street -All spaces on both sides of the street in the 100 block west except the two (2) spaces designated in (b) below as being limited to fifteen (15) minutes, and except for the easternmost twelve (12) spaces on the north side of the street. 
Mirick Avenue -All spaces on both sides of the street in the 100 block south that are north of the alley, and in the 100 block north that are south of the alley. 
Rusk Avenue -All spaces on both sides of the street in the 100 block south and in the 100 block north. 
Rusk Avenue -All spaces on the west side of the street in the 200 block north. 
Woodard Street -All spaces on the south side of the street in the 100 block west. 
Woodard Street -All spaces on the south side of the 100 block east. 
Woodard Street -All spaces on both sides of the street in the 200 and 300 blocks west. 
Woodard Street -One (1) space on the north side of the street in the 500 block west, at 515 West Woodard, from a point that is one hundred sixty-five (165) feet west of the west curb on Fannin Avenue to a point that is one hundred seventy-six (176) feet west of the west curb of Fannin Avenue. 
Woodard Street -Four (4) spaces on the north side of the street in the 500 block west, at 525 West Woodard, from a point one hundred twenty (120) feet east of the east curb of Mirick Avenue to a point that is one hundred sixty-eight (168) feet east of the east curb of Mirick Avenue. 
Woodard Street -Twelve (12) spaces on the north side of the street in the 400 block west, from the Burnett Avenue Intersection. 
Woodard Street -All spaces on the north side of the street in the 100 block west, and those spaces on the south side of the street form its intersection with Austin Avenue to a point one hundred forty-four (144) feet west of the Houston Street right-of-way line. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful, and an offense, for any person to park a vehicle under his control to stand unattended, in the following parking spaces, on the following streets, roadways, or highways, for a period of more than fifteen (15) consecutive minutes. This time limitation shall apply between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday, inclusive, except for any and all legal holidays. 
Main Street -Two (2) spaces on the south side of the street in the 100 block west, in front of City Hall, from a point sixty-four (64) feet west of the west curb of Houston Avenue to a point seventy-five (75) feet west of the west curb of Houston Avenue to a point one hundred sixty-seven (167) feet west of the west curb of Houston Avenue. 
Rusk Avenue -All spaces on the east side of the street, by the post office, in the 200 block north, that are south of the alley. 
(c)  Each period, or portion thereof, in excess of the time limits established by this section shall be considered a separate offense. 
(d)  The city manager is hereby directed to have suitable signs erected, and/or to have suitable curb markings painted, to designate the parking spaces established by this section. 
(e)  Any and all violators of the provisions of this section shall be subjected to a fine of two dollars ($2.00) for each separate offense. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person, in any manner, to attempt to evade the provisions of this section by the movement of his vehicle to another space, by destroying the signs or marks designating the parking spaces, or in any other manner. Any person who attempts to evade the provisions of this section in violation of this subsection shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) or more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Code 1965, § 26-119.1; Ord. No. 3166, § 1, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 3167, § 1, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 3197, § 1, 1-15-90) 
Sec. 25-147. - Parking during specified hours only. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle, or to permit a vehicle under his control to stand unattended, in the following locations between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday: 
(1)  On the east side of the 1900 block of South Mirick, from the traffic signal at the intersection of Mirick Avenue and Yellow Jacket Drive, north a distance of nine hundred twenty (920) feet to the intersection of Mirick Avenue with Brock Street; 
(2)  On the west side of the 1900 block of South Mirick, from the traffic signal light at the intersection of Mirick Avenue and Yellow Jacket Drive, north a distance of eight hundred eighty (880) feet from Yellow Jacket Drive to the north entrance to the Denison High School parking lot, plus an additional thirty-three (33) feet north of the signal light. 
(b)  The city manager is hereby directed to have suitable signs erected and/or to have suitable curb markings painted to designate the parking regulations established by this section. 
(c)  Any and all violators of the provisions of this section shall be subjected to a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Code 1965, § 26-119.2; Ord. No. 3179, § 1, 10-2-89) 
Sec. 25-148. - Loading and unloading generally. 
    All freight trucks shall be, and are hereby required, to be loaded and unloaded from the alley entrance, if practicable. Where conditions are such as to make the loading or unloading thereof from an alley impracticable, such trucks shall be parked on the street in accord with all applicable provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 26-120) 
Sec. 25-149. - Permit to back to curb for loading or unloading. 
    The chief of police is authorized to issue special permits to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privileges as therein stated and authorized herein, and it shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(Code 1965, § 26-121) 
Sec. 25-150. - Loading zones. 
(a)  Loading zones shall be granted only by resolution of the city council on application of the owner or occupant of property abutting the street where such loading zone is requested and then only where the following conditions exist: 
(1)  A store or business having no alley entrance and the loading requirements for such cannot properly be met from the street during times other than usual business hours; and 
(2)  Regularly and frequently used service trucks exceed the number of alley parking places available behind the business. 
(b)  Application for designation of loading zones shall be made in writing and filed with the city secretary for consideration by the city council at a regular meeting. The applicant shall assume responsibility for providing factual information showing that one (1) or more conditions set forth in (a) above exist in support of such application. 
(c)  No loading zone shall be approved for the singular use of one (1) business, although it may be located because of the needs of one (1) store or business falling within the provisions of (a) above, but it shall not be deemed established for the exclusive use of any one (1) store or business. 
(d)  No vehicle shall be parked in a loading zone except for the purpose of loading and unloading and such parking shall be limited to the time reasonably necessary for that purpose; provided however, that bona fide service or delivery vehicles falling within the category mentioned in (a)(2) above shall be permitted to park in a loading zone by its place of business while waiting to make service calls. 
(e)  Vehicles not conspicuously marked to indicate their use as service and delivery vehicles shall be required to have a card approximately six (6) inches by eleven (11) inches in size placed in the right corner of the front windshield while parked in a loading zone indicating the vehicle is a service or delivery vehicle with the firm name placed thereon. 
(f)  Those areas outside of normal vehicle traffic lane, between intersections in the 200, 300, and 400 blocks West Main Street, shall be considered as passenger loading and unloading zones. Vehicles, including taxicabs shall be authorized to use these areas for all passenger loading and unloading providing that the stopped vehicle does not interfere with normal traffic flow and that vehicle does not remain stopped more than is necessary to load or unload passengers. 
(Code 1965, § 26-122; Ord. No. 4701, § 18(f), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 25-151. - Impoundment of standing or parked vehicles. 
    Any vehicle which shall be or remain standing or parked upon any public street, avenue, way, alley or other public place, may be removed by or upon order of the city manager or the chief of police, and placed in storage in a privately operated garage or other place designated by or maintained by the city, under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When any vehicle is found upon a street, avenue, alley, way, or public place and a report has been previously made that such vehicle has been stolen or complaint has been filed and a warrant issued thereon, charging that such vehicle has been stolen or converted in violation of law. 
(2)  When a police officer arrests any person driving or in control of a vehicle for an alleged offense and such officer is or may be required by law to take the one arrested immediately before a magistrate, or if the arrested one is immediately taken before a magistrate, and when the arrested one is the sole occupant or the owner of the vehicle and is immediately placed in custody. 
(3)  When a vehicle is so disabled that its normal operation is impossible or impractical and the persons in charge of the vehicle are incapacitated by reason of physical injury or other causes to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its removal or custody, or cannot be found or are not in the immediate vicinity of such vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 26-123) 
State Law reference- Removal of illegally parked vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 94. 
Sec. 25-152. - Presumption that owner of vehicle illegally parked same. 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any ordinance or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such ordinance or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(Code 1965, § 26-124) 
Sec. 25-153. - Parkway parking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand or park a motor vehicle on the parkway of any right-of-way owned by the State of Texas and managed by the state department of transportation situated within the corporate limits. 
    For the purpose of this section, the term "parkway" shall be defined as the portion of the right-of-way situated outside of the area improved for vehicular travel including, but not limited to, the area between the back of the curb and the right-of-way line, or the shoulder of the roadway and the right-of-way line. 
(Ord. No. 3844, § 1, 1-19-99) 
Secs. 25-154-25-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PEDESTRIANS 

Sec. 25-176. - Application of article. 
    Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic-control signals as provided in this chapter, but at all other places pedestrians shall be granted those rights and be subject to the restrictions stated in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 26-151) 
Sec. 25-177. - Right-of-way in crosswalks. 
(a)  When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk, when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger, but no pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle, which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
(b)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 26-152) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 49. 
Sec. 25-178. - Use of crosswalks; crossing between crosswalks; crossing at other than crosswalks. 
(a)  All crossings by any pedestrian at any intersection or street crosswalk which is plainly marked, shall be made within crosswalks of such intersection or street. 
(b)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway, street or highway at any point other than within a plainly marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon such roadway, street or highway approaching such place of crossing and in proximity thereto. It shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cause any interference with the movement of any vehicle by reason of such crossing at such place. 
(Code 1965, § 26-153) 
Sec. 25-179. - Roadway to be crossed at right angles; exception. 
    No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb, except in a crosswalk. 
(Code 1965, § 26-154) 
Sec. 25-180. - Walking on roadways. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a street or highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. 
(Code 1965, § 26-155) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 81. 
Sec. 25-181. - Hitchhikers not to stand in roadway. 
    No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 26-156) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 81. 
Sec. 25-182. - Duty of drivers with regard to pedestrians. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this article, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Code 1965, § 26-157) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 79. 
Sec. 25-183. - Solicitations at street intersections. 
(a)  General. Notwithstanding any other provisions of the city's Code of Ordinances and except as permitted by state law, a person eighteen (18) years of age or older may solicit contributions while standing on a traffic median, shoulder, improved shoulder, sidewalk, or the improved portion of the roadway from occupants of any vehicle on a roadway, street or thoroughfare under the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  All solicitors must be eighteen (18) years of age or older; 
(2)  No solicitor may block any intersection of streets, or to do any act which impedes traffic at or near an intersection of streets; 
(3)  All solicitors must enter or remain in a roadway, street or thoroughfare only while the controlling traffic signal prohibits vehicular movement; 
(4)  All solicitors must remain within one hundred (100) feet of or from the intersection approved under a permit issued by the city; 
(5)  No person may solicit without the required insurance coverage as outlined in subsection (d) of this section; 
(6)  All solicitors must wear a city-approved florescent orange or yellow vest at all times while soliciting; 
(7)  No person may solicit until: 
a.  A sign approved by the city is posted, no less than five hundred (500) feet from the intersection, in the right parkway for each approaching lane of traffic up to two (2) lanes wide; or 
b.  Two (2) signs approved by the city are posted, no less than five hundred (500) feet from the intersection, in both the left and right-side parkway of approaching lanes of traffic of three (3) or more lanes. 
(8)  No person may solicit until a permit is issued from the city per the terms of this section. 
(b)  Signs and vests. Prior to the issuance of a permit, applicant must obtain approval from the city of all signs and vests to be used by the solicitors. All signs must be removed from each intersection at the end of each day of the permit period. Signs shall not block or impede traffic at or near any intersection. 
(c)  Permits. 
(1)  Each person or organization, whose application meets the requirements of this section, may be issued one (1) permit per calendar year at no charge, for no more than two (2) specified days. Each permit shall allow solicitation only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and one (1) hour before sunset, as determined by the official newspaper or a paper of general circulation in the city. 
(2)  Only one (1) permit will be issued for an intersection on any given day. Permits will be issued on a first come basis to those applicants who submit a completed application form, required certificate of insurance and approval by the city of the signs and vests to be used by the solicitors. 
(3)  The application for a solicitation permit shall state the name, mailing address and telephone number of the person or organization registering to solicit and the location(s) and times the solicitation will take place. 
(4)  Permit applications must be accompanied by a certificate of insurance as outlined in subsection (d) of this section. 
(5)  The city manager or his or her designee shall review the application and issue a permit to a person or organization whose application meets the requirements of this section. 
(d)  Insurance. The certificate of insurance must be signed by an agent authorized to bind coverage and indicate that the applicant has obtained, at his or her sole expense, the following insurance coverage: 
(1)  That is written by an insurance company with an A- or better rating by AM Best and that is admitted or approved to do business in the State of Texas; 
(2)  That is in full force and effect for the duration of the permit period; 
(3)  That provides one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) of liability coverage per occurrence with no deductible; 
(4)  That insures the applicant and all persons who will be soliciting; 
(5)  That names the City of Denison, its officers, agents, employees and elected representatives as an additional insured; 
(6)  That provides that any insurance maintained by the city shall apply in excess of and not contribute with it; 
(7)  That is written on an occurrence basis; and 
(8)  That is otherwise acceptable to and approved by the City of Denison. 
(e)  Restricted hours in Downtown Entertainment District. No person shall engage in the acts set forth in this section at any time within one thousand (1,000) feet (measured to and from the nearest corner of the intersecting street, highway, roadway, measured along the curb, shoulder, improved shoulder) of the intersections within the Downtown Entertainment District as defined in section 21-121 of the Code of Ordinances during the hours of 5:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m. 
(f)  Offense. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person: 
a.  To engage in activity described in this section without first obtaining a permit pursuant to the provisions of this section; 
b.  To block any intersection of streets, or to do any act which impedes traffic at or near an intersection of streets; 
c.  To enter or remain in a roadway, street or thoroughfare when the controlling traffic signal allows vehicular movement; or 
d.  To violate any other provision of this section. 
(2)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (f)(1) that the person impeding a roadway, as defined by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 552.0071(g) is authorized to do so under an authorization issued by the City as required by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 552.0071(a). 
(g)  Penalty. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). A culpable mental state is not required, and need not be proved, for an offense under this section. 
(Ord. No. 3377, § 1, 4-19-93; Ord. No. 4928, § 2(2.01), 2-5-18) 
Sec. 25-184. - Aggressive solicitation. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section: 
    Aggressive manner , aggressive behavior or aggressively . As related to soliciting, begging and panhandling means: 
a.  Using violent or threatening gestures toward a person solicited; 
b.  Continuing to solicit from a person after the person has given a negative response to such soliciting; 
c.  Intentionally touching or causing physical contact with another person without that person's consent in the course of soliciting; 
d.  Intentionally blocking or interfering with the safe or free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle by any means, including causing a pedestrian or vehicle operator to take evasive action to avoid physical contact; 
e.  Soliciting money from anyone who is waiting in line for tickets, for entry to a building or for any other purpose; 
f.  Approaching or following a person for solicitation individually or as part of a group of two (2) or more persons, in a manner and with conduct, words, or gestures intended or likely to cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or damage to or loss of property or otherwise to be harassed or intimidated into giving money or other thing of value; or 
g.  Soliciting, begging or panhandling of minors less than sixteen (16) years of age. 
    Automated teller machine. A device, linked to a bank or financial institution's account records, which is able to carry out transactions, including, but not limited to: account transfers, deposits, cash withdrawals, balance inquiries, and mortgage and loan payments which are made available to banking customers. 
    Bank. A bank, savings bank, savings and loan association, credit union, trust company, or similar financial institution. 
    Check cashing business. An entity in the business of cashing checks, drafts, or money orders for consideration. 
    Parking meter or parking pay station. A location on a street, parking lot or parking garage where persons pay, for parking by either cash or credit, to a person or at a machine or other device designed to accept payment for parking. 
    Private building. Shall be deemed to include, but is not limited to, retail or service establishments, such as restaurants, convenience food stores, laundromats, service stations, hotels, offices, and similar privately-owned establishments open to the public. This term does not include any building owned, leased or operated by the federal or state government, political subdivisions thereof, municipalities, special districts, any public administration board or authority of the state. 
    Public area. An area to which the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, the common area of a hospital, apartment house, office building, transport facility, shop, basement, building entrance or doorway, lobby, hallway, stairway, mezzanine, elevator, foyer, public restroom or sitting room or any other place used in common by the public, tenants, occupants or guests situated in any private building. 
    Public place. A place to which a governmental entity has title to which the public has access, including, but not limited to: any street, highway, sidewalk, walkway, parking lot, plaza, transportation facility, school, place of amusement, park, or playground. 
    Solicit, ask, beg or panhandle. To request, by the spoken, written, or printed word, or by other means of communication an immediate donation or transfer of money or another thing of value from another person, regardless of the solicitor's purpose or intended use of the money or other thing of value, and regardless of whether consideration is offered. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if the person solicits: 
(1)  In an aggressive manner in a public area or public place; or 
(2)  Within twenty (20) feet of the following areas where the public is considered vulnerable or where solicitation would interfere with the flow of pedestrian or motor vehicle traffic: 
a.  An automated teller machine; 
b.  The entrance or exit of a bank; 
c.  The entrance or exit of a check cashing business; 
d.  An authorized charitable contribution activity; 
e.  A parking meter or parking pay station on a street; 
f.  A public parking garage or parking lot pay station; 
g.  The entrance or exit of a restaurant or the service area of an outdoor eating establishment; 
h.  In a bus, at a bus station or stop, or at a facility operated by a transportation authority for passengers including but not limited to any school bus stop; 
i.  A marked crosswalk; or 
j.  An entrance of a commercial or government building. 
(3)  Within five (5) feet of a curb or edge of a street; 
(4)  Within fifty (50) feet from any land owned by a public or private school and used in whole or in part for providing education services to elementary age children; 
(5)  Within ten (10) feet of a gas station, liquor store, or convenience store property; 
(6)  In a public restroom; or 
(7)  At a public event that is operating by permit issued by the city at city parks as defined in the city's Code of Ordinances; 
(c)  Private property. 
(1)  No person may solicit, ask, beg or panhandle on private property or residential property without permission from the owner or occupant. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
a.  Solicit, ask, beg or panhandle, as those terms are defined in this chapter, in any public room in any private building, without the written permission or consent of the building's owner or managing and authorizing agent. For the purpose of enforcement of this subsection, it is presumed that if the owner, lessee, managing agent or other person in charge of a building prominently displays a sign as provided in subsection (c), then the activities declared unlawful in this section are deemed to be without the permission or consent of the building's owner, lessee, managing agent or other person. 
b.  Solicit, ask, beg or panhandle, as those terms are defined in this chapter, on any private property where the owner, lessee, managing agent or other person in charge of such property displays a sign as provided in subsection (c). 
c.  Conspicuous notice. To invoke the protections afforded under this section, each owner, lessee, managing agent or person in charge of the operation of a private building or private property shall prominently display a sign on the premises, such as the lobby or entrance of the private building or private property, where it may be read by any person going in or out of the building or private developed property stating generally: "NO PANHANDLING PERMITTED SEC. 25-184, CODE OF ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF DENISON", "NO SOLICITORS" or "NO SOLICITATION." 
(d)  For purposes of subsection (b) in this section, measurement shall be made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest point at which an unlawful act is conducted to the nearest portion to the items listed in subsection (b). 
(e)  The solicitation of contributions while standing on a traffic median, shoulder, improved shoulder, sidewalk, or the improved portion of the roadway from occupants of any vehicle on a roadway, street or thoroughfare shall only be permitted in compliance with the terms and conditions set out in section 25-183, "solicitation at street intersections" of the city's Code of Ordinances, provided they are not in an aggressive manner as defined in this section. 
(f)  Any person who engages in any activity specified in subsection (b), maybe subject to prosecution for a Class C misdemeanor and a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). A culpable mental state is not required, and need not be proved, for an offense under this section. 
(Ord. No. 4928, § 2(2.02), 2-5-18) 
Secs. 25-185-25-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - RAILROADS 

Sec. 25-201. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 3700, adopted Feb. 17, 1997, repealed § 25-201, which pertained to railroad speed limits and derived from the 1965 Code, § 22-1. 
Sec. 25-202. - Obstructing crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any engineer, conductor or other person to, in this city, stop, or cause to be stopped, any railway engine or car across any street, alley, road or highway, so as to obstruct or interfere with the free passage thereon, for a longer time than five (5) minutes at a time. 
(Code 1965, § 22-2) 
Sec. 25-203. - Boarding or alighting from or clinging to moving train. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in this city to jump on or off, or cling to or hang on any railway engine or car, while the same is in motion, such person not being a regular passenger on or employee or official of the railroad company. 
(Code 1965, § 22-3) 
Sec. 25-204. - Maintenance of roadbeds, tracks, culverts, switches and drainage. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every railroad which has a track in the city to keep its roadbeds, culverts, switches and drainage in good repair. 
(b)  Wherever the track of any railroad crosses a street or alley in this city the top of the rail shall be even with the surface of the street or alley for the full width of such street or alley, and the street crossing shall be fixed by the railroad company's agent. The same rule shall be observed where there are switches in the streets. 
(c)  Where gutters or culverts are maintained by a railroad, the same shall be so constructed or covered up as not to interfere with free passage and convenient travel along the street or alley, and so as not to convey water into any street or lot in the city. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the station agent or representative of any railroad having a track in this city to see that the requirements of this article are complied with, and in case of failure to comply, or of any violation of this article, the agent shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 22-4)

ARTICLE II. - SEWER USE, WASTEWATER AND STORMWATER DISPOSAL[2] 
Footnotes:

II, Divs. 1-5, pertaining to sewer use and wastewater disposal, and § 3 of said ordinance enacted a new Art. II in lieu thereof to read as set out herein. The provisions of former Art. II derived from Ord. No. 3187, § 3, adopted Dec. 18, 1989. Prior to amendment by Ord. No. 3187, Art II derived from Code 1965, §§ 27-1-27-6, and Ord. No. 3091, § 1, adopted Aug. 15, 1988. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-26. - Definitions and abbreviations. 
(a)  Definitions. Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the following terms and phrases, as used in this article shall have the meanings hereinafter designated: 
(1)  Act or "the Act": The Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended (33 U.S.C. 1251, et seq.). 
(2)  Amenable to treatment: A substance that is susceptible to reduction in concentration by the treatment normally provided by the city's receiving wastewater treatment plant to a level that is in compliance with federal and state effluent limitations for discharge to the waters of the state. 
(3)  Approval authority: the director in an NPDES state with an approved state pretreatment program and the appropriate regional administrator in a non-NPDES state or NPDES state without an approved state pretreatment program. 
(4)  (a)  Authorized official of the city: The city manager, who is held responsible for administrative and enforcement procedures by the city council, and the city manager's properly indentified subordinate employees who hold positions of responsibility directly related to wastewater activities of the city, to include, but not to be limited to, the director of public works, city engineer, wastewater treatment superintendent, environmental service officers, and any assistants or others performing similar duties, as the case may be.
