(b)  Authorized representative of industrial (non-domestic) user: An authorized representative of an industrial (non-domestic) user may be: (1) A principal executive officer of at least the level of vice-president, if the user is a corporation; (2) a general partner or proprietor if the User is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; (3) a duly authorized representative of the individual designated above if such representative is designated in writing as being responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the discharge to the public sewage collection and treatment system originates, and the city is notified in writing of the designation. 
(5)  BOD: (Biochemical oxygen demand) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
(6)  Building sewer: A privately-owned sewer conveying wastewater from the premises of a user to the publicly-owned sanitary sewer. 
(7)  Categorical standards: See National Categorical Pretreatment Standards. 
(8)  City: The City of Denison, Texas; or the City Council of Denison, Texas; or any authorized person acting in its behalf. 
(9)  COD: (Chemical oxygen demand) is the measure of the oxygen consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in the water or waste-water, expressed in milligrams per liter, as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specific test, but not differentiating between stable and unstable organic matter, and thus not necessarily correlating with biochemical oxygen demand. 
(10)  Composite sample: A sample of the wastewater discharged to the collection system by a user and composed of a series of not less than three (3) samples taken during the periods when industrial wastes are being discharged. The period of time over which the samples are collected for compositing into a single sample shall not exceed twenty-four (24) hours. The series of samples may be collected on a time-proportional or flow-proportional basis. Additional procedures for composite sampling are described in 40 CFR Part 403 Appendix E. 
(11)  Control authority: POTW representative(s) responsible to the city council for administration and enforcement of an EPA approved pretreatment program. 
(12)  Control point: A point of access to a building sewer before the discharge mixes with other discharges in a public sewer. 
(13)  Cooling water: The water discharged from any use, such as air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration, to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
(14)  Direct discharge: The discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the State of Texas. 
(15)  Environmental Protection Agency, or EPA: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. Where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for the Administrator or other duly authorized official of said agency. 
(16)  O&G: Oil and greases, whether emulsified or not, normally expressed as a concentration in milligrams per liter, as determined by standard laboratory tests. O&G is used to define wastes from animal, vegetable, petroleum and mineral-based oil origins. 
(17)  Floatable oil: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate or stratify by gravity from wastewater in the city's collection system or the receiving treatment facility. 
(18)  Garbage: Animal and vegetable wastes and residue resulting from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and resulting from the handling, processing, storage and sale of food products and produce. 
(19)  Grab sample: A sample which is taken from a waste stream on a one-time basis with no regard to the flow in the waste stream, collected over a period of time not exceeding fifteen (15) minutes. 
(20)  Grease: Fatty acids, soaps, fats, waxes, petroleum products, oil, and any other material which is extractable by hexane or freon solvent from an acidified sample, and which is not volatilized during evaporation of the solvent. 
(21)  Grease trap: A device by which the grease content of sewage may be cooled and congealed so that it may be skimmed from the surface. 
(22)  Holding tank waste: Any waste from a containment device, such as those commonly used in conjunction with vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, septic tanks, and vacuum-pump tank trucks. 
(23)  Indirect discharge: Means the introduction of pollutants into a POTW from any nondomestic source regulated under section 307(b), (c) or (d) of the Act. 
(24)  Industrial user or user: a source of indirect discharge. 
(25)  Industrial waste surcharge: An additional charge made against industrial (non-domestic) users who discharge wastes to the public sewers that are amenable to treatment, but which exceed the concentration levels of normal domestic wastewater. 
(26)  Interference: A discharge by an industrial user which, alone or in conjunction with discharges by other sources, inhibits or disrupts the city's sewage collection and treatment system, its treatment processes or operations, or its sludge processes, use, or disposal, and which is a cause of violation of any requirement of the city's sewage collection and treatment system NPDES permit (including an increase in the magnitude of duration of a violation) or of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the city's sewage collection and treatment system in accordance with the following statutory provisions and regulations or permits issued thereunder (or more stringent State or local regulations): Section 405 of the Clean Water Act, the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA) (including Title II, more commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), and including State regulations contained in any State sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Subtitle D of the SWDA), the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substance Control Act, and the Marine Protection Research and Sanctuaries Act. 
(27)  Milligrams Per Liter (mg/L): Essentially equivalent to "parts per million;" a weight-to-volume ratio commonly used to express concentrations of substances in wastewater; milligrams-per-liter are multiplied by the factor 8.34 to convert to pounds per million gallons. 
(28)  Minor industrial user: A non-domestic user whose discharge contains pollutant concentrations greater than normal domestic wastewater, but who does not otherwise qualify as a significant industrial user. 
(29)  National categorical pretreatment standard or pretreatment standard: Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Act, (33 USC 1317) which applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
(30)  National prohibitive discharge standard or prohibitive discharge standard: Any regulation developed under the authority of 307(b) of the Act and 40 CFR, Section 403.5, to regulate or prohibit discharge of toxic pollutants. 
(31)  National pollution discharge eliminations system (NPDES) permit: A permit issued pursuant to Section 402 of the Act (33 USC 1342) which regulates discharges to "Waters of the State." 
(32)  Natural outlet: Any outlet, including storm sewers and combination storm/sanitary sewer overflows, through which a discharge is routed into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
(33)  New source: Any building, structure, facility, or installation meeting the definition of 40 CFR Part 403.3(k) 
(34)  Normal domestic wastewater: Wastewater, normally discharged into sanitary sewers from households and industrial sanitary conveniences, in which the average concentration of total suspended solids is not more than 250 mg/L, of BOD is not more than 250 mg/L, and of O&G is not more than 150 mg/L, and which contains no other prohibited or toxic constituents in concentrations greater than the levels allowed by this Article. 
(35)  Overload: The imposition of organic or hydraulic loading of a treatment facility in excess of its engineered average daily design capacity. 
(36)  pH: The logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions expressed in grams per liter of solution. 
(37)  Pass-through: A discharge which exits the POTW into waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the POTW's NPDES permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation). 
(38)  Person: Any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. The masculine gender shall include the feminine, and the singular shall include the plural, where indicated by the context. 
(39)  Pollutant: Any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, or industrial, municipal, or agricultural waste discharged into water. 
(40)  Pollution: The man-made or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological, and radiological composition of water. 
(41)  Pretreatment: The reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to and in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a POTW. The reduction or alteration may be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes; process changes or by other means, except as prohibited by section 403.6(d). Appropriate pretreatment technology includes control equipment, such as equalization tanks or facilities, for protection against surges or slug loadings that might interfere with or otherwise be incompatible with the POTW. However, where wastewater from a regulated process is mixed in an equalization facility with unregulated wastewater or with wastewater from another regulated process, the effluent from the equalization facility must meet an adjusted pretreatment limit calculated in accordance with section 403.6(e). 
(42)  Pretreatment requirements: Any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment, other than a national categorical pretreatment standard imposed on an industrial user. 
(43)  Publicly owned treatment works (POTW): A treatment works, as defined by Section 212 of the Act, (33 USC 1292), which is owned by the city. This definition includes any sewers that convey wastewater to the treatment plant, but does not include pipes, sewers or other conveyances not connected to a facility providing treatment. For the purposes of this ordinance, "POTW" shall also include any sewers that convey wastewaters to the city's sewage collection and treatment system from persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city's sewage collection and treatment system. This definition also includes any public sludge disposal sites or public sludge handling or treatment structures or equipment. 
(44)  POTW treatment plant: That portion of the public sewage collection and treatment system designed to provide treatment to wastewater and/or the resulting sludges. 
(45)  Sanitary sewer: A publicly owned pipe or other closed conduit that transports waterborne wastes from the building sewers of residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with quantities of ground, storm, and surface water that are not admitted intentionally. 
(46)  Shall: Is mandatory: May: is permissive. 
(47)  Significant industrial user: All industrial users subject to Categorical Pretreatment Standards under 40 CFR 403.6 and 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N; and any other industrial user that: discharges an average of 25,000 gallons per day or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, non-contact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater); contributes a process wastestream which makes up five (5) percent or more of the average number dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant; or is designated as such by the control authority as defined in 40 CFR 403.12 (a) on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement (in accordance with 40 CFR 403.8 (f)(6). 
(48)  Slugload: Any substance released in a discharge at a rate and/or concentration which causes interference to a POTW. 
(49)  Standard Industrial Classification (SIC): A classification pursuant to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual issued by the Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget. 
(50)  State: State of Texas, including any duly-authorized agency thereof having jurisdiction over waters of the state, sewage collection or treatment, or municipal sewage sludge disposal. 
(51)  Storm sewer: A publicly-owned pipe, improved watercourse, or other conduit intended to transport the runoff resulting from precipitation, or to transport other drainage from natural groundwater or surface waters, and into which domestic wastewater or industrial wastes are not intentionally introduced. 
(52)  Storm water: Storm water runoff, snow melt runoff, and surface runoff and drainage. 
(53)  Superintendent: The person designated, directly or indirectly, by the city manager to supervise the operation of the publicly-owned sewage collection and treatment works, and who is charged with certain duties and responsibilities by this article, or his duly authorized representative. 
(54)  Total suspended solids (TSS): The total amount of matter that floats on the surface of, or is suspended in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and which is removable by the approved laboratory filtering method described in 40 CFR, Part 136. 
(55)  Toxic pollutant: Any pollutant or combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency under the provisions of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, Section 307(a), or other Acts, or as specifically identified by the city as being toxic to any wastewater treatment or sludge management processes used by the city. 
(56)  Unpolluted water or waste: Any water or liquid waste containing none of the following: Phenols or other substances to an extent imparting taste and odor in receiving waters; toxic or poisonous substances in suspension colloidal state or solution; noxious or odorous gases; not more than ten thousand (10,000) parts per million, by weight, of dissolved solids, of which not more than twenty-five hundred (2,500) parts per million are chloride; not more than ten (10) parts per million each of suspended solids and BOD, color not exceeding fifty (50) color units, nor a pH value of less than 5.5 nor higher than 10.0; and/or any water or waste approved for discharge into a stream or waterway by the appropriate state authority. 
(57)  Reserved. 
(58)  Wastewater: The waterborne industrial or domestic wastes from dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial facilities, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, or storm water that may be present, whether treated or untreated, which is contributed into or permitted to enter the city's sewage collection and treatment system. This term is generally considered synonymous with "sewage," "sanitary sewage," "sanitary wastes," or "liquid wastes." 
(59)  Wastewater facilities: The structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, transport, and treat domestic, commercial, and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent and resulting sludge. Generally synonymous with "POTW." 
(60)  Wastewater treatment works: An arrangement of devices and structures for treating and disposing of wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant," "water pollution control plant," or "sewage treatment plant." 
(61)  Waters of the state: The water of the ordinary flow, underflow, and tides of every flowing river, natural stream, and lake, and of every bay or arm of the Gulf of Mexico, and the stormwater, floodwater, and rainwater of every river, natural stream, canyon, ravine, depression, and watershed in the state. 
(62)  Wastewater discharge permit: A document granting certain users of the public sewage collection and treatment system permission to contribute wastewater to the system, and establishing conditions regulating the quantity and quality of the wastewater contributed. 
(63)  Work day: When used in conjunction with the determination of a significant industrial user, is any day, or portion thereof, when the user is providing any service, or producing its product or any part of its product line, or otherwise generating nondomestic wastewater that may be discharged to the public sewage collection and treatment system. All other use of this term shall mean any day a non-domestic wastewater discharge occurs. 
(b)  Abbreviations. The following abbreviations shall have the designated meanings: 
BOD-Biochemical oxygen demand 
CFR-Code of Federal Regulations 
COD-Chemical oxygen demand 
EPA-Environmental Protection Agency 
O&G-Oil and grease 
L-Liter 
NPDES-National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System 
POTW-Publicly owned treatment works 
SIC-Standard Industrial Classification 
SWDA-Solid Waste Disposal Act, 42 USC 6901, et seq. 
USC-United States Code 
TSS-Total suspended solids 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, § 1, 2-6-06; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(a), 6-17-13) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-27. - Purpose and policy. 
    This article sets forth uniform requirements for direct and indirect contributors into the wastewater collection and treatment system for the city. It is the intent of this article to comply with all applicable state and federal laws and regulations promulgated pursuant to the Clean Water Act of 1977 and the General Pretreatment Regulations (40 CFR, Part 403). The objectives of this article are: 
(a)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal wastewater system which will interfere with the operation of the system or contaminate the resulting sludge; 
(b)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the municipal wastewater system which will pass through the system, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or the atmosphere, or which will otherwise be incompatible with the system; 
(c)  To improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewaters and sludges from the system; and 
(d)  To provide an incentive for industrial users of the city's wastewater collection and treatment system to pretreat their wastes to domestic strength concentrations, and to discharge those wastes at a uniform, constant rate, thus enabling maximum effective use of the city's facilities. 
(e)  To provide for distribution of the cost of the municipal wastewater system. 
    This article provides for the regulation of direct and indirect contributors to the municipal wastewater system through the issuance of permits to certain nondomestic users and through enforcement of general requirements for the other users, authorizes monitoring and enforcement activities, requires user reporting, assumes that existing customer's capacity will not be preempted, and provides for the setting of fees for the distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. 
    This article shall apply to the city and to persons outside the city who are, by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city's wastewater collection and treatment system. Except as otherwise provided herein, the city manager or his responsible designee shall be responsible for administering, implementing, and enforcing the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-28. - Mandatory sewer connections. 
(a)  Every owner of a building or part hereof occupied by people for any purpose, any part of the day or night, anywhere within the city limits, where a public sewer capable of receiving gravity flow from such building exists within one hundred fifty (150) feet of the lot, tract, or acreage upon which the building is situated, shall have the same connected to the sewer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other private facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage or industrial wastes within the city limits except as allowed by this article. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-29. - Septic tank required in absence of sewer connection. 
    If any owner of a building is not required to connect with the sewer system, a suitable on-site treatment system approved by the local regulatory authority must be constructed on the premises. Such construction shall comply with section 5-821 et seq. of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(b), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(b) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-29 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-29 derived from Ord. No. 3551, § 3, adopted May 15, 1995. 
Sec. 26-30. - Improper connections to sewer. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any building or premises within this city to use, or to permit anyone else to use, any privy or water closet on such premises that is connected with the sewer system of the city, unless the same shall be used in connection with sufficient water flowing into the sewer to keep the pipes connecting such privies or water closets with the sewers free from obstruction. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-31. - Unlawful connections. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any direct or indirect physical connection that will lead to discharge into the public sanitary sewers of any: 
(1)  Unpolluted stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, or subsurface drainage; 
(2)  Other unpolluted drainage, including water from draining swimming pools. This does not prohibit the discharge of swimming pool filter backwash water to the sanitary sewers. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-32. - Authority to designate point of connection. 
(a)  In compliance with the Texas Water Code and other statutes, the city may designate storm sewers and other watercourses into which unpolluted waters described in section 26-31 may be discharged. 
(b)  Plans and specifications, sealed by a professional engineer registered in the state, and other pertinent information relating to proposed facilities for handling unpolluted waters, may be required to be submitted for the approval of the city. No construction of such facilities shall be commenced until such approvals, when required, are obtained in writing. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Secs. 26-33-26-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 26-46. - Suspension, termination of service for discharging harmful contributions or nonpayment. 
(a)  The city may suspend the water and/or wastewater service to a user, and/or a user's wastewater discharge permit, to stop an actual or threatened discharge which presents an imminent or substantial danger to the health or welfare of persons or to the environment; or which causes or may cause interference to the city's sewer collection and treatment system, or which causes, or may cause the city to violate any condition of its NPDES or state discharge permits. 
(b)  Any user notified by the city manager or his or her designee of a suspension of the wastewater treatment service and/or the wastewater discharge permit shall immediately (40 CFR Park 403.12 (f)) stop or eliminate its discharge, or that portion deemed to be in violation of this article. In the event of a failure of the user to comply including immediate severance of the sewer connection and/or water supply, to prevent or minimize damage to the city's sewage collection and treatment system, endangerment of any individuals, damage to the environment, or imminent violation of the city's NPDES or state discharge permit. A detailed written statement submitted by the user describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence shall be submitted to the city within five (5) days of the date of occurrence, as detailed under subsection 26-123(d). 
(c)  The city may also terminate water and/or wastewater service and/or disconnect any user from the water and/or wastewater system after delivery of written notice when the user: 
(1)  Has discharged wastewater that violates the terms of its wastewater discharge permit three (3) times in any twelve-month period and has received notice of such violations; or 
(2)  Fails to pay in full monthly bills for water and sanitary sewer service, including industrial wastewater surcharges, sampling costs, and bills for cleanup costs from spills, upsets or accidental discharges, and other allowable fees, forfeitures, or penalties imposed under the terms of this chapter when due; or 
(3)  Has repeated a discharge of prohibited wastewaters to public sewers without a wastewater discharge permit. 
(d)  The city shall restore water and/or wastewater service, and/or reinstate the suspended wastewater discharge permit upon proof of the elimination of the noncomplying discharge, and installation of adequate measures to prevent its recurrence. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(c), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-47. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  Any discharger may be subject to having its permit revoked in accordance with the procedures of this subsection for: 
(1)  Failure to factually report the wastewater constituents and characteristics of its discharge; 
(2)  Failure to report significant changes in operations, or in wastewater constituents and characteristics, including spills, upsets, and accidental discharges; 
(3)  Refusal of access to its premises for the purposes of inspection or monitoring; 
(4)  Not fulfilling the conditions of its permits or this article, or obeying any final judicial order with respect thereto. 
(5)  The third conviction of any other offense under this article within a twelve-month period (or, in the case of users outside the city limits, the third assessment of an administrative penalty in a twelve-month period); 
(b)  Notification of violation, administrative adjustment. Whenever the city finds that any discharger has engaged in conduct which justifies revocation of a wastewater discharge permit, pursuant to this section, the city shall serve or cause to be served upon such discharger a written notice, either by personal delivery or by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, stating that nature of the alleged violation. Within thirty (30) days of the date of receipt of the notice, the discharger shall respond in person or in writing to the city, advising of its position with respect to the allegations. Thereafter, the parties shall meet to ascertain the veracity of the allegations and where necessary, establish a plan for the satisfactory correction thereof. 
(c)  The city may order any user who is suspected of any of the violations listed in subsection (a), above, which have not been corrected by means of administrative adjustment, to show cause before the city council why his permit should not be revoked. A written notice shall be served on the user specifying the time and place of a hearing to be held by the city council regarding the violation, and the reasons why the action is to be taken, and directing the user to show cause before the city council why his permit should not be revoked. The notice of the hearing shall be served personally or by registered or certified mail (returned receipt requested) at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing. Service may be made on any agent, or authorized representative of the discharger. The proceedings at the hearing shall be considered by the city which shall then enter appropriate orders with respect to the alleged improper activities of the discharger. 
(d)  The city council may itself conduct the hearing and take the evidence, or may designate any of its members or any officer or employee of the city to: 
(1)  Issue in the name of the city council notices of hearings requesting the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of evidence relevant to any matter involved in such hearings; 
(2)  Take the evidence; 
(3)  Transmit a report of the evidence and hearing, including transcripts and other evidence, together with recommendations to the city council for action thereon. 
(e)  At any hearing held pursuant to this article, testimony taken must be under oath and recorded electronically. The transcript so recorded will be made available to any member of the public or any party to the hearing upon payment of the usual charges as may be promulgated by the city council from time to time. 
(f)  After the city council has reviewed the evidence, it may revoke the user's permit, or it may issue an order to the user responsible for the violation directing that, following a specified time period, the sewer service be discontinued unless adequate pretreatment or treatment facilities, devices or other related appurtenances shall have been installed, and that such facilities, devices or other related appurtenances shall be properly operated. Further orders and directives as are necessary and appropriate may be issued. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(d), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-48. - Other local enforcement procedures. 
(a)  An authorized official of the city shall serve upon any user found to be violating any of the provisions of this article or discharge permit conditions a written notice of violation stating the nature of the violation(s), and allowing not more than forty-five (45) days from the date of such notice for correction of the violation or, if correction is deemed by the city as impractical to achieve within the time specified, submittal by the user within twenty (20) days of the date of such notice, of a plan satisfactory to the city for correction of the violation(s). 
(b)  If any person discharges sewage, industrial wastes or other wastes into the city's wastewater disposal system contrary to the provisions of this article, federal or state pretreatment requirements, any permit issued by the city, or any order of the city, the city attorney may commence an action of appropriate legal and/or equitable relief, in a court of competent jurisdiction in any of the following instances: 
(1)  The user has received a notice of violation for violating the same provision of this article or of its discharge permit conditions three times in any twelve-month period; 
(2)  The user has failed, twice within any twelve-month period, to properly notify the city of a pretreatment facility upset, a process spill, or other accidental discharge of prohibited or restricted substances as required by section 26-123, whether or not such discharge caused the city's sewage collection and treatment system to violate the terms of its NPDES or state discharge permits. 
(3)  The user is a significant industrial user, and/or is subject to national categorical pretreatment standards, and meets any of the following federal criteria qualifying him as a "significantly violating major industrial user": 
(A)  Discharging a pollutant to the public sewage collection and treatment system that has caused an imminent endangerment to the health or welfare of persons and/or has presented an endangerment to the environment; or 
(B)  Causing any violation of the city's NPDES or state discharge permit, or impairing the use or disposal of the treatment work's sludge; or 
(C)  Violating either categorical standard or conventional pollutant effluent requirements set forth in this article or in discharge permit conditions in twenty (20) percent or more of the samples taken, either by the city, or as part of a self-reporting requirement, during any twelve-month period; or 
(D)  Not correcting a violation (i.e., returning to compliance) within the time specified in a Notice of Violation; or 
(E)  Failing to accurately report noncompliance with the provisions of this article; and especially with the conditions or provisions of a wastewater discharge permit. 
(F)  Failure to provide written response to any notice of violation within twenty (20) days from the date of said notice. 
(c)  In addition to any legal or administrative action taken by the city, the city shall, at least annually, cause to be published in the largest daily newspaper published in the city a list of all industrial users which, at anytime in the previous twelve (12) months, were in significant noncompliance with applicable pretreatment requirements. For the purposes of this provision, an industrial user is in significant noncompliance if its violation meets one (1) or more of the following criteria: 
(1)  Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined here as those in which sixty-six (66) percent or more of all of the measurements taken during a six-month period exceed (by any magnitude) the daily maximum limit or the average limit for the same pollutant parameter; 
(2)  Technical review criteria (TRC) violation, defined here as those in which thirty-three (33) percent or more of all of the measurements for each pollutant parameter taken during a six-month period equal or exceed the product of the daily maximum limit or the average limit multiplied by the applicable TRC (TRC=1.4 for BOD, TSS, fats, oil, and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except ph. 
(3)  Any other violation of a pretreatment effluent limit (daily maximum or longer-term average) that the control authority determines has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass through (including endangering the health of POTW personnel or the general public); 
(4)  Any discharge of a pollutant that has caused imminent endangerment to human health, welfare or to the environment or has resulted in the POTW's exercise of its emergency authority under 40 CFR Section 403.8(f)(1)(vi)(B) to halt or prevent such a discharge; 
(5)  Failure to meet, within ninety (90) days after the schedule date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a local control mechanism or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance; 
(6)  Failure to provide, within thirty (30) days after the due date, required reports such as baseline monitoring reports, ninety-day compliance reports, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; 
(7)  Failure to accurately report noncompliance; 
(8)  Any other violation or group of violations that the control authority determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
(d)  The degree and extent of violations of this chapter by an industrial user may be the basis for the exercise of professional judgment of the enforcement staff and the authorized official of the city, and of the prosecutorial discretion of the city's attorney. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, §§ 2, 3, 2-6-06) 
Sec. 26-49. - Other legal action. 
    Chapter 54 of the Local Government Code of the State of Texas reserves unto the cities their common law remedies for the abatement of nuisances, for the recovery of damages incurred, and such other authority as may be necessary to enforce all of its ordinances. If any person discharges wastewater, industrial wastes or other wastes into the city's wastewater collection and treatment system contrary to the provisions of this article, of federal and state pretreatment requirements, any permit issued by the city, or of any order of the city, the city attorney may commence and pursue an action for appropriate legal and/or equitable relief in any court of competent jurisdiction. Further, the city has and will require as a part of the agreement to extend water and sewer service into unincorporated areas, the contractual obligation of the User to abide by all of the terms and provisions of its water and wastewater ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-50. - Emergency suspension of service and discharge permits. 
    The city may, for good cause shown, suspend wastewater treatment service to the discharger's facility, when it appears to the city that an actual or threatened discharge presents or may present an imminent or substantial danger to the health or welfare of persons, substantial danger to the environment, interfere with the operation of the POTW, violates any pretreatment limits imposed by this article or any wastewater discharge permit issued pursuant to this article. Any discharger notified of the suspension of the city's wastewater treatment service and/or the discharger's wastewater discharge permit, shall within a reasonable period of time, as determined by the city, cease all discharges. In the event of the failure of discharger to comply voluntarily with the suspension order within the specified time, the city may commence judicial proceedings to compel the discharger's compliance with such order or may immediately disconnect such discharger's service line from the city water and/or sanitary sewer system. In the case of emergency disconnection of service, the director shall make reasonable attempt to notify the occupant or user of the premises where such illegal discharge is generated before disconnecting the service line, and the party whose service has been disconnected shall have an opportunity for a hearing on the issue of the illegal discharge and the disconnection as soon as possible after such disconnection has taken place. The city may reinstate the wastewater discharge permit and/or the wastewater or water service upon proof by the discharge of the cessation of the noncomplying discharge or elimination of conditions creating the threat of imminent or substantial danger as set forth above. The city water and/or wastewater service shall only be reconnected at the discharger's expense. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-51. - Operating upsets. 
    Any discharger which experiences an upset in operations which places the discharger in a temporary state of non-compliance with this Ordinance shall inform the city thereof immediately (40 CFR Part 403.12(f)) of the commencement of the upset. Upset conditions include "bypass" which EPA defines as the "intentional diversion of wastestreams from any portion of an Industrial User's treatment facility" (40 CFR Part 403.17). Reporting of bypass conditions is to be in accordance with 40 CFR Part 403.17. Where such information is given orally, the city may at its discretion require a written follow-up report thereof to be filed by the discharger with the city within five (5) working days. The report shall specify: 
(1)  Description of the upset, the cause thereof and the upset's impact on a discharger's compliance status. 
(2)  Duration of noncompliance, including exact dates and times of noncompliance, and if the noncompliance continues, the time by which compliance is reasonably expected to occur. 
(3)  All steps taken or to be taken to reduce, eliminate and prevent recurrence of such an upset or other conditions of noncompliance. 
A documented and verified, bona fide operation upset shall be an affirmative defense to any enforcement action brought by the city against a discharger for any noncompliance with this article which arises out of violations alleged to have occurred during the period of the act of God. Monitoring and analysis by an industrial user to demonstrate continued compliance shall be conducted in accordance with 40 CFR Part 403.12(g). For the purposes of this chapter, "acts of God" shall mean war, riot, an extraordinary occurrence by natural cause such as flood, wind, earthquake or other catastrophe that cannot be reasonably foreseen, but does not include occurrences caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, § 4, 2-6-06) 
Sec. 26-52. - Mental state. 
    A culpable mental state is not required to prove an offense under this article. A person is criminally responsible for a violation of this article if: 
(1)  The person commits or assists in the commission of a violation; or 
(2)  The person owns or manages the property or facilities determined to be the source of an illegal discharge. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-53. - Falsifying information. 
    Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representations or certifications in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this article, or to a wastewater discharge permit, or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required pursuant to this article, shall, upon conviction, be punished by the imposition of a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-54. - Penalty for criminal mischief. 
    The city may pursue all criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes and ordinances against any person negligently, willfully, or maliciously causing loss by tampering with or destroying public sewers, monitoring devices or treatment facilities. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-55. - Circumstances beyond user's control. 
    If a person can establish that an event that would otherwise be a violation of the pretreatment ordinance or permit issued under this article was caused solely by an act of God, war, riot, or other catastrophe, the event is not a violation of this article or permit. A justifiable basis for the person's nonperformance may arise from national emergency, uncontrolled and unanticipated material charges, civil disorder and power outages in degree or duration beyond the capabilities of required emergency generation capacity, casualty losses and damages. Other conditions that may represent a justifiable basis for nonperformance under this article may be considered when the conditions are found by the city to be of such difficulty to accomplish as to be impractical to pursue at any given time due to any factor which could not have been foreseen or anticipated and which could not have been avoided or lessened in impact by the actions of the user. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4139, § 1, 10-7-02 ) 
Sec. 26-56. - Civil penalties. 
    Any user who is found to have violated an order of the city council, or who will willfully or negligently failed to comply with any provision of this article, and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder, may be fined (or, in the case of users outside the city limits, shall pay an administrative penalty) an amount not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor greater than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation; provided however, the following minimum fines shall be assessed upon a finding of guilty to any charge of violation: 
(1)  First violation, five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(2)  Second violation, seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(3)  Third and subsequent violation, one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
    Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue may be deemed a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the penalties provided herein, the city may recover reasonable attorney's fees, court costs, court reporters' fees and other expenses of litigation by appropriate suit at law against the person found to have violated this article or the orders, rules, regulations, and permits issued hereunder. In determining the extent of the penalties herein contemplated, the court or the jury, as the case may be, may take into account the economic benefit realized by the user during the period of violation attributed to the act or acts of noncompliance in determining and assessing the penalties under this section. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, § 5, 2-6-06) 
Sec. 26-57. - Administrative relief. 
    Any user objecting to a decision, edict, or order of an authorized official of the city, other than the city manager, under the authority of this article shall have the right to administrative relief, and may petition, in writing, and within ten (10) working days of receipt of such decision, edict, or order, for a ruling from the city manager. The city manager shall, within ten (10) working days of receiving the petition, review the contentions of both the authorized official of the city and the user. The city manager may at his discretion, request other city or professional opinions prior to rendering his decision. The city manager shall render a written ruling within twenty (20) days of receiving the petition. A user objecting to a decision, edict, order, or ruling of the city manager may appeal any such action directly to the city council. The city council shall conduct a review of the facts and contentions during any regular or special city council meeting, open to the public, to be held no sooner than five (5) days nor later than thirty (30) days from the date of the city manager's ruling. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-58. - Recovery of costs incurred by city. 
    Any discharger violating any of the provision of this article, or who discharges or causes a discharge producing a deposit or obstruction, or causes damage to or impairs the city's wastewater disposal system, shall be liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage caused by such violation or discharge. The city shall bill the discharger for the costs incurred by the city for any cleaning, repair, or replacement work caused by the violation or discharge. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-59. - Cost of administering program. 
    The city may make such charges, known as monitoring and pretreatment charges, as are reasonable for services rendered in administering the program outlined in this article. Such charges may include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Permitting industrial facilities. 
(2)  Inspection. 
(3)  Sample analysis. 
(4)  Monitoring. 
(5)  Enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-60. - Preservation of records. 
    All dischargers subject to this article shall retain and preserve for no less than three (3) years or for the duration of the permit if it is valid for more than three (3) years, any records, books, documents, memoranda, reports, correspondence and any and all summaries thereof, relating to monitoring, sampling and chemical analyses made by or on behalf of a discharger in connection with its discharge. 
    All records which pertain to matters which are the subject of administration adjustment or any other enforcement or litigation activities brought by the city pursuant hereto shall be retained and preserved by the discharger until all enforcement activities have concluded and all periods of limitation with respect to any and all appeals have expired. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Secs. 26-61-26-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DISCHARGE PERMITS 

Sec. 26-71. - Required. 
(a)  This division specifically repeals any and all previously issued wastewater discharge permits for significant industrial users issued by the city, and any special agreements or contracts whether written or oral that do no conform to all requirements of this article, to the extent of the conflict. 
(b)  All significant industrial users connected to, or otherwise contributing to, the city's sewage collection and treatment system on the effective date of this article shall apply for a new wastewater discharge permit within sixty (60) days of the effective date of this article. 
(c)  All minor industrial users shall be required to apply for a new wastewater discharge permit within thirty (30) days of receiving notification from an authorized official of the city that a permit is required. 
(d)  Any significant industrial users proposing to connect to, or otherwise contribute to, the city's sewage collection and treatment system after the effective date of this article shall apply for and obtain a wastewater discharge permit before so connecting or contributing. 
(e)  In cases involving public health or safety, or public convenience and necessity, the city manager or his or her designee may, allow a significant industrial user to connect or contribute to the POTW before processing of the permit application is complete. Allowing such a connection or contribution shall in no way relieve the user from its obligation to obtain a wastewater discharge permit at the earliest possible time, and to comply with all other provisions of this article, beginning at the instant each connection or contribution is made. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any significant industrial user to discharge to the public sewage collection and treatment system without possessing either a valid wastewater discharge permit or written permission from an authorized official of the city based on a pending application for a permit. Similarly, no minor industrial user shall discharge to the public system for more than thirty (30) days after being notified of the need for a wastewater discharge permit without either receiving a valid permit, or written permission from the city manager or his or her designee to discharge pending processing of an application. 
(g)  Classification of discharges and permits: 
(1)  All nondomestic users which discharge into the sanitary sewer system of the city shall be grouped according to the following definitions. Group I users are classified as significant and groups II, III and IV are classified as minor. Definitions for categorical significant and minor industrial users are recorded in section 26-26. 
a.  Group I-Major and significant industries. Industries that discharge a significant quantity of regulated pollutants. All categorical industries belong to this group and will be permitted according to applicable national pretreatment standards. 
b.  Group II-Classed industries. Industries, such as printers, photographic developers and other dischargers which can be classed according to the character of their wastewater, and which may discharge regulated pollutants. 
c.  Group III-Commercial facilities and small industrial users. Those facilities which do not discharge a significant amount of regulated pollutants on a regular basis. 
d.  Group IV-Wastewater haulers. The city may promulgate regulations pertaining to the permitting of all transporters of industrial waste desiring to discharge such transported industrial wastes into the city's sewage collection system, or its tributaries, as necessary to adequately protect the POTW and its operations from injurious effects resulting from the acceptance into that system of the transported industrial wastes. 
The industrial waste discharged or deposited into the sanitary sewers by a group III or group IV user shall be subject to periodic inspection and sampling as often as may be deemed necessary by the city. Samples shall be collected in such manner as to be representative of the character and concentration of the waste under operational conditions. The laboratory methods used in the examination of such waste shall be those set forth in 40 CFR Part 136. The determination of the character and concentration of industrial waste shall be made by the city at such times and on such schedules as may be established by the city. Should an owner or occupant discharging industrial waste to the sanitary sewers desire a determination of the quality of such industrial waste be made at some time other than that scheduled by the city, such special determination may be made by the city at the expense of the owner or occupant discharging the waste. 
(2)  All significant industrial users from group I shall submit a wastewater discharge permit application to the director of utilities, the form for which shall be provided by the city. In the case of existing dischargers who have not already complied with this section, such application must be submitted within sixty (60) days of the effective date of this article. 
(3)  Sixty (60) days following the effective date of this article, no significant industrial user (group I) shall be permitted to discharge unless and until it has submitted a completed wastewater discharge permit application in accordance with (2) above. 
(4)  The city will evaluate the completed applications and data furnished by the discharger and may require additional information. The city will determine to which group each applicant will be assigned and if a permit is required. Within sixty (60) days after evaluation of the application, a wastewater discharge permit, if required, shall be issued, subject to the terms and conditions specified herein; and to the regulations of the city. 
(5)  If the application is denied, the applicant shall be notified in writing within sixty (60) days of the reasons for such denial. If denial is based on the city's determination that the applicant cannot meet the pretreatment standards specified in this article, it may specify that additional pretreatment operations will be required of applicant. 
(6)  Where additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance activities will be required to comply with this article, pursuant to (5), above, the discharger shall provide a declaration of the shortest schedule by which the Discharger will provide such additional pretreatment and/or implementation of additional operational and maintenance activities. 
(i)  The schedule shall contain milestone dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment required for the discharger to comply with the requirements of this article including, but not limited to dates relating to hiring an engineer, completing preliminary plans, completing final plans, executing contract for major components, commencing construction, completing construction, and all other acts necessary to achieve compliance with this article. 
(ii)  The time increments between milestone dates established shall be the shortest practicable for the completion of the required work. Under no circumstances shall the city permit a time increment for a single step in the compliance schedule to exceed nine (9) months. The completion date in this schedule shall not be later than the compliance date established for applicable categorical pretreatment standards. 
(iii)  Not later than fourteen (14) days following each milestone date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the discharger shall submit a progress report to the city, including no less than a statement as to whether or not it complied with the increment of progress represented by that milestone date and, if not, the date on which it expects to comply with this increment of progress, the reasons for delay, and the steps being taken by the discharger to return the construction to the approved schedule. In no event shall more than nine (9) months elapse between such progress reports to the city. 
(7)  Unless exempted by the city, all group I and group II dischargers shall provide monitoring facilities prior to approval of a permit application, to allow inspection, sampling and flow measurement at each discharge point. Each monitoring facility shall be located on the discharger's premises; except in the case where such location would be impractical or cause undue hardship to the discharger, the city may approve the placement of monitoring facilities in the public street or sidewalk area. All monitoring equipment and facilities shall be maintained in a safe and proper operating condition at the expense of the Discharger. 
Failure to provide proper monitoring facilities shall be grounds for denial of a permit application. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(e), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-72. - Application. 
(a)  Users required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit shall complete and file with the city an application, on forms provided by the city, and accompanied by the proper fee as established elsewhere in this article. New users shall apply at least sixty (60) days prior to the date the connection or contribution is to be made. In support of the application, the user shall submit, in units and terms appropriate for evaluation, the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, and location (if different from the address); 
(2)  SIC number according to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual; 
(3)  A listing of wastewater constituents and their concentrations and characteristics. This list shall include, but not be limited to, those mentioned in section 26-113 et seq. The analysis shall be determined by a reliable analytical laboratory approved by the city; sampling and analyses shall be performed in accordance with procedures established by the EPA pursuant to section 304(c) of the Act and contained in 40 CFR, Part 136, as amended; 
(4)  Times and durations of contributions; 
(5)  Average daily and thirty-minute peak wastewater flow rates, including daily, monthly and seasonal variations, if any; 
(6)  Site plans, and, if required by the city manager or his or her designee, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans and details, sufficient to show all sewers, sewer connections, and appurtenances by the size, location, and elevation, including a complete, detailed description of any pretreatment facilities, existing or proposed. 
(7)  Description of all activities, facilities and plant processes on the premises, including all materials which are, or could be, discharged, either intentionally or accidentally; 
(8)  Where known, the nature and concentration of any pollutants in the discharge that are limited by any city, state or federal pretreatment standards, and a statement regarding whether or not the pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis and, if not, whether additional operation and maintenance and/or additional pretreatment is required for the user to meet applicable pretreatment standards; 
(9)  If additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance will be required to meet the pretreatment standards, the shortest schedule by which the user will provide such additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance. The completion date on this schedule shall not be later than the compliance date established for the applicable pretreatment standard. The following conditions shall apply to this schedule: 
(A)  The schedule shall contain increments of progress in the form of dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment required for the user to meet applicable pretreatment standards (e.g., hiring an engineer, completing preliminary plans, completing final plans, executing contract for major components, commencing construction, completing construction, etc.). 
(B)  No increment referred to in a. above shall exceed nine (9) months. 
(C)  Not later than fourteen (14) days following each date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the user shall submit a progress report to the city manager or his or her designee including, as a minimum, whether or not the user complied with the increment of progress to be met on such date and, if not, the date on which the user expects to comply with this increment of progress, the reason for delay, and the steps being taken by the user to return the remaining increments to the schedule established. In no event shall more than nine (9) months elapse between such progress reports to the city manager or his or her designee. 
(10)  Each product produced by type, amount, process or processes and rate of production; 
(11)  Type and amount of raw materials processed (average and maximum per day); 
(12)  Number and type of employees, hours of operation of plant, proposed or actual hours of operation of pretreatment system, and any periods of discharge or contribution to the public system at times not set forth herein as hours of plant and/or pretreatment system operation; 
(13)  Any other information as may be deemed to the city to be necessary to evaluate the permit application. 
(14)  Each application shall be certified by the authorized representative of the industrial user as being true and correct as to each statement and representation made in the application. 
(b)  The city will evaluate the data furnished by the user and may require additional information. After evaluation and acceptance of the data furnished, the city may issue a wastewater discharge permit subject to terms and conditions provided herein. The city may deny a permit if evaluation of available data indicates that the user will not be able to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, § 6, 2-6-06; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(f), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-73. - Modification. 
(a)  Within nine (9) months of the promulgation of a national categorical pretreatment standard, the wastewater discharge permits of users subject to such standards shall be revised to require compliance with such standard within the time frame prescribed by such standard. Where a user who is subject to a national categorical pretreatment standard has not previously submitted an application for a wastewater discharge permit as required by the preceding section, the user shall apply for a wastewater discharge permit within one hundred eighty (180) days of the promulgation of the applicable national categorical pretreatment standard. When a user has an existing wastewater discharge permit, he shall submit to the city manager or his or her designee within one hundred eighty (180) days of the promulgation of an applicable federal categorical pretreatment standard the information required by this section, and must request a new or modified permit. 
(b)  The terms and conditions of any existing permit may be modified by the city during the term of the permit if the limitations or requirements identified in section 26-113 et seq. are modified, or if a change in the user's classification has occurred. The user shall be informed of any proposed changes in his permit at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of change. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(g), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-74. - Conditions. 
(a)  Holders of wastewater discharge permits shall be expressly subject to all provisions of this article and all other applicable regulations, including user charges, industrial waste surcharges, and fees established by the city. 
(b)  Permits shall be conditioned by specific requirements set forth by the city, as indicated by conditions or attachments to such permit, regarding any or all of the following: 
(1)  Limits on average and maximum rate and time of discharge, including requirements for flow regulation and equalization; 
(2)  Limits on the average and maximum wastewater constituents and characteristics; 
(3)  Requirements for installation and maintenance of flow measuring, inspection, and sampling facilities and devices (control points); 
(4)  Specifications for self-monitoring programs which may include sampling locations, frequency of sampling, number, types and standards for tests, and a reporting schedule; 
(5)  Requirements for submission of technical reports or discharge reports; 
(6)  Requirements for maintaining and retaining plant records relating to wastewater discharge as specified by the city, and for furnishing the city copies thereof; 
(7)  Requirements for notifying the city prior to any introduction of new wastewater constituents and/or any change that the User knows or knew, or had reason to know, might alter the volume or character of the wastewater constituents being introduced into the wastewater treatment system, for however brief a time; 
(8)  Requirements to install traps basins, holding tanks and/or pretreatment facilities; 
(9)  In the event a user's application for wastewater discharge permit, previously established or planned operational procedures, or other information available to the city indicates to an authorized official of the city that the user may discharge wastewater of either nondomestic or domestic quality at a rate exceeding one hundred (100) gallons per minute, the user's discharge permit may be issued conditioned upon flow equalization procedures, specified periods of discharge, or other conditions intended to decrease the impact of anticipated peak load discharges from such user. Said flow equalization conditions of a permit may he imposed by an authorized official of the city subject to administrative relief set forth in this article; 
(10)  Requirements that users outside the city limits agree to accept administrative penalties equivalent to the fine structure for violations of the provision of this chapter; 
(11)  Permit duration; 
(12)  Compliance schedules; 
(13)  Limits on permit transfer; 
(14)  Other conditions as deemed appropriate by the city of control the contribution to the POTW of certain industrial users to ensure compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements and this article. Said conditions may include requirements to prevent slugloads as defined in this article; or 
(15)  The unit charge or schedule of user charges and fees for the wastewater to be discharged to a city sewer. 
(16)  The full range and extent of civil and criminal penalties that may be assessed against a user for violation of the permit and/or the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 2336, § 7, 2-6-06) 
Sec. 26-75. - Duration. 
    Permits shall be issued for a specified time period, not to exceed five (5) years. A permit may be issued for a period less than a year, or may be stated to expire on a specific date. The user shall apply in writing for permit reissuance a minimum of sixty (60) days prior to the expiration of the user's existing permit. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-76. - Not transferable. 
    Wastewater discharge permits are issued to a specific user for a specific operation. A wastewater discharge permit shall not be reassigned, transferred or sold to a new owner, new user, different premises, or a new or changed operation. In each such instance, a new permit will be required. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-77. - Enforcement. 
    The failure to meet any of the terms, conditions, reporting requirements, or any other regulation or procedure embodied in a wastewater discharge permit issued pursuant to this article shall be individually enforceable as if such terms, conditions, reporting requirements, regulations, or procedures embodied in such permit had been included, verbatim, within this article. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-78. - Pretreatment. 
    When required by conditions of the permit, industrial users shall provide all wastewater pretreatment necessary to comply with this article, and shall achieve compliance with all applicable federal categorical pretreatment standards within the time limitations specified by the federal pretreatment regulations. Any facilities required to pretreat wastewater to a level acceptable to the city shall be provided, operated and maintained at the user's expense. Detailed plans showing the pretreatment facilities and operating procedures shall be submitted to the city for review, and shall be approved in writing by the city before construction of the pretreatment facility. The approval of such plans and operating procedures will in no way relieve the user from the responsibilities of modifying the facility as necessary to produce a discharge acceptable to the city under the provisions of this article. Any subsequent changes in the pretreatment facilities or method of operation shall be reported to, and be acceptable to, the city prior to the user's initiation of the changes. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-79. - Compliance date report. 
    Within ninety (90) days following the date for final compliance with applicable categorical pretreatment standards or, in the case of a new source, following commencement of the introduction of wastewater into the public sewage collection and treatment system, any user subject to such pretreatment standards and requirements shall submit to the city manager or his or her designee a report indicating the nature and concentration of all pollutants in the discharge from the regulated processes that are limited by categorical pretreatment standards and requirements, together with the average and maximum daily flow for those process units in the user's facility that are limited by such pretreatment standards or requirements. The report shall state whether or not the applicable pretreatment standards or requirements are being met on a consistent basis and, if not, what additional operation and maintenance and/or pretreatment is necessary to bring the user into compliance with the applicable pretreatment standards or requirements. This statement shall be signed by an authorized representative of the user, and certified by a professional engineer registered in the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(h), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(h) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-79 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-79 derived from Ord. No. 3551, § 3, adopted May 15, 1995. 
Sec. 26-80. - Period compliance reports. 
(a)  Any user subject to a categorical pretreatment standard, after the compliance date of such pretreatment standard, or, in the case of a new source, after commencement of the discharge, shall submit a report to the city manager or his or her designee during the months of June and December, unless required more frequently in the pretreatment standard or by the city manager or his or her designee, which indicates the nature and concentration of all pollutants in the effluent that are limited by such pretreatment standards. In addition, this report shall include a record of all daily flows which, during the reporting period, exceeded the average daily flow allowed by the user's wastewater discharge permit. In consideration of such factors as local high or low flow rates, holidays, budget cycles, etc., an authorized official of the city may alter the months during which the above reports are to be submitted. 
(b)  An authorized official of the city may impose mass limitations (pounds per day or similar units) on users who are required to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements. In such cases, the report required by (a) above shall indicate the mass of pollutants regulated by categorical pretreatment standards in the effluent of the user. These reports shall contain the results of sampling and analysis of the discharge, including the volume of the flow and the nature and concentration (or production and mass where required) of pollutants contained therein that are limited by the applicable categorical pretreatment standards. The frequency of monitoring shall be as prescribed in the applicable pretreatment standard. All analyses shall be performed in accordance with procedures established by EPA pursuant to section 304(g) of the Act and contained in 40 CFR, Part 136 and amendments thereto, or with any other test procedures approved by EPA. Sampling shall be performed in accordance with the techniques approved by EPA. Where 40 CFR, Part 136 does not include a sampling or analytical technique for the pollutant in question, sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with the procedures set forth in the EPA publication, "Sampling and Analysis Procedures for Screening of Industrial Effluents for Priority Pollutants," April, 1977, and amendments thereto, or with any other sampling and analytical procedures approved by EPA. 
(c)  All records relating to compliance with pretreatment standards shall be made available to officials of the city, state or EPA upon request. 
(d)  All industrial users are subject to the self-monitoring and resampling provision of 40 CFR 403.12(g) and (h). 
(e)  Industrial users shall submit reports to the POTW in form and substance meeting the requirements of 40 CFR 403.12(b), (d) and (e) and each such report shall be certified as to the truth and accuracy of each statement and/or representation therein made in a manner satisfying the requirement of 40 CFR 403.12(I). 
(f)  Industrial users shall report potential problems or actual changes in volume, quality or constituents of sewer discharge in an manner satisfying the requirements of 40 CFR 403.12(f) and (p). 
(g)  Each significant industrial user shall submit to the POTW baseline monitoring reports in a manner satisfying the requirement of 40 CFR 403.12(b). 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, §§ 8, 9, 2-6-06; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(i), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-81. - Confidential information. 
    All information concerning the industrial pretreatment programs will be available to the public, at the office of the city manager or his or her designee, from the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., except for that information requested by the industry to be made confidential that would reveal company or trade secrets. This confidential information must conform to the guidelines specified in 40 CFR 403.14 for confidentiality. The confidential information will be secured in a separate folder and locked in a file cabinet inside the city manager's or his or her designee's office. The file cabinet will only be accessible by the environmental services staff and the city manager or his or her designee. All laboratory analysis and effluent data will not be confidential information. This information shall not be made available for inspection by the public, but shall still be made available, upon written request, to governmental agencies if such portions of a report shall be available for use by the state or any state agency in judicial review or enforcement proceedings involving the user furnishing the report. Information accepted by the city as confidential shall not be transmitted to any governmental agency by the city until and unless a notification is given to the user and the governmental agency requesting the information enters into an agreement to comply with the requirements of 40 CFR Park 2, Subpart B, concerning the confidential information. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(j), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(j) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-81 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-81 derived from Ord. No. 3551, § 3, adopted May 15, 1995. 
Secs. 26-82-26-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTION 

Sec. 26-96. - Monitoring facilities to be provided by user. 
(a)  Significant industrial users and minor industrial users, if so required by the city, shall be required to provide and maintain, at their own expense, a control point on each discharge line that connects to the sewage collection and treatment system that will allow inspection, sampling, and, if required, flow measurements of the discharge from the building sewers and/or internal drainage system. The control point should normally be situated on the user's premises, but the city may, when such a location would be impractical or cause undue hardship on the user, allow the facility to be constructed in the public street or sidewalk area, if it will not be obstructed by landscaping or parked vehicles. If required by the city for added fee computation, monitoring a regulated or restricted flow rate, or as a condition of a wastewater discharge permit, the user may also be required to provide, install, and maintain flow measuring equipment acceptable to the city at the control point, whether or not the user would have preferred to pay for sewer service or surcharge fees based on metered water consumption. 
(b)  There shall be ample room in or near such control point to allow accurate sampling and preparation of samples for analysis. The control point and measuring equipment, and any privately owned sampling equipment, shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition at the expense of the user. 
(c)  Whether constructed on public or private property, the control point, and any sampling or monitoring facilities provided by the user, shall be provided in accordance with the city's requirements and with all applicable local construction standards and specifications. Construction shall be completed within ninety (90) days of receiving written notification by the city that a control point is required. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-97. - Right of access. 
    The city shall have the right to inspect the premises of any user to ascertain whether the purposes and requirements of this article are being met. Persons owning or occupying any premises where wastewater is created or discharged, or which are crossed by any public sewer, shall allow the city ready access at all reasonable times to those parts of the premises necessary for the purposes of inspection, sampling, records examination or the performance of any of its duties. The city, state or EPA shall have the right to set up on the user's property such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling, inspection, compliance monitoring, and/or metering operations. 
    Where a user has security measures in force that require identification and clearance before entry, the user shall instruct his security personnel that, upon presentation of identification, personnel of the city, the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission, the EPA, or other persons (such as private laboratory personnel) authorized by the city, will be permitted to enter without delay to perform their specific duties. 
    Anyone acting under this authority shall observe the establishment's rules and regulations concerning safety, internal security, and fire protection. The inspectors, agents or representatives of the city charged within the enforcement of this section shall be deemed to be performing a governmental function for the benefit and health and welfare of the general public and neither the city nor any individual inspector, agent or representative shall be held liable for any loss or damage whether real or asserted, caused or alleged to have been caused as a result of the performance of such governmental function. The failure or refusal of such owners or occupants to comply with this provision shall be grounds for the disconnection of water and/or sewer service to the facility, pursuant to the enforcement and/or termination of service provisions of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-98. - Sampling schedules for monitoring, surcharging and enforcement. 
    The industrial waste discharged or deposited into the sanitary sewers by industrial users shall be subject to periodic inspection and sampling as often as may be deemed necessary by the city. Significant industrial users shall be subject to periodic inspection and sampling at least once annually.
