Samples shall be collected in such a manner as to be representative of the character and concentration of the waste under operation conditions. The laboratory methods used in the examination of such waste shall be those set forth in 40 CFR, Part 136. The determination of the character and concentration of industrial waste shall be made at such times and on such schedules as may be established by the city. Should a discharger desire a determination of the quality of such industrial waste be made at some time other than that scheduled by the city, such special determination may be made by the city at the expense of the owner or occupant discharging the waste. A permittee shall make application to amend its permit thirty (30) days before expiration, or during the term of the permit immediately upon the event of significant change in volume of or the pollutants in the discharge into the sanitary sewer. The city reserves the right to deny an application for permit seeking to amend an existing or expiring permit that increases the volumes and/or pollutant level of the propose discharge. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, § 10, 2-6-06) 
Sec. 26-99. - Sampling and analysis procedures. 
(a)  Examination and analysis of the characteristics of waters and wastes required by this article, whether for enforcement, routine monitoring, or assessing a surcharge, shall be: 
(1)  Conducted in accordance with those set forth in 40 CFR, Part 136; and 
(2)  Determined from samples taken at the control point or other location approved by the city. 
(b)  The city may select, at its own discretion, an independent firm or laboratory to perform sampling and testing on its behalf. The city may select the exact time and frequency of sampling at its sole discretion. 
(c)  Industrial users shall retain the right to request at any time that samples taken from their own discharges be split for the purpose of having independent analysis performed, for either process control or for verification of the city's analyses. Such requests, however, must be made in advance to allow arrangements to be made for sample splitting. In cases where sample splitting is required for verification of the city's analyses, the city shall, at the user's expense, retain a mutually acceptable independent commercial laboratory, and shall split all samples taken from that user with the laboratory retained. Industrial waste surcharge calculations and enforcement action will then be based on the average of the test results from the city's analyses or those of the independent laboratory. The city manager or his or her designee may also arrange, at the city's expense, to split all samples three (3) ways, and have the third fraction analyzed by yet another mutually acceptable independent commercial laboratory. In such cases, industrial waste surcharge calculations and enforcement action will be based on the city's judgment of the agreement between the three (3) independent test results. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(k), 6-17-13) 
Secs. 26-100-26-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - REGULATION OF DISCHARGE AND SEWER CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 26-111. - All discharges regulated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to discharge any unpolluted water or any wastewater to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, or to the sewage collection and treatment system, except as authorized in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Except as otherwise permitted by this article, all discharges of storm runoff and other unpolluted waters must be made to storm sewers or natural outlets; all discharges of wastewaters must be made to the sewage collection and treatment system. All users discharging wastewater other than normal domestic wastewater shall be classified as either minor or significant industrial users; and, according to Division 3 of this article, may be required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit, as described elsewhere in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-112. - Unlawful to discharge polluted waters in watercourses. 
(a)  Unless otherwise authorized by a valid permit issued by the Texas Water Commission or EPA, no person may deposit or discharge wastewater, industrial waste or other polluted liquids, whether on public or private property, into or adjacent to any natural outlet, watercourse, storm sewer, or other area within the jurisdiction of the city. All such discharges shall be made to the public sanitary sewer system unless so authorized. 
(b)  The city shall verify, prior to the discharge, that wastes authorized to be discharged in (a) above will receive suitable treatment within the provisions of laws, regulations, ordinances, and rules of the federal, state and local governments. To this end, the city may require submittal of plans sealed by a professional engineer registered in the State of Texas, specifications, and other pertinent information prior to construction of facilities for such treatment. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-113. - Prohibited substances and concentrations of specific substances. 
    No user shall contribute, or cause to be contributed, directly or indirectly, any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operation or performance of the public sewage collection and treatment system, whether or not the user is subject to national categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state, or local pretreatment requirements. A user shall not contribute the following substances to the POTW: 
(1)  Any substance which, by reason of its nature or quantity is, or may be sufficient, either alone or by interaction with other substances, to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the public sewage collection and treatment system or to its operation. At no time shall two (2) successive readings on an explosion hazard meter, at the point of discharge into the system (or at any point in the system), be more than five (5) percent, nor shall any single reading be over ten (10) percent of the lower explosive limit (LEL) of the meter. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to acetone, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides, sulfides, and any other substances which the city, the state or EPA has notified the user is a fire hazard or a hazard to the system. 
(2)  Solid or viscous substances which cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer or other interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment facilities, such as, but not limited to: Floatable O&G, garbage with particles greater than one-half inch in any dimension, animal guts or tissues, paunch manure, bones, hair, hides, or fleshings, entrails, whole blood, feathers, ashes, cinders, sand, spent lime, lime slurries, stone or marble dust, metal, glass, straw, shavings, grass clippings, rags, spent grains, spent hops, wastepaper, wood, plastics, tar, asphalt residues, residues from refining or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, mud, or glass-grinding or polishing wastes. 
(3)  Any wastewater having a pH less than 5.5 or greater than 10.0, or wastewater having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, and/or personnel of the public sewage collection and treatment system. 
(4)  Any wastewater containing toxic pollutants in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, to injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a toxic effect in the receiving waters of a public treatment plant, or to exceed the limitation set forth in a categorical pretreatment standard. Toxic pollutants, for this subsection, shall include, but not be limited to, those pollutants identified by EPA pursuant to section 307(a) of the Act. 
(5)  Any noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, or solids which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, create a public nuisance or hazard to life, or which prevent safe entry into the sewers for maintenance and repair. 
(6)  Any substance which may cause the treatment works' effluents, or any other product of the public sewage collection and treatment system such as residues, sludges, or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse, or which will interfere with the reclamation process. In no case shall a substance discharged to the public sewage collection and treatment system cause the city to be in noncompliance with a sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or regulations developed under section 405 of the Act, or with any criteria, guidelines, or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the Solid Waste Disposal Act, the Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substances Control Act, or state criteria applicable to the sludge management method(s) being used by the city. 
(7)  Any substance which will cause the city to violate its NPDES and/or state disposal system permit or the receiving water quality standards. 
(8)  Any slugload, which shall mean any pollutant, including oxygen-demanding pollutants (BOD, ammonia (NH 3 ), etc.), released in a single extraordinary discharge episode of such volume or strength as to cause interference to the POTW. 
(9)  Any wastewater with color not removed in the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes, vegetable tanning solutions, and coffee processing wastes. 
(10)  Heat in amounts which will inhibit biological activity in the POTW resulting in Interference, but in no case heat in such quantities that the temperature at the POTW treatment plant exceed 40 degrees C (104 degrees F) unless the approval authority, upon request of the POTW, approves alternate temperature limits. 
(11)  Any wastewater containing any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the city in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(12)  Any wastewater which causes any hazard to human health or life not specifically mentioned above. 
(13)  Any wastewater containing any of the following substances, as determined by any individual grab sample tested in accordance with the appropriate procedures in 40 CFR, Part 136 having a result above the minimum detectable limit, is prohibited: 
(1)  Antimony 
(2)  Beryllium 
(3)  Bismuth 
(4)  Fungicides 
(5)  Herbicides 
(6)  Pesticides 
(7)  Rhenium 
(8)  Strontium 
(9)  Tellurium 
(14)  Any wastewater containing concentrations of the following substances greater than the limits indicated below, as determined by sampling and analysis in accordance with 40 CFR Part 403.12 and according to the appropriate procedures in 40 CFR Park 136, is prohibited. Sampling shall be representative of a facility's daily operations. The local limits established above shall be determined by the daily average for the permittee's facility.

(17)  Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems.

(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, § 11, 2-6-06; Ord. No. 4359, § 1, 6-5-06; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(l), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-114. - Authority to require pretreatment. 
    When an authorized official of the city determines that a user is discharging wastewater to the sewage collection and treatment system which contains any of the prohibited substances, or restricted concentrations of substances, listed in section 26-113, the authorized city official shall: (1) advise the user of the impact of the discharge on the system; and (2) develop effluent limitation(s) for such user which will alleviate that impact. The authorized official may require the user(s) to pretreat his wastewater or to utilize outside disposal of such substances so as to make the remaining waste acceptable under the terms and conditions of city, state and federal regulations. The authorized official may also require the user to obtain a wastewater discharge permit, as described elsewhere in this article. 
    The city may impose mass pollutant limitations on industrial users (based on total pounds per day) where the imposition of mass limitations is deemed appropriate. 
    The significant industrial users with average loads of BOD or TSS exceeding fifty (50) pounds per day shall obtain a wastewater discharge permit. The permit will establish a pounds-per-day loading imitation based upon a maximum concentration of five hundred (500) mg/L for BOD and TSS multiplied by the flow from the discharger's plant. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-115. - Authority to approve pretreatment installations. 
    An authorized official of the city may review and approve the design, installation, and operation of any pretreatment facility proposed by a user to meet a pretreatment requirement. Such review and approval shall not, however, release the user from his obligation to comply with the requirements of this article. In particular, the authorized official may require, review, and approve the installation and operation of traps, and of garbage grinders equipped with three-fourths HP or larger motors. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-116. - Requirements for traps. 
    Discharges requiring a trap (or other pretreatment approved by an authorized official of the city) include, but are not limited to, those containing: 
(1)  Floatable oil and grease; 
(2)  Sand and/or gravel; 
(3)  Other floatable or settleable materials, if directed by an authorized official of the city. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-117. - User's duties regarding traps. 
    Any person responsible for a discharge requiring a trap (or other pretreatment) shall, at his own expense, and as required by the city: 
(1)  Provide equipment and facilities of a type and capacity approved by the city; 
(2)  Locate the facilities in a manner that provides ready and easy accessibility for cleaning and inspection; 
(3)  Maintain the facilities in effective operating condition. An authorized official of the city may require copies of contracts if maintenance is performed by a third party. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-118. - General categorical pretreatment standards. 
(a)  Upon the promulgation of the federal categorical pretreatment standards for a particular industrial subcategory, the federal standard, if more stringent than limitations imposed by this article, shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed by this article. An authorized official of the city shall notify all affected users of the reporting requirements applicable under 40 CFR, section 403.12. 
(b)  No person shall contribute or cause to be discharged, directly or indirectly, into any sanitary sewer any wastewater containing toxic pollutants in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction to injure or interfere with any wastewater treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or to exceed the limitation set forth in the National Categorical Pretreatment Standards List of Toxic Pollutants, set forth in the Code of Federal Regulations, 40 CFR, Part 403, Appendix B which List, and all amendments to such list as may be made from time to time, are made a part of this Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-119. - Modification of federal categorical pretreatment standards. 
    If the city's wastewater treatment system is shown to achieve consistent removal of pollutants limited by federal pretreatment standards, the city may apply to the state or federal agency having jurisdiction for modification of specific limits in the federal pretreatment standards. Consistent removal shall mean reduction in the amount of pollutant, or alteration of the nature of the pollutant, by the wastewater treatment system to a less toxic or harmless state in the system's effluent in ninety-five (95) percent of the samples taken, when measured according to the procedures set forth in section 403.7(c)(2) of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 403 "General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution." The city may then modify pollutant discharge limits in the federal pretreatment standards if the requirements contained in 40 CFR, Part 403, section 403.7, are fulfilled and prior approval from the state or federal agency having jurisdiction is obtained. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-120. - State requirements. 
    State requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case where they are more stringent than federal requirements and limitations or those in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-121. - City's right of revision. 
    The city reserves the right to establish, by amendment of this article, more stringent limitations or other requirements on discharges to the sewage collection and treatment system, if deemed necessary to comply with the objectives of this article. Less stringent limitations or other requirements on discharges shall also require amendment of this article, or approval of a specific wastewater discharge permit, by ordinance or resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-122. - Excessive discharge. 
    No user shall ever increase the use of nondomestic water or in any way attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with the limitations contained in the federal categorical pretreatment standards, or with any other pollutant-specific limitation developed by the city or state. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Sec. 26-123. - Spills, upsets and accidental discharges. 
(a)  Each user shall provide protection from spills, upsets, and accidental discharges of prohibited materials or other substances regulated by this article. Facilities to prevent accidental discharge of prohibited materials shall be provided and maintained at the user's own expense. If required by an authorized official of the city, detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to provide this protection shall be submitted to the city for review, and shall be approved by the city before construction of the facility. All significant industrial users existing prior to the enactment of this article shall complete such a plan by March 1, 1987. Any other significant industrial user who commences discharging to the sewage collection and treatment system after the effective date of this article shall not be permitted to introduce pollutants into the system until such discharge prevention procedures have been approved by the city. Review and approval of such plans and operating procedures shall not relieve the significant industrial user from the responsibility to modify his facility as necessary to meet the requirements of this article. All such plans shall meet the requirements of 40 CFR, 403.8(f)(2)(B). 
(b)  In the case of a spill, upset, or accidental discharge, it is the responsibility of the user to immediately telephone and notify an authorized official of the city of the incident. The notification shall include location of discharge, type of waste, concentration and volume, and corrective actions taken. 
(c)  In the event of a spill, upset, or accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other substances regulated by this article, the user causing or allowing such spill, upset, or discharge shall be responsible for paying, in addition to any fines or industrial wastewater surcharges relating to such spill, upset, or discharge, any costs incurred by the city or other governmental agency to: 
(1)  Determine the nature of the materials involved and trace them to their source; 
(2)  Provide necessary labor, equipment, and/or materials to remove or otherwise reduce the effects of the spill, upset, or discharge on the sewage collection and treatment system, the atmosphere, the land overflowed upon, or receiving waters; 
(3)  Pay any fees, forfeitures, or penalties imposed upon the city by the state or EPA as a result of any noncompliance with an NPDES or state discharge permit resulting from the spill, upset, or discharge, including administrative and legal costs associated with the fine. 
(d)  Within five (5) days following a spill, upset, or accidental discharge, the user shall submit to the city manager or his or her designee a detailed written report describing the cause of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Such notification shall not relieve the user of any fines, civil penalties, or other liability which may be imposed by this article or other applicable law. 
(e)  A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees whom to call in the event of a spill, upset, or accidental discharge. Users shall ensure that all employees who may cause or suffer a spill, upset, or accidental discharge to occur are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95; Ord. No. 4336, § 12, 2-6-06; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(m), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-124. - Authority of city to prevent improper discharges into sewers. 
    The city, acting through an authorized official of the city, shall have the power to stop and prevent from discharging into the sewer system, any private sewer or drain through which substances are discharged that are liable to injure the sewers or obstruct the flow of sewage, or interfere with the operation of the disposal plant. 
(Ord. No. 3551, § 3, 5-15-95) 
Secs. 26-125-26-129. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - STORM DRAIN SYSTEM-ILLICIT DISCHARGE PROHIBITION 

Sec. 26-130. - Purposes. 
    This division sets forth uniform requirements for discharges to the Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4) and enables the City of Denison (city) to comply with all applicable federal and state laws, including, but not limited to, the Clean Water Act, Chapter 26 of the Texas Water Code, Title 30 of the Texas Administrative Code, and the MS4 Texas Pollution Discharge Elimination System (TPDES) General Permit. The purposes and objectives of this article are as follows: 
(a)  To maintain and improve the quality of surface water and groundwater within the city. 
(b)  To prevent the discharge of contaminated stormwater runoff from industrial, commercial, residential, and construction sites into the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) and natural waters within the city. 
(c)  To promote public awareness of the hazards involved in the improper discharge of hazardous substances, petroleum products, household hazardous waste, industrial waste, sediment from construction sites, pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers, and other contaminants into the storm sewers and natural waters of the city. 
(d)  To encourage recycling of used motor oil and safe disposal of other hazardous consumer products. 
(e)  To facilitate compliance with state and federal standards and permits by owners and operators of industrial and construction sites within the city. 
(f)  To enable the city to comply with all federal and state laws and regulations applicable to stormwater discharges. 
(g)  To establish legal authority to carry out all inspection, surveillance, and monitoring procedures necessary to ensure compliance with this article. 
(h)  To provide enforcement remedies for non-compliance with this article. 
(i)  To provide authority to prevent improper discharges to the municipal stormwater system. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-131. - Administration. 
    Except as otherwise provided, the director of public works shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this article. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the director may be delegated by the director to other city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-132. - Definitions and abbreviations. 
    Unless a provision of this article explicitly provides otherwise, the terms, phrases, and abbreviations used in this division shall have the meanings designated by the TPDES General Permit to Discharge TXR0400000 effective December 13, 2013, as amended, Chapter 402 of the Clean Water Act and Chapter 26 of the Texas Water Code. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-133. - General prohibition. 
(a)  No person shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) any discharge that is not composed entirely of stormwater. 
(b)  It is an affirmative defense to subsection (a) of this section that the discharge was composed entirely of one (1) or more of the following categories of discharges: 
(1)  A discharge authorized by, and in full compliance with, an NPDES or TPDES permit (other than the NPDES or TPDES permit for discharges from the MS4); 
(2)  A discharge or flow resulting from firefighting by the fire department; 
(3)  A discharge or flow of fire protection water that does not contain oil or hazardous substances or materials that the fire code, as adopted and as amended by the city, requires to be contained and treated prior to discharge, in which case treatment adequate to remove harmful quantities of pollutants must have occurred prior to discharge; 
(4)  Return flows from irrigated agriculture or agricultural stormwater runoff; 
(5)  A discharge or flow from water line flushing, but not including a discharge from water line disinfection by super chlorination or other means unless the discharge contains no harmful quantity of any chemical used in line disinfection; 
(6)  A discharge or flow from lawn watering, or landscape irrigation; 
(7)  A discharge or flow from a diverted stream flow or natural spring; 
(8)  A discharge or flow from uncontaminated pumped groundwater or rising groundwater; 
(9)  Uncontaminated groundwater infiltration (as defined as 40 C.F.R. § 35.2005(20)) to the MS4; 
(10)  Uncontaminated discharge or flow from a foundation drain, crawl space footing drain, or sump; 
(11)  A discharge or flow from a potable water source not containing any harmful substance or material from the cleaning or draining of a storage tank or other container; 
(12)  A discharge or flow from air conditioning condensation that is unmixed with water from a cooling tower, emissions scrubber, emissions filter, or any other source of pollutant; 
(13)  A discharge or flow from individual residential car washing; 
(14)  A discharge or flow from a riparian habitat or wetland; 
(15)  A discharge or flow from water used in street washing that is not contaminated with any soap, detergent, degreaser, solvent, emulsifier, dispersant, or any other harmful cleaning substance; 
(16)  Stormwater runoff from a roof that is not contaminated by any runoff or discharge from an emissions scrubber, filter, or any other source of pollutant; 
(17)  Swimming pool water that contains no harmful quantity of chlorine, muriatic acid or other chemical used in the treatment or disinfection of the swimming pool water or in pool cleaning; or 
(18)  A discharge of flow from a temporary car wash sponsored by a civic group, school, religious, or nonprofit organization. 
(c)  Persons wishing to discharge water other than that listed under subsection (b) of this section and not listed as a specific prohibition under section 26-134, must file a written request to the director five (5) days prior to the date of discharge that details the source of the discharge and the volume of the discharge. Written authorization must be obtained from the director prior to discharge. 
(d)  No affirmative defense is available under subsection (b) of this section if the discharge or flow in question has been determined by the director to be a source of a pollutant or, pollutants to the waters of the United States or to the MS4, written notice of that determination has been provided to the discharger, and the discharge has occurred more than fifteen (15) days beyond the notice. The correctness of the director's determination that a discharge is a source of a pollutant or pollutants may be reviewed in an administrative proceeding by appeal to the city manager. The correctness of the city manager's determination may be appealed for a determination by the city council, and the decision of city council may be appealed by filing a petition in a court of competent jurisdiction within ten (10) days after the date of city council's decision stating that the decision of the city council is illegal in whole or in part and specifying the grounds of the illegality. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-134. - Specific prohibitions and requirements. 
(a)  The specific prohibitions and requirements in this section are not inclusive of all the discharges prohibited by this article. 
(b)  No person shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the MS4 any discharge that is prohibited by the Clean Water Act, the Texas Water Code, or the Texas Administrative Code, or that causes or contributes to causing the city to violate a water quality standard, the city's NPDES permit or TPDES permit, or any state-issued discharge permit for discharges from its MS4. 
(c)  No person shall dump, spill, leak, pump, pour, emit, empty, discharge, leach, dispose, or otherwise introduce or cause, allow, or permit to be introduced any of the following substances into the MS4: 
(1)  Any used motor oil, antifreeze, or any other motor vehicle fluid; 
(2)  Any industrial waste; 
(3)  Any hazardous waste, including hazardous household waste; 
(4)  Any domestic sewage or septic tank waste, grease trap waste, or grit trap waste; 
(5)  Any garbage, rubbish, or yard waste; 
(6)  Any wastewater from a commercial carwash facility; from any vehicle washing, cleaning, or maintenance at any new or used automobile or other vehicle dealership, rental agency, body shop, repair shop, or maintenance facility; or from any washing, cleaning, or maintenance of any business or commercial or public service vehicle, including a truck, bus or heavy equipment, by a business or public entity that operates more than two (2) such vehicles; 
(7)  Any wastewater from washing, cleaning, de-icing, or other maintenance of aircraft; 
(8)  Any wastewater from a commercial mobile power washer or from the washing or other cleaning of a building exterior that contains any soap, detergent, degreaser, solvent, or any other harmful cleaning substance; 
(9)  Any wastewater from commercial floor, rug, or carpet cleaning; 
(10)  Any wastewater from the wash-down or other cleaning of pavement that contains any harmful quantity of soap, detergent, solvent, degreaser, emulsifier, dispersant, or any other harmful cleaning substance; or any wastewater from the wash-down or other cleaning of any pavement where any spill, leak, or other release of oil, motor fuel, or other petroleum or hazardous substance has occurred, unless all harmful quantities of the released material have been previously removed; 
(11)  Any effluent from a cooling tower condenser, compressor, emissions scrubber, emissions filter or the blowdown from a boiler; 
(12)  Any commercial runoff or wash-down water from any animal pen, kennel or fowl or livestock containment area; 
(13)  Any filter backwash from a swimming pool or fountain; 
(14)  Any swimming pool water containing any harmful quantity of chlorine, muriatic acid, or other chemical used in the treatment or disinfection of the swimming pool water or in pool cleaning; 
(15)  Any discharge from water line disinfection by super chlorination or other means if the total residual chlorine it contains any harmful quantity of chlorine or any other chemical used in line disinfection; 
(16)  Any fire protection water containing oil or hazardous substances or materials that the fire code in this Code requires to be contained and treated prior to discharge, unless treatment adequate to remove pollutants occurs prior to discharge (this prohibition does not apply to discharges or flow from firefighting by the fire department.); 
(17)  Any water from a water curtain in a spray room used for painting vehicles or equipment; 
(18)  Any contaminated runoff from a vehicle wrecking yard; 
(19)  Any substance or material that will damage, block, or clog the MS4; 
(20)  Any discharge from oil and gas well drilling, derrick washing, fracturing, or other activities relating to gas pipelines, compression stations, or gas well padsites; 
(21)  Any release from a petroleum storage tank (PST); any leachate or runoff from soil contaminated by a leaking PST; or any discharge of pumped, confined, or treated wastewater from the remediation of any such PST release unless the discharge: 
a.  Is in compliance with all state and federal standards and requirements; and 
b.  Does not contain a harmful quantity of any pollutant. 
(d)  No person shall introduce or cause be introduced into the MS4 any harmful quantity of sediment, silt, earth, soil or other material associated with clearing, grading, excavation, or other construction activities in excess of what could be retained on site or captured by employing sediment and erosion control measures to the maximum extent practicable. 
(e)  No person shall connect a line conveying sanitary sewage, domestic or industrial, to the MS4, or allow such a connection to continue. 
(f)  No person shall cause or allow any pavement wash water from a service station to be discharged into the MS4 unless such wash water has passed through a properly functioning and maintained, grease, oil, and sand interceptor before discharge into the MS4. 
(g)  Regulation of pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers. 
(1)  Any sale, distribution, application, labeling, manufacture, transportation, storage, or disposal of a pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer must comply fully with all state and federal statutes and regulations including, without limitation, the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act (FIFRA) and all federal regulations promulgated pursuant to FIFRA; Chapters 63, 75, and 76 of the Texas Agriculture Code and all state regulations promulgated pursuant to it; and any other state or federal requirement. 
(2)  Any license, permit, registration certification, or evidence of financial responsibility required by state or federal law for sale, distribution, application, manufacturer transportation, storage, or disposal of a pesticide herbicide or fertilizer must be presented to the director or his/her delegate and any city law enforcement officer for examination upon request. 
(3)  No person shall use or cause to be used any pesticide or herbicide contrary to any directions for use on any labeling required by state or federal statute or regulation. 
(4)  No person shall use or cause to be used any pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer in any manner that the person knows or reasonably should know, is likely to cause, or does cause, a harmful quantity of the pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer to enter the MS4 or waters of the United States. 
(5)  No person shall dispose of, discard, store, or transport a pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer or a pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer container in a manner that the person knows or reasonably should know is likely to cause or does cause a harmful quantity of the pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer to enter the MS4 or waters of the United States. 
(h)  Used-oil regulation. 
(1)  No person shall: 
a.  Discharge used oil into the MS4 or a sewer, drainage system, septic tank, surface water, groundwater, or watercourse; 
b.  Knowingly mix or commingle used oil with solid waste that is to be disposed of in a landfill or knowingly directly dispose of used oil on land or in a landfill; 
c.  Apply used oil to a road or land for dust suppression, weed abatement, or other similar use that introduces used oil into the environment. 
(2)  All businesses that change motor oil for the public, municipal waste landfills are encouraged to serve as public used oil collection centers as provided by state statute in Section 371.024 of the Texas Health and Safety Code. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-135. - Compliance monitoring. 
(a)  Right of entry; inspection and sampling. The director may enter the premises of any person discharging stormwater to the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) or to waters of the United States to determine whether the discharger is complying with all requirements of this article and with any state or federal discharge permit, limitation, or requirement. Dischargers shall allow the director ready access to all parts of the premises for the purposes of inspection, sampling, records examination, copying, and for performing any additional duties. Dischargers shall make available to the director, upon request, any stormwater pollution prevention plan (SWPPP), modifications to them, self-inspection reports, monitoring records, compliance evaluations, notices of intent, and any other records, reports, and other documents related to compliance with this article and with any state or federal discharge permit. 
(1)  Where a discharger has security measures in force which require proper identification and clearance before entry into its premises, the discharger shall make necessary arrangements with its security system so that, upon presentation of suitable identification, the director will be permitted to enter without delay for the purposes of performing his/her responsibilities. 
(2)  The director may set up on the discharger's property, or require installation of such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling and/or metering of the discharger's operations. 
(3)  The director may require any discharger to the MS4 or waters of the United States to conduct specified sampling, testing, analysis, and other monitoring of its stormwater discharges and may specify the frequency and parameters of any required monitoring. 
(4)  The director may require the discharger to install monitoring equipment as necessary at the discharger's expense. The discharger shall maintain the facility's sampling and monitoring equipment be at all times in a safe and proper operating condition at its own expense. The discharger shall calibrate all devices used to measure stormwater flow and quality to ensure their accuracy. 
(5)  Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the discharger at the written or verbal request of the director and shall not be replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by the discharger. 
(6)  Unreasonable delays in allowing the director access to the discharger's premises are a violation of this article. The failure or refusal of such discharger to comply with this section shall be grounds for prohibition of dumping or disposal of materials into the MS4, the disconnection of water and/or sewer service to the facility, pursuant to the enforcement and/or termination of service provisions of this chapter, and revocation or suspension of any authorization or permit issued by the city in accordance with the provisions of the city Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Search warrants. If the director has been refused access to any part of the premises from which stormwater is discharged and he/she is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this article or any state or federal discharge permit, limitation, or requirement, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine inspection and sampling program of the city designed to verify compliance with this article or any order issued under it, or to protect the overall public health, safety, and welfare of the community, the director may seek a search warrant from any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  Interlocal and interagency agreements. The city may enter into interagency or interlocal agreements or other maintenance agreements, as necessary, to facilitate the implementation and enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-136. - Acts adversely affecting water quality. 
    It is unlawful for any person to: 
(a)  Maintain grease and sand traps in any automotive center, service station, vehicle maintenance center or vehicle wash operation which is not connected to the sanitary sewer. 
(b)  Wash more than two (2) vehicles per twenty-four-hour period without the waste effluent being trapped and placed in the sanitary sewer. 
(c)  Wash aircraft without the waste effluent being trapped and placed in the sanitary sewer. 
(d)  Dump grass clippings, leaves, brush or any rubbish or debris to the curb, gutter, storm inlet, storm drain or watercourse. 
(e)  Permit crankcase draining, drainage from engine oil filters, vehicle engine wash, or other oils or oily substances, greases, or like material to go to or remain in or on any area that may drain to the storm system or watercourses. 
(f)  Deposit liquid waste, semi-liquid waste, or chemical waste in any area that may drain to the storm system or watercourses or dispose of them at any site other than one approved for that purpose. 
(g)  Permit cooling tower, compressor, or boiler blowdown water that is not clean, untreated water to flow to the storm system or watercourses. 
(h)  Permit water from nurseries which is used to water plants to flow to streets and alleys to the extent that a nuisance may be created by standing water, damage may result to streets or alleys, or the free passage of foot traffic may be affected. 
(i)  Permit waste water resulting from floor cleaning, rug and carpet cleaning, and laundering processes to flow to streets and alleys or into any storm drain or watercourse or to any place other than the sanitary sewer. 
(j)  Permit filter backwash from swimming pools and fountains to drain to any area other than the sanitary sewer or connect the backwash discharge pipe to anything other than the sanitary sewer system. 
(k)  Permit liquid wastes from animal pens used for kennels, animal hospitals, packing houses, poultry processing plants and dairies to flow to any area other than the sanitary sewer. 
(l)  Permit unused materials from ready-mix concrete mortar, and asphalt base delivery trucks to be dumped to any area that may drain to any stream, watercourse storm sewer, or sanitary sewer. 
(m)  Permit any residue to be disposed of or any vehicle to be washed down at any site not approved for that purpose. 
(n)  Permit waste oil storage drums or any other containers which are filled or partially filled with waste oil, solvents, or chemicals to remain in the open or under the eave of a building or structure in such a manner that the storage vessels may overflow as the result of precipitation or leak as a result of corrosion or damage. 
(o)  Permit old motors, transmissions, automobile parts, or any other machinery parts which are coated or partially coated with grease, oil, or solvents to remain uncovered in the open where portions of the coating materials may be washed to the storm sewers or watercourses from precipitation. 
(p)  Permit sewage wastes, whether domestic or industrial, to flow to any area other than a sanitary sewer or approved septic tank. 
(q)  Permit any sanitary sewer pipe to be open. It is an affirmative defense to this subsection that the sewer pipe is open while being actively constructed, cleaned, repaired, or inspected. 
(r)  On any premises he or she manages, owns, leases, or otherwise has control over, fail to complete repair of all malfunctioning sewer systems within seventy-two (72) hours and complete removal of all residue, and complete treatment of affected areas with a suitable disinfectant within twenty-four (24) hours after written notice. Such notice shall be effective upon the earliest of any of the following: 
(1)  Upon personal service; 
(2)  Upon delivery to the person's office during normal working hours; 
(3)  Upon posting such notice on the door to the person's residence or office; or 
(4)  Seventy-two (72) hours after depositing the notice, enclosed in a postpaid, properly addressed wrapper, in a post office or official depository under the care and custody of the United States Postal Service. 
(s)  On any premises a person owns through which a watercourse passes, or such person's lessee, fail to keep and maintain that part of the watercourse within the property free of trash, debris, excessive vegetation, and other obstacles that would pollute, contaminate, or significantly retard the flow of water through the watercourse. In addition, the owner or lessee shall maintain existing privately owned structures within or adjacent to a watercourse, so that such structures will not become a hazard to the use, function or physical integrity of the watercourse. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-137. - Plan for controlling accidental spills and hazardous substances. 
    The city council adopts by reference as the standard for handling accidental spills and controlling hazardous substances within the city, the State of Texas Oil and Hazardous Substances Pollution Contingency Plan. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-138. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  Any expenses incurred in handling an accidental spill shall be paid by the party responsible for the accident. 
(b)  The director may promulgate rules and regulations that are reasonable and necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. A copy of the rules and regulations, when and if promulgated and certified as to truth and accuracy by the director, shall be filed with the city secretary of the city who shall maintain them as public record available for information. 
(c)  Plan review, inspection, and enforcement fees to administer the provisions of this article are hereby established and can be found in the Comprehensive Schedule of Fees attached hereto as Exhibit A and incorporated herein by this reference. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Editor's note- Exhibit A, Comprehensive Schedule of Fees, can be found at the end of ch. 22, div. 5. 
Sec. 26-139. - Enforcement, punishment for violations, and other remedies. 
(a)  Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this article or any permit issued under this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction is punishable by a fine not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each violation thereof, for each act of violation and for each day of violation. 
(b)  In addition to proceeding under authority of subsections (a) of this section, the city is entitled to pursue all criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes or other ordinances against a person, firm, or corporation that remains in violation of this article. 
(c)  The city may disconnect the water service for violation of this article. The city may issue a stop work order for violation of this article. 
(d)  Any person responsible for the depositing or discarding of any material prohibited by this article upon any sidewalk, alley, street, bridge, public passageway, drain, gutter, waterbody, MS4, or other public shall be responsible for any costs associated with the cleaning up or removal and disposal of such materials. Such person shall also be responsible for reimbursing the city for any costs/damages incurred by the city. These costs/damages may include, but are not limited to, manpower, equipment, supplies, analytical costs, disposal costs, consultants, private contractors, street/utility repairs, and repairs to components of the MS4. 
(e)  In the event there is an emergency condition on private property, the director may enter upon such premises and may do such work as necessary, or cause the same to be done, to abate the condition in order that the premises may comply with the requirements of this article. For the purposes of this subsection, "emergency condition" shall be defined as any condition or conditions which are or reasonably could be an immediate threat to the health, safety or welfare of the citizens of the city or to the environment. Anytime the city or its agents abates a nuisance or violation of this article, the owner of such premises shall be responsible for reimbursing the city for any costs/damages incurred by the city and the city manager is hereby authorized to file claims, lawsuits, and/or liens as necessary to collect such costs. 
(Ord. No. 4863, § 2(2.02), 4-17-17) 
Sec. 26-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 5-281. 
State Law reference- Protection of public water supplies, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 4477-1 §§ 10-14. 

Sec. 26-141. - General scope of article. 
    This article regulates the use of the city's potable water system and provides for metering of water used by consumers. 
(Code 1965, § 27-7) 
Sec. 26-142. - Tampering with or injuring property of water system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without the permission of the city manager or his or her designee, to tamper with, injure, damage or deface any component of the city's water system including valves, meters, meter boxes, lids, hydrants, lines, pump stations, ground storage tanks, elevated storage tanks, stopcock, standpipe, public fountain, or other fixture or appliance belonging to the city's water system. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(n), 6-17-13; Ord. No. 4902, § 2(2.01), 9-18-17) 
Editor's note- Section 19(n) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-142 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-142 derived from the 1965 Code, § 27-8. 
Sec. 26-143. - Unlawful turning on or off of water stopcocks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, not the agent or employee of the water department of the city, to turn on or off any water stopcock which is the property of the water department, or to procure another person not the agent or employee of the water department to turn on or off any such water stopcock. 
(Code 1965, § 27-9) 
Sec. 26-144. - Water wells-Covers generally. 
    Every water well located within the corporate limits of the city must have a permanent cover, securely fastened at all times, and capable of supporting at least two hundred (200) pounds of weight. 
(Code 1965, § 27-10) 
Sec. 26-145. - Same-Filling or covering when abandoned. 
    In the event any water well within the city is abandoned or not used, the same shall be filled to the surface with earth or earth and rock or be securely and permanently covered at all times with a permanent cover capable of supporting at least three hundred (300) pounds. 
(Code 1965, § 27-11) 
Sec. 26-146. - Same-Nuisances. 
    Any open water well in violation of section 26-144 or 26-145 is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and the owner, occupier, or person in charge of the property on which such well is located shall cause such well to be covered or filled as required by such sections. 
(Code 1965, § 27-12) 
Sec. 26-147. - Water service connections and meters; multiple service from single meter. 
(a)  Separate for each residence or building in new service. For any service hereafter installed each individual resident or building making connection with the city water system shall have a separate meter, and no new connection shall be made by the city unless such individual residence or building is separately metered. Except, that multiple connections to a single meter may be allowed under the terms of section 26-186. Where more than one (1) connection is so allowed, the billing will be provided in (b) below. 
(b)  Multiple use of meter in existing buildings. In existing cases where more than one (1) building is served by a single meter, the entire amount of water consumed and registered through such meter shall be billed to the building nearest the meter and shall include an additional minimum for each and every other building served by such meter, and such procedure shall continue until such buildings are separately metered. 
(c)  One meter in motel and HUD-code manufactured home park. Any number of structures on one (1) plat of ground owned by one (1) person and constituting a bona fide motel or HUD-code manufactured home park shall be entitled to water service from one (1) meter. In all such cases, however, where the owner's or manager's residence, store, or filling station is conducted in connection with such motel or HUD-code manufactured home park, such residence, store and filling station shall be equipped with a separate meter and a separate charge made therefor, unless the residence, store and filling station be situated within a single building, in which case, a single meter shall suffice for such residence, store and filling station and one (1) charge shall be made therefor. Provided, however, that a structure as used herein shall mean a permanent building which is a part of the realty, and specifically shall not include a HUD-code manufactured home in a HUD-code manufactured home park other than an owner's residence. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  One meter for two or more houses presently so connected. In all cases where two (2) or more houses or buildings are now served by one (1) meter, separate charges shall be made for each house and building and no allowance shall be made for a vacancy of either house or building unless the owner shall furnish satisfactory proof to the city council that water service to such house or building has been disconnected; and at the same time by a written application agrees that in the event of a reconnection, the same shall be equipped with a separate meter and a separate charge paid therefor. 
(f)  Cross-connections with other sources. Cross- connection between piping receiving water from water mains and piping receiving water from any other source or storage is positively forbidden, and the city reserves the right when it discovers the existence of any such cross-connections to immediately and without further notice disconnect the service connecting such piping with the city mains. Anyone desiring to use water from some other source in addition to the city connection may do so by using a storage tank and delivering the city water supply into the tank six (6) inches above the overflow line and through a pipe having at least a six-inch air space between its discharge end and the top of the tank. The water from the other source may then be piped into the tank and the service lines taken from the tank in any manner desired. If inflow from the city water main to a swimming pool or other storage of water is below overflow level a cross-connection exists. 
(Code 1965, § 27-13; Ord. No. 3703, § 3, 3-3-97; Ord. No. 4701, § 19(o), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 26-148. - Water conservation plan adopted. 
    The City of Denison, Texas, Water Conservation Plan attached to Ord. No. 4511 as Exhibit "A," as revised, is made a part hereof for all purposes, and the same is hereby adopted as the official policy of the city. 
    Exhibit "A" is not set out herein but is on file for inspection in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(p), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(p) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-148 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-148 derived from Ord. No. 3921, § 1, adopted Dec. 13, 1999; and Ord. No. 4511, § 1, adopted April 20, 2009. 
Secs. 26-149-26-165. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - INSIDE CITY 

Sec. 26-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Developer means the owner, or agent of the owner, subdividing and installing utilities to serve lots or tracts for resale as homes or industrial sites. 
    Lot or tract of land is defined as the same as a building site as defined in the zoning ordinance of the city, and such definition, restrictions and conditions are hereby adopted and made a part of this division as if fully copied herein. 
    Off-site mains means water and/or sewer mains totally outside of a tract of land to be subdivided and developed for resale. 
    On-site mains means water and/or sewer mains totally within or adjacent to a tract of land to be subdivided and developed for resale. 
    Programmed extension means water and/or sewer extensions included in the master plan of the system design for which funds have been specifically provided. 
(Code 1965, § 27-14) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-182. - Purpose of division. 
    The intent and purpose of this division is to provide an equitable charge for water and sanitary sewer connections as a proportionate distribution of the cost of water and sanitary sewer main extensions to serve property in the city on a front-foot basis. 
(Code 1965, § 27-15) 
Sec. 26-183. - Authority to make extensions. 
    The public works department may extend water and sanitary sewer mains in the streets, alleys or easements within the city limits in order to permit connections by persons desiring and seeking water service and sanitary sewer service. 
(Code 1965, § 27-16)

DIVISION 3. - OUTSIDE CITY SERVICE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4701, §§ 19(s), (t), adopted June 17, 2013, repealed the former div. 3, §§ 26-211-26-217, and enacted a new div. 3 as set out herein. The former div. 3, entitled "Outside City" derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 27-29-27-35. 

Sec. 26-211. - Powers and duties of the city manager or his or her designee. 
    The city manager or his or her designee shall supervise all installations, connections and extensions to both the water and sewer lines of the city outside the city limits. The city manager or his or her designee shall determine whether existing mains in place and outside the city are sufficiently sized and of a condition to allow additional customers without the impairment of the quality of service to existing customers on the main line. If the decision is that additional service may be established on the line in question without impairing quality of service, the city manager or his or her designee may authorize the additional connection if the property to be served is adjacent and contiguous to the corporate limits and petitions the city to be annexed. If such property is not adjacent and contiguous to the city, the city manager or his or her designee may allow the additional connection. No connection to the water or sewer system of the city shall be made or allowed if the city manager or his or her designee finds that quality of service will be impaired below acceptable levels of service. All costs associated with connecting to the system shall be borne by the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 4701, §§ 19(s), (t), 6-17-13)

ARTICLE V. - WATER AND SEWER USE FEES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 26-236. - Tap connection fees-Established. 
    To provide for payment of a portion of the cost and to provide for a uniform and equitable charge for connecting to the water and sewer mains of the city, the city council shall enact from time to time such fees and charges. All applicable fees and charges shall be kept of record in the office of the city manager or his or her designee and shall be available for public inspection in such offices during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(u), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(u) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-236 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-236 derived from the 1965 Code, § 27-36; Ord. No. 4324, § 2, adopted Nov. 7, 2005; and Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 5, 2008. 
Sec. 26-237. - Same-Payment. 
    All tap connection fees established by section 26-236 must be paid to the city before any water or sewer connection is made. 
(Code 1965, § 27-37; Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, 5-5-08) 
Sec. 26-238. - Water service charge-Imposed. 
(a)  The rates or charges for services furnished by the city shall be established from time to time by ordinance of the city council. All applicable fees and charges shall be kept on record in the office of the city clerk and in the water department and shall be available for public inspection in such offices during normal business hours. 
(b)  Each water customer shall be allowed one (1) reread of their water meter during any twelve-month cycle free of charge. If further rereadings are requested during the twelve-month cycle the customer shall be charged as follows: 
(1)  $25.00, if the first reading is confirmed. 
(2)  No charge if it is determined that the first reading was in error. 
(c)  Applicable charges for rereading water meters shall be added to the customer's bill the month following the rereading. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(v), 6-17-13; Ord. No. 4744, § 1, 5-19-14) 
Sec. 26-239. - Same-Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in section 27-238, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    HUD-code manufactured home shall mean the same as trailer, with or without capacity to be towed or moved, located on a temporary, semi-permanent or permanent installation. 
    Single meter shall mean one (1) water meter service to two (2) or more apartments or HUD-code manufactured homes. 
    With meter shall mean with single water meter installed for exclusive use of one (1) apartment or HUD-code manufactured home. 
(Code 1965, § 27-39; Ord. No. 3707, § 3, 3-3-97; Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, 5-5-08) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 26-240. - Charge for connect and disconnect of service. 
    A charge which shall be set from time to time by the city council shall be made to customers who request that water be turned off or on during the normal business days prior to 3:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday. A charge which shall be set from time to time by the city council shall be made to customers who request that water be turned on or off after 3:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday and on weekends. Such fees shall also apply to the disconnection and reconnection occurring due to nonpayment of utility services. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(w), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(w) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-240 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-240 derived from the 1965 Code, § 27-40; Ord. No. 4135, § 1, adopted Sept. 16, 2002; and Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 5, 2008. 
Sec. 26-241. - Same-Collection. 
    The amounts set out in section 26-240 shall be a charge against the owner, occupant or lessee of the premises served by said water meter and the amount so fixed shall be collected through the water department, as water charges are collected and failure to pay such charges shall subject the customer to the same penalty as prescribed for failure to pay water or sewer charges. 
(Code 1965, § 27-41; Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, 5-5-08) 
Sec. 26-242. - Sanitary sewer service charges. 
    The monthly rates or charges for service to be furnished by the sanitary sewer system shall be established from time to time by ordinance of the city council. All applicable fees and charges shall be kept on record in the office of the city manager or his or her designee and shall be available for public inspection in such offices during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(x), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(x) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-238 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation. 
Sec. 26-243. - Monthly billing; payment; delinquent charge; disconnection for nonpayment. 
(a)  Consumers shall be billed at the rates and charges provided in this article once each month. All statements for residential users shall be due and payable on the next due date appearing on the face of such statement, which date shall be twenty-five (25) days following the date of the statement. All statements for apartment complex and commercial/industrial users shall be due and payable on the next due date appearing on the face of such statement, which date shall be twenty-five (25) days following the date of the statement. Any statement not paid by the next due date as herein provided shall incur a late payment penalty of ten (10) percent of the net due date amount and shall appear on the statement as the gross amount due. 
(b)  In the event any user or customer of such service does not pay the statement by the next due date, the utility office manager shall notify the user or customer by U.S. mail that nonpayment is cause for discontinuation of water/sewer service and such notice shall state that payment must be made within ten (10) days of the date of the notice to avoid disconnecting services. Failure to pay the correct amount due on or before the date specified in the notice provided in this subsection shall be cause for disconnecting water service to the user or customer. 
(c)  In instances where the customer has experienced two (2) or more terminations of service for nonpayment of bills within the preceding twelve-month period, a refundable security deposit shall be required in order to gain restoration of service following the second termination of service for nonpayment. This refundable deposit shall be in addition to payment of any outstanding balance and/or reconnection fees. The security deposit amount shall be an additional fifty dollars ($50.00) for residential customers and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for commercial customers. Upon discontinuance of service, the security deposit amount will be applied against the final billing. Any funds remaining after the bill is paid will be refunded to the party from whom they were received. 
(d)  From and after June 1, 2008, [for] existing delinquent accounts and accounts going delinquent thereafter, arrangements for satisfying the delinquency and continuing service may be negotiated between the user/customer and the city in a manner consistent with the provisions of this chapter. Such negotiated arrangements shall be in writing and signed by the person responsible for the payment of the water/sewer service account. In no event shall any account be continued beyond sixty (60) days following the date of the negotiated agreement. 
(e)  In instances where damage to the city's water system has occurred due to tampering with, injuring, damaging or defacing any component of the city's water system including but not limited to valves, meters, meter boxes, lids, hydrants, lines, pump stations, ground storage tanks, elevated storage tanks, stopcock, standpipe, public fountain, or other fixture or appliance belonging to the city's water system, customers shall be billed the rates, fees and/or charges established from time to time by ordinance of the city council. Said rates, fees and/or charges shall be added to the customer's water bill; and, in cases where the service is terminated for nonpayment, the fee shall be paid before service is restored. All applicable fees and charges shall be kept on record in the office of the city manager or his or her designee and shall be available for public inspection in such offices during normal business hours. Payment of these charges for the damage is payable as set out in this section. 
(Code 1965, § 27-43; Ord. No. 3141, § 2, 4-17-89; Ord. No. 4135, § 2, 9-16-02; Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, 5-5-08; Ord. No. 4902, § 2(2.02), 9-18-17) 
Sec. 26-244. - Charges for checks not honored by financial institutions. 
    There shall be a handling fee in an amount determined by the city council for any check issued for payment of water and/or sewer service not honored for payment by that financial institution on which the check was drawn. This handling fee shall be added to the customer's water bill; and, in cases where the service is terminated for nonpayment, the fee shall be paid before service is restored. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(y), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(y) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-244 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-244 derived from the 1965 Code, § 27-44; Ord. No. 4135, § 3, adopted Sept. 16, 2002; and Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 5, 2008. 
Sec. 26-245. - Fee required prior to commencement of service. 
    There is hereby established a fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) which shall be paid prior to commencement of water service by the city. This connection fee shall not be refunded and shall represent the cost of establishing utility services and of setting up accounting and billing records for a customer. Applicants for water service shall be required to provide acceptable proof of identity. Each such customer shall be charged a security deposit in addition to all other fees set forth, as follows: 
(1)  Single-family residential customers ..... $50.00 
(2)  All other customers ..... 100.00 
Under no circumstances shall water service be provided to any person or firm with a previously unpaid account on the records. 
(Code 1965, § 27-45; Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, 5-5-08) 
Sec. 26-246. - Transfer fee. 
    A fee shall be established in the amount of thirty dollars ($30.00) for the transfer of service from one (1) residence or business to another location within the city's service area. Such fee includes the turning off the old service and the connecting of the new service. 
(Code 1965, § 27-46; Ord. No. 4459, §§ 1, 2, 5-5-08) 
Sec. 26-247. - Free service not allowed; exception. 
    No free service shall be allowed except as authorized by the city council by proper resolution. 
(Code 1965, § 27-47) 
Sec. 26-248. - Fees related to the environmental services and monitoring program-Purpose and scope. 
(a)  The purposes of sections 26-248 through 26-250 are to: 
(1)  Provide for the recovery of the costs of implementing and operating the city's pollution abatement and monitoring program from nondomestic users of the city's sewage collection and treatment system; and 
(2)  Establish an industrial waste surcharge that will provide a financial incentive for nondomestic users of the city's sewage collection and treatment system to install meaningful pretreatment facilities. 
(b)  To accomplish these purposes, the city council may adopt, from time to time, by amendment to this section, fees which may include: 
(1)  Fees for reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the city's environmental services monitoring program; 
(2)  Fees for monitoring, inspections and surveillance procedures; 
(3)  Fees for reviewing accidental discharge procedures and construction plans and specifications, and for inspecting construction of facilities; 
(4)  Fees for permit applications; 
(5)  Fees for filing appeals; 
(6)  Fees for consistent removal (by the city) of pollutants otherwise subject to federal pretreatment standards (industrial cost recovery charges); or 
(7)  Other fees as the city may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained in this chapter. 
These fees relate solely to the matters covered by this section, and are separate from, and in addition to, all other fees chargeable by the city, such as sanitary sewer service charges and water service charges, connection fees (tap charges), and front-foot charges. 
(Code 1965, § 27-48(1.2); Ord. No. 4701, § 19(z), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(z) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, changed the title of § 26-248 from "Fees related to the pollution abatement and monitoring program-Purpose and scope" to "Fees related to the environmental services and monitoring program-Purpose and scope." 
Sec. 26-249. - Same-Industrial waste surcharge. 
    In addition to the rates and charges provided by section 26-242 above, charges to customers in the monitored group classes shall be established from time to time by ordinance of the city council. All applicable fees and charges shell be kept on record in the office of the city manager or his or her designee and shall be available for public inspection in such offices during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(aa), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(aa) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-249 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-249 derived from the 1965 Code, § 27-48(1.2); Ord. No. 3216, § 2, adopted April 16, 1990; Ord. No. 3188, §§ 1, 3, adopted Dec. 18, 1989; Ord. No. 4324, § 2, adopted Nov. 7, 2005; and Ord. No. 4325, § 1, adopted Nov. 7, 2005. 
Sec. 26-250. - Same-Fee schedule. 
    Wastewater discharge permit fees shall be established from time to time by ordinance of the city council. All applicable fees and charges shall be kept on record in the office of the city manager or his or her designee and shall be available for public inspection in such offices during normal business hours. 
(Ord. No. 4701, § 19(bb), 6-17-13) 
Editor's note- Section 19(bb) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed § 26-250 and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Former § 26-250 derived from the 1965 Code, § 27-48(1.3); Ord. No. 3188, § 2, adopted Dec. 18, 1989; and Ord. No. 4324, § 2, adopted Nov. 7, 2005. 
Secs. 26-251-26-275. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DROUGHT CONTINGENCY PLAN[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Section 19(cc) of Ord. No. 4701, adopted June 17, 2013, repealed art. VI, §§ 26-276-26-283, which pertained to bulk water sales and derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 27-109-27-116.  Subsequently, Ord. No. 4753, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 2014, enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 26-276. - Declaration of policy, purpose and intent, and public involvement. 
(a)  The City of Denison adopts the following regulations and restriction on the delivery and consumption of water during periods of drought conditions, known as the drought contingency plan ("the plan"). The plan will conserve the available water supply and protect the integrity of water supply facilitates, with particular regard for domestic water use, sanitation, and fire protection. The purpose of these regulations is to protect the public health, welfare and safety and minimize the adverse impacts of water supply shortages or other water emergency conditions. 
(b)  As required by the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) rules in Title 30, Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 288, Subchapter B, Rule 288.20, as amended, this article addresses various situations including the following: 
 Provisions to inform the public and provide opportunity for public input; 
 Provisions for continuing public education and information; 
 Coordination with regional water planning group; 
 Criteria for initiation and termination of drought stages; 
 Initiation of drought response stages; 
 Drought and emergency response stages; 
 Specific, quantified targets for water use reductions; 
 Water supply and demand management measures for each stage; 
 Procedures for initiation and termination of drought stages; 
 Procedures for granting variances; 
 Procedures for enforcement of mandatory restrictions; 
 Consultation with wholesale supplier; 
 Notification of implementation of mandatory measures; 
 Review and update of plan. 
(c)  Prior to adoption of this plan, a public meeting will be held to receive comments. Provisions shall include actively informing the public and providing opportunity for public input in the preparation of the plan. The draft plan shall be made available for the City of Denison website and by providing a copy of the draft plan to any person requesting a copy. Wholesale water users will be given an additional opportunity to provide input into the development of the plan. 
(Ord. No. 4753, § 1, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 26-277. - Authorization of responsible official. 
    The director of public works is hereby authorized and directed to implement the applicable provisions of the plan upon determination that such implementation is necessary to protect public health, safety, and welfare of the community. The director shall have the authority to initiate or terminate stages of the plan as stated in this article. The director shall review and propose updates, if necessary, to the city council at least every five (5) years, or as required by state law. 
(Ord. No. 4753, § 1, 9-2-14) 
Sec. 26-278. - Definitions. 
    The words and terms used in this article shall have the following meaning, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(a)  The provision of the plan shall apply to all persons, users, and property utilizing water provided by the City of Denison. The terms "person" and "user" as used in the DECP includes individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations and all other legal entities. 
(b)  Aesthetic use: Water use for ornamental or decorative purposes such as fountains, reflecting pools, and water gardens. 
(c)  Commercial and institutional water use: Water use which is integral to the operations of commercial, non-profit, and governmental entities such as retail establishments, hotels and motels, restaurants, and office buildings. 
(d)  Conservation: Those practices, techniques, and technologies that reduce the consumption of water, reduce the loss or waste of water, improve the efficiency in the use of water or increase the recycling and reuse of water so that a supply is conserved and made available for future or alternative uses. 
(e)  Contamination: The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or biological) in water which tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a health hazard or impair the usefulness of the water such that the water system cannot be used. 
(f)  Customer or user: Any person, company, organization or municipality using water supplied by the City of Denison. 
(g)  Director: The City of Denison Public Works Director or designee. 
(h)  Drought: A long period of abnormally low precipitation that adversely affects growing or living conditions. 
(i)  Even number address: Street addresses, box numbers, or rural postal route numbers ending in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8 and locations without addresses. 
(j)  Industrial water users: The use of water in processes designed to convert materials of lower value into forms having greater usability and value. 
(k)  Institutional water users: Public, educational, charitable, or other organizations devoted to a particular cause or program including all levels of government agencies, schools, colleges, and healthcare facilities such as nursing homes and hospitals. 
(l)  Landscape irrigation use: Water use for irrigation and maintenance of landscaped area, whether publicly or privately owned, including residential and commercial lawns, gardens, golf courses, parks, rights-of-way, and medians. 
(m)  Non-essential water use: Water use that is neither essential nor required for the protection of public health, safety, and welfare, including: 
(1)  Irrigation of landscaped areas, including parks, athletic fields, and golf courses, except as otherwise provided under this plan; 
(2)  Use of water to wash any motor vehicle, motor bike, boat, trailer, airplane or other vehicle at any noncommercial establishment not designed for such purposes; 
(3)  Use of water to wash any sidewalks, walkways, driveways, parking lots, tennis courts, or other impervious surfaces;
